PROCTEXT.PARA: FIRST SESSION OF THE THIRTY-SIXTH PARLIAMENT
The Senate, on 21 December 1990, adjourned until 2 p.m. on Tuesday, 12 February 1991, in accordance with the resolution agreed to that day.
The President, pursuant to the resolution of the Senate passed on 21 December 1990, summoned the Senate to meet on Monday, 21 January 1991, at 2 p.m.
The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion relating to the Gulf crisis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I do not want to take an unnecessary length of time before we move onto this debate, but the Opposition is disturbed that one of the facilities open to the Opposition in meeting its responsibility is that of Question Time. We are surprised and disappointed to see that the Government has set down an order of business for today which does not include a Question Time. It is particularly relevant as both the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) are in the Senate. We would wish to ask them a whole range of questions, as we believe it is our responsibility to do on behalf of the people of this country. Today we are not being given that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand the Government has indicated that it will have a Question Time tomorrow, but that will be for simply one hour and will not provide the availability, clearly, that two Question Times would. Some of the matters that we will no doubt want to raise tomorrow will arise out of the debate that is going to take place. But there are many other questions on the public agenda now that we do not need a debate or a statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to raise.

I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) whether he is prepared to indicate the reason the Government chose not to allow the Senate a Question Time today and, in fact, whether he will consider Ministers answering questions by providing us with a Question Time at a later hour this day, either for an hour before the dinner break or an hour after the dinner break.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I understand there were discussions between Senator Ray and members of the Opposition, and I believe other parties, relating to this matter. Senator Ray is in a position to put the Government's position.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There have been no formal discussions that I am aware of, other than relayed messages to the various people that normally set up the procedures in this chamber. We were most anxious, if this chamber was not to be reduced to a second level chamber, to have a simultaneous debate with the House of Representatives. That is the sole motive for Senator Button seeking leave to move a motion at the same time. I understand that the television cameras will go from one chamber to the other. I did not want to see, firstly, this chamber relegated to a second rate chamber and, secondly, the accusation being able to be made against any of us that we were playing petty politics in Question Time prior to dealing with the motion. We listed the normal procedures for tomorrow, including petitions, notices of motion, condolences and questions because the debate will be somewhat advanced by then. There was no desire by the Government to hide from Question Time, but there was a desire to get on with this most important matter-as most people in the chamber would acknowledge-at the same time as the House of Representatives.
—The Leader of the Government in the Senate has sought leave to move a motion. Is leave granted?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations and in particular the resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait;
(b) affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 678 for support in implementing that Resolution;
(c) expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian forces serving with the United Nations-sanctioned multi-national forces in the Gulf;
(d) deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack upon Israel; and

(e) recognises, as those with whom we are acting now in the Gulf have recognised, the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel, once the crisis in the Gulf is resolved.

Mr President, on 2 August 1990 Iraq's armed forces assaulted, seized and subjugated Kuwait. Now, with the authority of the United Nations (UN), and only after Iraq has made it clear that it would defy the United Nations by remaining in Kuwait, Australia has joined a great coalition of nations in a military commitment to defeat that invasion and to restore Kuwait's sovereignty and independence.

The decision to commit Australian armed forces to combat is of course one that constitutionally is the prerogative of the Executive. It is fitting, however, that the Government places on parliamentary record the train of events behind this decision.

On 4 December I informed the Senate that following a decision of Cabinet, Australia was prepared to provide forces to participate in operations under the United Nations Security Council resolution 678 should that become necessary.

On 17 January, after consulting senior Ministers, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave effect to that decision by authorising our naval task force in the Gulf to par-ticipate in such operations. The Prime Minister then formally notified the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Governor-General of the Government's action. The Prime Minister subsequently requested you, Mr President, and the Speaker of the House of Representatives to recall Parliament so that the Prime Minister could report to the Parliament and to the nation on this grave issue, and so that honourable senators could have the opportunity to express their views.

The passage of this resolution will solemnly and forcefully underline to Iraq, to the United Nations, to our partners in the multinational force, and to our fellow Australians serving in the Gulf, the strength of Australia's support for our armed forces there and for the role to which they have been committed under the authority of the United Nations.

This is the most serious step any government can take, just as indeed war is the most serious action on which any nation can embark. In this turbulent century Australians, like many others, have endured severe trials of war and have made tremendous sacrifices to enjoy the fruits of peace. The last few days of fighting in the Middle East have served to remind us once more what a terrible price is paid when nations embark on war, and we must be prepared for worse.

The protests within Australia over recent days have reminded us too how deeply felt are the emotions aroused by any military commitment such as this. Let me assure every member of this Senate and every Australian that this Government is deeply concerned to see that this conflict is ended as soon as possible. Every decision and action we have taken since 2 August was aimed at preventing this war in the only way it could have been prevented, by upholding the United Nations resolution for the unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. Every member of this Government, not least the Prime Minister, shares with the overwhelming majority of the Australian people the sense of sadness, the compassion and sorrow for all the victims of this war, not least for the Iraqi people who have been hurled into this tragedy by a dictator.

There have been few wars-perhaps none in history-which have been debated so intensely and widely before the actual outbreak. In Australia there has been, as there should have been, the most intensive and comprehensive public debate. This is the third occasion on which the Government has initiated formal debate in the Senate.

On this occasion it is of vital importance for us as senators to ensure that our constituents-the people of Australia-understand clearly why this war has come about, why this allied military response has become necessary, why the decision to commit Australian forces was a proper and a just one and what the goals are for which we are now fighting. Australians should be ready to commit our forces to combat only in the highest cause and only as a last resort. The Government believes most fervently that the cause which our forces now serve does embody nothing less than our highest aspirations and interests, and that we have committed our forces to combat only as a last resort. Those will be my themes today.

The decision to commit Australian forces to this war in the Gulf is without historical precedent. Never has Australia's military action been undertaken with such global consent and within such a broad alliance. We stand with the coalition of nations the like of which, in its diversity, strength and authority, has never before been assembled. Never have the nations of the world acted in such overwhelming concert to condemn and to reverse an action as they have in these last few months condemned and acted to reverse Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

One hundred and forty-four nations in the United Nations General Assembly have condemned Iraq's invasion. About 40 nations have agreed to provide or help sustain military forces deployed in the Gulf to uphold the United Nations position. North Atlantic Treaty Organisation nations, former Soviet bloc nations, Arab nations, Muslim nations, Pacific nations-nations from every continent-have provided troops, ships, aircraft, medical teams, supplies and money. Members of this coalition are now conducting military action with the highest authority that the international community can bestow-the authority of the United Nations Security Council, given in resolution 678.

The reason this unprecedented coalition has come into existence is to achieve and preserve three interests of truly global importance. Each of these three interests is of tangible importance to each of the members of the coalition of nations, including Australia. None of the three can be achieved without first achieving, as the essential precondition, the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. These are indeed stakes worth fighting for, by peaceful means if possible but by force of arms if necessary.

First, we seek to establish the conditions for peace and stability in the critical region of the Middle East. There can be no security in the Middle East while Iraq remains in occupation of Kuwait or continues to threaten the whole region. As this resolution acknowledges, it can only be after the current crisis is resolved that we can, as we must, intensify our efforts to establish peace and stability in the region, including through convening an international conference as part of this objective. As honourable senators know, we supported the concept of an international conference before this conflict erupted. We continue to do so.

Secondly, we seek to prevent the catastrophic distortion and disruption of the international economy that would result from Saddam Hussein being placed to pursue his goal of domination of the world oil market. This can be done only by restoring Kuwait's sovereignty. Let me nail that easy but mindless catchcry `no blood for oil'-as though we could somehow wish away the strategic, utterly vital nature of oil to our daily lives for the prosperity of our nation and the economic health of the world. The one who is shedding blood for oil is Saddam, who has shed the blood of so many Kuwait people on the altar of his ambitions, as he did for eight years the blood of his own and the Iranian people for the same purpose. It is he who seeks to dominate the oil market, and it would be he who would exact for it not only an economic but also a political and strategic price.

Thirdly, beyond even these vital interests, we seek to achieve the promise of a freer, more peaceful and more prosperous world order in which the goals of the charter of the United Nations can at last be fulfilled-the promise that, until Iraq invaded Kuwait, was so tantalisingly within our reach now that we have put behind us the draining rivalry of the Cold War.
The history of civilisation is in large part about the attempt of humankind to move from the law of the jungle, where blood and might prevail, to the rule of free men by just law.

It is a tragic truth, however, that our century has known more of the jungle than of justice: two world wars and tens of millions dead; countless smaller wars; and the development of weapons of mass destruction-chemical, biological and nuclear. The League of Nations collapsed, and for many years the United Nations was emasculated by great power contention, thereby denying the world, especially smaller nations like Australia, the prospect of a just system of collective security.

The last few years, however, have seen a dramatic turnaround. The Cold War has ended. The prospect of global nuclear holocaust has significantly diminished. Despite the current problems within the Soviet Union, we must hope, and work towards ensuring, that there will be no return to the superpower confrontation of the past.

We have entered a new global environment where the possibility of effective United Nations response to conflict or aggression has been growing ever stronger. The United Nations, in which the great powers now cooperate, has helped or is helping to bring peace in Namibia, Afghanistan, between Iran and Iraq itself, and potentially to Cambodia.
Saddam Hussein's special guilt lies in his defiance of the United Nations and his attempt to return to the era of unpunished aggression.

And our special responsibility is to try once more, but this time with real hope in our hearts, for an effective international system against aggression, a system in which all countries, great and small, play a part. If we fail in this obligation, in this the first test of the new international order after the Cold War, the consequences for our medium and long term security and for that of many other countries are deeply disturbing.

For those who say that this international system, centred on the United Nations Charter, is a system which rejects the use of force, I say that they have not read the Charter-or if they have, they choose now, conveniently, to ignore it. The centrepiece of the United Nations Charter, as established in the 1940s, was the collective use of force in extreme cases where no other way was left to punish and defeat aggression. This should be utterly unsurprising. The United Nations was, after all, founded by men and women who had just lived through a global slaughter the like of which had never been seen before. They knew why this slaughter had happened. It happened because men and women of decency, compassion and hope had turned their eyes away from the great evil which had arisen in their time. They hoped it could be reasoned with, placated; it could not.

It seems that each generation has to learn anew the same hard truth-that peace without justice is a dangerous charade but that peace with justice is not given free of charge, but sometimes demands a high and terrible price.
As the Prime Minister said to the people of Australia on Thursday, Mr President:

We all of us wish for peace. But we cannot have peace just by wishing for it or just by talking about it; we have to work for it, and sometimes, tragically, we have to fight for it. The great lesson of this century is that peace is bought at too high a price, if that price is the appeasement of aggression.

Do any of us believe that, if allowed to go unchecked, Saddam would have been content with Kuwait? Does anyone believe that he would not have sought to master Saudi Arabia and the other Gulf states, and manipulate his control over the world's oil supply, to the massive detriment not only of developed countries like Australia but also developing countries and the newly-emerging democracies of eastern Europe? Does anyone doubt that he would have used, once more, his chemical weapons-against his own people, or against his neighbours? Who doubts he would have continued to develop, and then perhaps use, biological and nuclear weapons?
These concerns are not merely our speculations-they reflect his actions in the past and in many cases his explicit threats for the future.

This is a leader who, after his eight-year war with Iran, has attacked, without provocation, two countries in the last six months: Kuwait and, only in the last few days, Israel. This is a man who has brutalised his own people and the people of Kuwait, and who was prepared to take innocent hostages, including Australians, and use them as human shields.

This is a self-proclaimed leader of the Arab people, who has killed Arabs and crushed an Arab nation. He did not, as he later claimed, invade Kuwait for the sake of the Palestinians. Indeed, his exploitation of the Palestinian cause was for the most callous and transparent of reasons-to help him satisfy his own greed and territorial ambitions.

The Government is confident that the majority of the Australian people understand and accept the reason why this war has come about and why Australia has become involved. We believe the majority of Australians recognise the magnitude of Iraq's challenge to the world community and the importance of our campaign to meet and overcome the challenge. There are, of course, some voices raised in protest against the war and against our involvement. The Government does not in any way question the right of those voices to be heard-vocal protest is a proud part of Australia's democratic heritage-but it most profoundly disagrees with what those voices are saying today.

Here in the Senate, with logic and patience, let those criticisms be answered. It is vitally important, as we embark on a military endeavour that may not be short or simple, that every Australian understands the facts-not the slogans or dogmas, but facts-on which the Government's position is based. We have heard some say that this alliance serves only to promote the interests of the United States. But truly, Mr President, it serves the interests of the United Nations and of each of its members, including, of course, the United States, who rightly demand the freedom of collective security and individual sovereignty.

We have heard others say that this is purely an Arab problem requiring an Arab solution. But the solution chosen by Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria and the Gulf states, including Kuwait itself, is clear: it is to seek the support of the United Nations and to participate in the multinational force against Iraq.

Mr President, we have heard others still who oppose this war and this Australian involvement because they opposed the Vietnam war and Australia's involvement in it. To them we say: do not debase the principled opposition that was voiced to the war in Vietnam and do not demean the motives of those who opposed it. Today we face a conflict of an utterly different kind. None of the great principles at stake in the Gulf-the principles I have outlined in the Senate today and previously-was at stake in Vietnam, and none of the principles on which we based our opposition to the Vietnamese war applies to the Gulf today. Most significantly, on this occasion as distinct from then, the processes which sought first to avoid conflict and which now mandate this action are the processes of the United Nations.

The Government has appreciated the bipartisan support given to it at this time by Opposition members, and I take this opportunity to thank them for it. They will therefore understand the sense in which I make this point. My Party disagreed with Australian involvement in Vietnam. That is a clear matter of record which needs no elaboration here. But the Government will not be dissuaded from taking what is the right decision today by the invocation of that decision of 25 years ago-it is irrelevant and massively irrelevant.

There is one issue on which all Australians of goodwill must stand united at this time. That is, we should all condemn without qualification any harassment, abuse or discrimination directed against Arabic and Muslim Australians. The suggestion that the entirely understandable concern of these people for their relatives, friends and former homelands constitutes some kind of disloyalty to Australia is a perverse and utterly distasteful one to me and to this Government-particularly so since, in the words of so many Arab Australians, they enjoy and value their new life in this country precisely because Australia is a land of peace, civil liberties and religious tolerance.

I am aware that there are many in the community who may well accept all that has been said so far, but who still feel disquiet on the grounds of timing-who judge that the allied military response is premature. Let me remind these people that this war did not begin on 17 January 1991. This war is not four days old. It began on 2 August last year, when Iraq invaded Kuwait. It is a war now in its sixth month. It is a war that has been fought against the innocent people of Kuwait in flagrant defiance of world opinion. It has been a war of ruthless suppression of Kuwaiti resistance fighters. It has been a war of systematic and premeditated plunder of Kuwait's assets by its greedy neighbour.

It has been a war that has forced hundreds of thousands of Kuwaiti and foreign nationals out of their rightful homes. And it has been a war, as Amnesty International reported on 19 December, where the human rights of those who remain in Kuwait have been repeatedly and awfully violated, including through detention, torture, rape and summary executions.

In this war, an allied military response began only on 17 January. And none of the destruction that has been caused to Iraq's military capabilities in the allied bombing since then would have been necessary-none of it-had Saddam simply brought a halt to this war by complying with the United Nations and withdrawing his forces unconditionally from Kuwait. He can still bring a halt to this war by such compliance and withdrawal. We continue to hope that he will do so.

So, Mr President, let it be clearly understood that we-the allied nations-did not initiate this war; we did not want this war. We sought to resolve this conflict by diplomacy, not by force. But let it be equally clear why diplomacy could not prevent this war.

Throughout the 5 1/2 months since it invaded Kuwait, Iraq has ignored or rejected every international initiative aimed at resolving the crisis by peaceful means. The United Nations Security Council has, since the invasion, passed 12 resolutions on the issue. The message and the extent of its international support could not have been made clearer to Iraq.

Finally, six weeks ago, the United Nations authorised the use of military force, if that should prove necessary, to compel Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. The Security Council gave Iraq until 15 January-`as a pause of goodwill'-to withdraw of its own free will. Those six weeks passed. Iraq did not withdraw its forces from Kuwait. It showed no willingness even to consider withdrawing those forces. It refused the very generous proposals put forward by the UN Secretary-General as late as last week.

Over those weeks the nations supporting the UN made it clear that they were resolved, if there was no alternative, to liberate Kuwait by force in accordance with the UN's resolutions. Iraq's Government was under no illusions about that resolve. It knew it had only two choices: to withdraw peacefully or be expelled by force.

Over that same period Iraq's Government made it more and more clear that it had no intention of withdrawing from Kuwait. Saddam Hussein talked about negotiation, but he never talked about concession. Nothing that he said suggested that Iraq would ever relinquish Kuwait. Everything he did made it clear that he intended to hold Kuwait forever. Because that has been Saddam Hussein's decision, the rest of the world has faced a choice equally stark, and equally tragic; we must either accept Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, or we must fight to reverse it. There is, now, no other way. And the world has agreed that Iraq's seizure of Kuwait cannot be allowed to stand.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Vallentine

TALK.START.PARA: —The world has not agreed; only 28 countries.

INTERJECT.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Vallentine. If there are any more repetitions or outbursts like that from the gallery I will have the people in the galleries removed.

—The UN has demanded that Iraq should withdraw because the invasion of Kuwait, the destruction of its state, the slaughter of its people and the plundering of its wealth are contrary to every principle upon which the UN was built, and upon which peace depends.

SPEECH.PARA: The UN has demanded that Iraq withdraw unconditionally because the nations of the world recognise that making concessions to aggressors is like making concessions to terrorists; it makes the world more dangerous for everyone.

The UN has agreed that, by giving concessions to the invader of Kuwait, we give away the principles upon which the United Nations was founded. Those principles are not airy abstractions; they are the laws that make the world safe for all of us. It cost the world the Second World War to establish those principles; they are too precious and too important to be bargained away to save Saddam Hussein's face. They are important enough to fight for.

At this moment of crisis, let us pay tribute to the courage and skill of our fellow Australians who serve aboard the HMAS Brisbane, the HMAS Sydney and the HMAS Success. They do us proud. They know the importance of the task we have asked them to perform; we know that whatever the danger they will perform that task as well as it can be done. We want them to know, and we want their families and loved ones to know, that we will bring them home as soon as possible when the job is done.

But let us ask the question in its most basic form. Why should Australia, here in the southern oceans, send its young men and women to fight thousands of kilometres from our shores? Why should we be concerned with, `a far away country of which we know little'-if I may borrow from Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain his description of Czechoslovakia as he consigned it to destruction in 1938? The answer, of course, lies in that very event-the fatal appeasement of Hitler.

The Czechoslovakians know something of life under a tyranny, having emerged from the Nazi scourge only to come under the rule of totalitarian communism. So it was truly significant to hear that the new democratically elected Government of Czechoslovakia expressed on 17 January its full support for the Gulf action. Earlier, President Vaclav Havel had said that no price is too high where aggression is concerned. Of course, there is special force, as well as poignancy, in that statement from President Havel. Czechoslovakia symbolises not only our terrible failures of the 1930s but also our great hopes for the 1990s and beyond. That is why his words are both a statement and a symbol of why this allied military campaign is necessary.

Czechoslovakians, invaded by a neighbour and abandoned by the rest of the world in 1938, know how important it is that Kuwait, invaded by its neighbour, not be abandoned by the rest of the world in 1991. They know it and, with the overthrow of the tyrannies of eastern Europe, they can express it and moreover can do something about it. Today, Czechoslovakian chemical decontamination teams are supporting the multinational effort to free Kuwait.

The allied nations, with Australia, shall prevail against Iraq's aggression. We shall restore the sovereignty of Kuwait. In doing that we shall have done much more: we shall have established the conditions for peace and stability in the Middle East. We shall have protected the health of the international economy and we shall have erected and strengthened the framework for a world order in which all nations can live in greater peace and harmony.

Sadly, of course, no-one can expect that there will never again be a dictator like Saddam or an outrage such as his invasion of Kuwait. But by our actions now we will have made it harder for such outrages to be perpetrated and we will have made it easier for them to be punished and remedied by the world community, because each time aggression is resisted it becomes harder for the next aggressor; just as each time aggression is appeased, it becomes easier for the next. Australia, as much as any country, must surely value that achievement. We must surely value the way the world is asserting this truth.

The very coalition building that has united us since last August and the very resolve displayed by us through the United Nations are the very qualities that we want to preserve and protect when this Iraqi crisis is over. They are the very qualities that we want to see as the hallmarks of the new world order. It is fundamental to everything the Government has said today that when this crisis is over we will have opened the way to a safer and more peaceful world-a community of nations working more harmoniously through a reinvigorated and more effective United Nations organisation. Mr President, in such a world we are entitled to hold this basic and earnest wish: that we will be able to devote ourselves, as never before, to the real and urgent tasks of peace; not expending our resources on war, but investing them in social justice, economic development and human freedom.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). I will take this opportunity to reiterate the reasons for the Opposition's support of the Australian commitment in this conflict. I also want to look at the new security order which might come out of the Gulf war and, in particular, what actions Australia might take in concert with others to influence an outcome which would enhance peace, stability and security.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, however, three preliminary points that I want to make. The first relates to the Parliament being given the opportunity to debate these issues, albeit after the commencement of the war. As you know, Mr President, parliaments in most democracies have been meeting and have endorsed the decisions of their respective governments to commit the use of force in bringing to an end the unlawful and brutal occupation of Kuwait by Saddam Hussein's forces. It is clear that the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, had no intention of calling the Australian Parliament together and would not have done so but for the fact that he knew that the Senate was out of his control and was likely to be recalled. That conclusion is only logical from the statements that were made by the Acting Foreign Minister, the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Dr Blewett, and the spokesman for Mr Hawke.

Whilst the Parliament should not seek to usurp the constitutional functions of government, it is Parliament to which this Government is accountable, and the elected representatives of the Australian people should have the opportunity of questioning Ministers, receiving reports from government, and debating these momentous issues. I reiterate the regret I expressed a few moments ago that the Government has declined to give us the opportunity to question Ministers today on these matters.

I have said before that there is no more grave a decision that a government might take than to commit Australia's Defence Force to armed conflict. We therefore want to make it clear that the Government should not assume that further issues will not develop over the next few days and weeks which in our minds will also require debate in this place, and may require debate before the Parliament is due to resume. The parliamentary system is a key to our democracy and our freedom. Our forces are being sent to help free another people who do not have our privileges and our safeguards. It is important that our safeguards are not taken for granted.

The second preliminary matter I wish to raise concerns our armed forces. I take the opportunity, as the Minister did, to commend the contribution that our armed services make to our security. Those who give a life of service in this way, who know that in the event of hostilities it will be their lives that they commit for our protection, deserve much greater community recognition and support than they usually receive. This commendation includes their families, who make sacrifices simply by being service families but also know that their loved ones might be called upon at any time to make the supreme sacrifice. In commending Australia's forces in the Gulf, I include those who just as easily could be there. The Defence Force must know that we genuinely appreciate and recognise their key contribution to our society and our way of life.

The third point I make arises out of the coverage of the war, which to me is being sensationalised. What is not coming through the coverage is the horror of war, the fear, the wasted lives, the maimed bodies and the families destroyed. In our liberal democracy we must reserve the use of force to preserve a freedom and a greater peace. It is legitimate to join collectively to do that, but the decision to use force of arms to achieve political objectives must always be recognised as a decision of enormous gravity. We can and should be proud of our forces. We can be pleased with the technical sophistication of our equipment, which hopefully will enable the achievement of objectives with the minimum loss of life, but we must never glorify military conflict.

It seems to me that President Bush, in carefully limiting the attack in terms of loss of life, in leaving open the option to Saddam Hussein to yield at any time and for his people to suffer no more, and for his care and caution, should be commended. He has acted with great dignity and we are fortunate that the world's great superpower is being led in this way. We are a little disappointed that that is not being recognised in the terms of the resolution that has been put to us.

It is also important, as I said, to reiterate the position of the Opposition from the start of this crisis some five months ago. We supported an Australian contribution to resist the expansionist policies of Saddam Hussein and, in particular, his forceful taking of Kuwait. We in fact called upon the Australian Government to make a contribution in respect of what we perceived to be Australian interests at risk: first, the need to respect the sanctity and security of states from unjustified aggression; secondly, the peril of allowing an unanswerable dictator control over so much of the world's economy through, of course, the control of oil and the consequent suffering and conflict which could result therefrom-which does not seem to be appreciated by so many; thirdly, the need to preserve order and stability in a more complex world environment which was likely to follow the breaking down of the major power blocs-an end to the bipolar world, as it has been referred to. Mr President, in our opinion these are Australia's interests.

We supported Australia joining in the United Nations (UN) resolutions and sending forces in support of the sanctions and their use, if it was ultimately necessary, to forcibly remove Saddam Hussein from Kuwait. We believe that the Australian Government made the right decision. Certainly, we criticise the ambiguity of the original assessment, the confusion between Ministers over rules of engagement and the like, the lack of consultation with people such as the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the divisions within the Government party, the Australian Labor Party, which demonstrated a lack of unity when it was necessary to show the strength of the Government's resolve. But we believe that the ultimate decisions were correct and we say so-no ifs or buts.

We saw sanctions as principally demonstrating the depth of resolve of the world community. They were to be part of a message. But we realised that if Saddam Hussein was not prepared to listen, sanctions would never force his withdrawal. Such is his style that he would make the people of Iraq suffer further before he would meet the international requirement.

Regrettably, the decision to use force, in our opinion, had to be made and, as I said, in our view it was the correct decision. Those who doubt that, Mr President, should remember the following: first, it must be remembered there was no justification for Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. Certainly, there was a quarrel over the price of oil. Saddam Hussein's nation, impoverished after eight years of war-which I must say he started-with Iran, wished that Kuwait would forgo its debts. And there was, of course, a dispute over the Rumaila oilfields. All these were capable of resolution by peaceful means. But Saddam Hussein acted in the only way he seemed to know to achieve an objective-through the use of brute force.

If historical claims were to be accepted as a legitimate basis for forceful invasion and occupation, then there would be no end to wars. So many of the national boundaries have been achieved through previous conflict or political bargains or seem to us to be arbitrary. But the current basis under which nation states seek to live in peace under the UN Charter is that they will respect those boundaries.

Secondly, it should be remembered that Saddam Hussein's invasion and occupation was carried out with great brutality. Amnesty International has published horrifying accounts of the terror, the murder, the rape and, in fact, the systematic terror inflicted by the invading forces. If one adds to that the looting and pillage, as everything of value in Kuwait was seized, stripped and transported to Iraq, one is entitled to come to no other conclusion than that the conduct was totally abhorrent.

Certainly, Kuwaiti leaders may live an extravagant lifestyle. There may not be in Kuwait the form of social justice which we might like to see. The powers of the Emir might be largely non-democratic. But none of these factors justified invasion and Saddam Hussein certainly could not claim that he was offering greater legitimacy in the field of democracy.

Mr President, thirdly we should never forget the inhuman use of innocent hostages to achieve political objectives. Already in some circles that behaviour is being forgotten. In using hostages as human shields for military installations, any semblance of internationally acceptable behaviour was forfeited. Fourthly, it must be remembered that the world community went to unprecedented lengths to convince him that he should voluntarily withdraw his forces.

These representations from friends and foe alike were universally dismissed by Saddam. After the visit of UN Secretary-General Perez de Cuellar, it was apparent that Saddam Hussein was never going to voluntarily withdraw from Kuwait and that he would rather sacrifice his people than bow to the requirements of the international community to abandon his territorial acquisition. To the UN Secretary-General, an undisputed man of peace, he offered no hope-nothing at all to take back to the international community. Therefore, in the opinion of the coalition parties in this country, we believe that President Bush then had no other choice but to make the fateful decision that would lead the international alliance into war.

I am not going to deal with the technical aspects of the military conflict, assessment of hardware, tactics or other such matters but, as I said at the outset, I want to look at the form of regional or world order which might come out of the conflict and, in particular, the progress or otherwise towards a more stable and secure world order.

There is no doubt that this war will in fact change the face of the region. With the defeat of Iraq, a major power vacuum could occur. But Iraqi policy over the past decade has hardly contributed to stability within the region. It has involved the Arab world in two major wars, the first of which lasted for eight years and cost one million lives. Iraq's quest for nuclear weapons had once provoked an Israeli attack and during the last two years had inflamed tension between Arabs and Israelis to levels unprecedented since 1973. The power vacuum, nevertheless, must be addressed.

There are those who have benefited and will benefit from the demise of Saddam Hussein's regime. Iran has already benefited significantly from the crisis over the last five months. Its enemy has been isolated from the rest of the world, the pre-1980 boundary between it and Iraq has been restored and it has experienced increased oil revenues. With Saddam Hussein's defeat, its most dangerous enemy will have been removed and the 1988 armed truce will have become much less fragile. Iran, however, will continue to resent any ongoing US presence. Its attitude towards Israel is also unlikely to change without at least a settlement of the Palestinian issue. How to bring Iran back into the family of cooperative nations is one of the greatest challenges the world community will have to face.

Egyptians will probably emerge with their leadership of the moderate Arab world intact and possibly strengthened. President Mubarak has clearly acted more skilfully than his admittedly courageous predecessor in rebuilding Arab support, but again there is evident in Egypt an underlying pan-Arabism which Saddam Hussein seems to be engendering. Again there is evidence of the fundamentalist forces which will seek to achieve political objectives through violent means, as they have done before in Egypt. Again, as in the case of so much of the Arab world, we find a country under enormous economic stress and, as we know, economic stress leads to instability and often political cost.

The role of Syria throughout the crisis has been one of great ambiguity and uncertainty. More than any other group the Syrian leadership has been deeply torn by the choices facing it. Its enmity towards its Iraqi sister regime has driven it into alliance with the United States and moderate Arab states, but its deep hatred of Israel remains. It is likely, after the war, that Syria will project itself as the most determined opponent of Israel. Its poor economic position and declining Soviet assistance to its armed forces will, however, almost certainly limit its ability to take independent action against the Israelis. Apart from the isolation of Baghdad, Syria has gained one significant advantage from the crisis: it has gained control over a vast proportion of Lebanon, including Beirut. It had a fair proportion before the conflict, but it has seized the advantage to take more.

Whilst this control is still fragile, it has to be recognised as a large step towards Syria achieving a goal which has eluded it for 14 years. The consequence of this control to certain minorities in Lebanon, particularly the Christians, is unclear, but to be other than concerned would be foolish. Syria has gained this advantage under the shield of its alliance contribution. It has therefore extracted advantage at potentially considerable cost. It might be argued, however, that its further commitment in the Lebanon will, at least in the short term, be a further factor in restricting its ability to take unilateral action against Israel.

Apart from that of the Palestinians, Jordan's future is the most uncertain and problematic. King Hussein has previously traded on his reputation as a moderate Arab leader to secure support from the West and Saudi Arabia. This support will almost certainly dry up in the short term. He will have lost support of the Palestinians in his country. In order to accommodate his generally pro-Iraqi population, he has been driven to deal with political groups outside the traditional elite he has hitherto relied on. His recently elected parliament, with a clearly fundamentalist bent, has carried resolutions in support of Iraq. The stability of Jordan has been important to Israel and an unstable and impotent Jordan will present difficult policy decisions in the future.

The Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) typically nailed its colours to the mast of the Arab strongman it thought could challenge Israel, swiftly destroying the efforts of recent years to earn respectability with the West as a negotiating partner. It has not only now lost that credibility but also the sponsorship, particularly financial, of critical states such as Saudi Arabia as well as further alienating itself from Egypt with which it had been rebuilding bonds. This places the PLO in a desperate position and one fears that its answer might be to again resort more often to terrorism.

Whilst there was no suggestion that Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait to benefit the Palestinians, the crisis and his subsequent attempt at linkage has nevertheless served to bring the Palestinian question back to the attention of the world community. It is clear that there will be no ongoing peace or security within the Middle East until the Palestinian issue is resolved. I say that, of course, emphasising that any attempt at linkage must be avoided.

Throughout the Muslim world, far beyond just Arab communities, there is a certain solidarity with the Palestinian people and their perceived injustice. On the other hand, international conference or not, Israel will not reach an accommodation with the Palestinian people, and cannot be expected to do so, whilst it remains in a state of war with practically all Arab nations. It will not sacrifice its security for an insecure peace. Until the Arab and Islamic world is prepared to make peace with Israel, the Palestinian issue will remain unresolved.

An international conference, which is just another opportunity for the release of vitriol, might well be counterproductive. A better option might be a working group set up under the auspices of the Secretary-General of the UN-including the US, the European Community, Arab nations and Israel-to explore options. I have always thought-and notwithstanding the failures of the PLO in this exercise-that a settlement without the contribution of the PLO remains unlikely. I believe, therefore, that it should be given representation in any such group but that there should also be direct representation from the allied territories.

For Israel to accept such a working group would be an accommodation that it has not been prepared to make to date, because clearly it has not been prepared to deal with terrorists. But there are new concerns for Israel. The relative ease at which missiles are getting through; the fact that the first Islamic nation is not far off achieving nuclear weapons; the fact that settlement of this conflict will lead to massive rearmament within the region, the merit of which I doubt but which no doubt will occur; the growing power and sophistication in weaponry of countries such as Egypt, which may not always be under leadership such as that President Mubarak gives; and the growing loss of patience for Israel in Europe as to failure to achieve a resolution of these issues-all of those factors should be causing Israel to reconsider its long term security strategy.

With regard to Iraq, there is no value in destroying Iraq as a nation. For years it has been seen to provide a balance and the rationale for that policy has not changed. What might happen to the Kurdish people in such a vacuum is too horrible to contemplate-the people who have, of course, already suffered the consequence of poison gas attack at the hands of Saddam Hussein.

The Gulf states will feel particularly vulnerable after this conflict and, in all likelihood, will seek a continuing United States (US) presence. Saudi Arabia might do likewise or compromise with some form of forward positions capacity. The US, having invested so much towards the goal of stability, will be tempted to accept these invitations. Yet, in the longer term, Islamic nations are not going to accept a continuing US presence which will grow as a focus for resentment and eventually lead to instability. The US must be particularly careful of simply being seen by the Arab masses as propping up feudal-type regimes which serve its interests. Reform will come from within such countries in due course and will provide new challenges, particularly to US policy-makers.

There must be greater effort made in the West to understand the Islamic and Arab peoples and their aspirations. Even within a country such as ours, more effort needs to be made to better understand our Muslim community, which numbers over 300,000. There is a deeply held view within the Arab world that they are exploited, that they have been milked of their natural wealth-that is, oil-and that their nations have been manipulated by Western powers and they suffer the indignity of holy places within occupied lands. It is true that millions of Arab people live in appalling conditions and there are in this tones of the north-south debate running through Arab issues. What I am saying is that it is important, in the long term, in the aspiration of seeking peace and stability within this region, to make more effort to understand the Arab point of view.

So there are major challenges which will arise out of a victory in war. It will not simply be a case of order replacing disorder. The Palestinian issue will have to be resolved; notwithstanding that, we reject linkage. Greater efforts will have to be made to overcome injustice and oppression within the Arab world. It is vitally important that the Arab world regain its dignity, which has been further shattered by Saddam Hussein's abuses. A formula will have to be found which enables Iraq to re-establish itself, hopefully under new leadership which will work to the goal of peace and improved prosperity for the long-suffering Iraqi people.

The United Nations, having been given new life, can help but it still has a long way to go. The UN can only be as useful as nation states allow it to be. Although it has played a useful function in this instance in providing a forum for debate, a forum for the coalescing of opinion and a sanction for actions that are to be taken, it is not the UN itself that has been able to resolve this issue; it is the US, in fact, that took the leadership. There is still no demonstration that the big powers wish to give the UN the authority of maintaining security, and probably it would still be premature.

This is an area in which Australia could play a visionary role. We have a good record in peacekeeping forces and other international functions. In this instance the US has shown leadership and made an enormous commitment. As the new multipolar world develops, it might not always be willing to do so, which lifts our responsibility and that of nations such as ours, which share our values, to meet it.

We pray that Iraq's aggression will be repelled, that the occupation will end soon, that the war will end quickly and with minimum loss of life on all sides. We look forward to then working to help meet the challenge of contributing to a more peaceful, stable and secure world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are here today debating a motion with regard to the conflict in the Middle East, a motion put before this Parliament concurrently in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. This is happening because those of us here in the Senate would not stand by and allow the Government to continue to make these decisions without debate in this Parliament, and I certainly welcome the opportunity to have this debate, albeit after the fact.

SPEECH.PARA: It defies belief that we are as a nation again at war. As we debate this motion, bombs with a total explosive power exceeding the Hiroshima nuclear weapon are being dropped daily on Iraq and Kuwait. Missiles are launched at non-military targets in Israel and Saudi Arabia, and there is a whole range of weapons with obscene potential for destruction being unleashed on vast numbers in the name of peace and the construction of a new world order. This is a war which need not be happening, this is a war which should not be happening, and this is a war in which Australia should not be involved.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Can I appeal to the gallery to be reasonable. Every honourable senator has the right to be heard in reasonable silence, and I would suggest to the people in the gallery that if they wish to listen to a particular senator, in this case Senator Powell, they listen in silence because if they do not I shall have to take action.

—Thank you, Mr President. Despite the billing of this war as being an unprecedented television event, the immense suffering which is being inflicted daily is largely still out of view. We have seen the trauma of Israelis injured by Iraqi Scud missiles. We know the sufferings of the Kuwaitis under Iraq's brutal occupation, and we know Western airmen have died. Iraqis too have died in their thousands; most of these would be service personnel, but many would be civilians. None of these Iraqis have had any influence over the actions taken in their name by the dictatorial and brutal regime of Saddam Hussein. In their own way too they are innocent victims.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it is normal in war time to regard one's adversary's casualties as regrettable but unavoidable, we do not have the luxury in this case because the long term consequences of this carnage are likely to rebound badly against our own interests, and because death and destruction on the scale now being wrought-which in all probability already exceeds that wreaked by Iraq on Kuwait-was avoidable if alternative and peaceful means had been committed to by the United States, our country and other coalition nations. An alternative approach was in place and would have worked. That alternative was not appeasement, it was an alternative which sought instead to drive Iraq from Kuwait by means which were non-violent, civilised and proportionate to the initial crime, and would have prevented the emergence of deep divisions in the international community which are now inevitable.

The sanctions imposed on Iraq, the most effective and swift in world history, would almost certainly have had their desired effect if given time to work. The initial euphoric predictions of a quick victory have now been replaced by sober assessments that the war with Iraq will probably last months and will be bloody and costly, as many of us said in the months past as this inevitable consequence was being built up by the United States, by Australia and by other participating nations.

Anti-Western pro-Muslim feeling has erupted in many nations in Asia, deepening an existing international division based on religion, wealth and access to resources. Divisions are occurring within nations, including our own, as the government supports war while the people call for peace. The people's voice deserves to be heard in this place equally with that of the leadership which has now become arrogant and distanced from the people it is supposed to represent.

If the war goes on it is likely Iraq will ultimately be defeated, of course, but the hatred and resentment which spring from defeat will affect many generations of Iraqis and others to come, and will sooner or later come back to haunt us. None of this need have happened.

There is much talk of the war being sanctioned, and that is the term used in the motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and by the United Nations Security Council in resolution 678. But resolution 678 called only for all necessary means to be used to remove Iraq from Kuwait. That is what the argument is about, to the extent that there is an argument in this Parliament, and thank goodness for the presence of those of us who are prepared to argue the case. While this leaves open the possible use of force of course, it also leaves it open to individual nations whether they believe that the use of force is warranted, and if so, whether to commit forces to war.

I would here like to stress that any of the reservations which I am expressing on behalf of my Party, and I believe on behalf of the majority of the Australian people, are not reservations with regard to our confidence in and our support of the service personnel who are deployed now in the Gulf. We certainly support that part of the motion of the Prime Minister, but we place the burden of responsibility where it belongs, squarely on the shoulders of the Federal Government and the Federal Opposition.

In our judgment there was no need to use force, as I have said, and no compulsion for Australia to take part in the United States led attack. It is possible at any time for our commitment in this obscene war to be reversed, and for the Australian Government to begin working for an immediate cease fire and a peaceful and just-and I stress the word just-resolution of the conflict. We have to ask ourselves whether placing the Emirs of Kuwait back in their positions of leadership in that nation would constitute justice.

I wish to speak about the sanctions and the diplomatic action the subject of resolution 661, the first resolution of the United Nations that is relevant to the potential for a genuine new world order. That resolution represents the strongest action taken by the United Nations in this conflict, imposing mandatory and comprehensive sanctions on Iraq and Kuwait until Iraq withdraws. Resolution 661 won universal acceptance, including by this nation, and that was very much to our credit since we had a great deal to lose in trade terms. We hit ourselves in our own hip pocket where it hurts most. It was recognised from the outset that sanctions would need time to work, and we were repeatedly reminded of this by our own Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and his United States counterpart, the Secretary of State, James Baker. Sanctions experts reminded us that at least a year, perhaps two, would be needed. They also predicted that given the unprecedented effect of the sanctions, which have reduced Iraq's trade to a trickle, and given also Iraq's extraordinary dependence on trade, that the chances of success were very high. I would like to recall the words of Senator Evans on 31 August 1990, and I quote:
There is no basis for assuming that the situation will be resolved by the end of the year . . .
We must remain committed to staying the cause, doing everything we can as a nation, paying whatever price is necessary and securing a principal peace, however long it takes.
That is the end of the quote from Senator Evans. Whilst not ruling out the use of military force, Senator Evans noted that it was a means of last resort, and again I quote Senator Evans:
The concept of a quick, clean surgical strike to wipe out key installations while avoiding a wider conflagration, is a think-tank fantasy. . . .
How right the honourable senator was. I go on with the quote from Senator Evans:
Any such exercise would be prolonged, messy and not especially productive.

Again I could not agree more. That was in August 1990, and I remind Senator Evans that the judgment remains valid now. Senator Evans, our Foreign Minister, repeated similar sentiments in October and early November, but in mid-November the Prime Minister stepped in. Reflecting a shift in the Bush Administration's position, he foreshadowed war, culminating in the December decision to commit our naval forces to the present conflict.

The fact is, as Professor Halliday warned in a Guardian Weekly article just two weeks after the invasion of Kuwait, that the Pentagon began agitating for a military strike from the outset. Within weeks its initial deployment for supposedly defensive purposes became an offensive force. The Pentagon never wanted sanctions to work. Our Government simply fell in behind this view.

I would like to quote from an article in the Guardian Weekly which sums up what happened. That article was published on 23 December. I want to quote fully from this article because it is such a good assessment. The heading is an important one from the point of view of the position held by the Australian Democrats and, as I said, I believe by more than 50 per cent of the Australian community. The article, headed `Sanctions are not ``appeasement'' ', states:
One interesting figure needs to be kept constantly in mind during another week of increasingly frazzled Gulf diplomacy.
This was the week before Christmas, I remind the Senate. I continue:
And the interesting thing about the interesting figure is how easily men who should remember it seem to forget.

The figure popped onto the public record only a couple of weeks ago, when the director of the CIA, William Webster, was giving evidence on Capitol Hill. He was talking about sanctions. Iraqi exports, he said, had been slashed by 97 per cent. That is an astonishing statistic (even more so than his Iraqi imports estimate, a mere 10 per cent of the trade before Saddam annexed Kuwait). It shows how total the embargo has become. It means the Baghdad regime is inexorably running out of the commodity on which its future depends: money. Oil revenues are the drip feed of Baghdad's life support system. Without them, the dictatorship will inevitably perish.
Why don't the allies trumpet this success? Why don't they repeatedly hail the economic noose that unprecedentedly effective, concerted world action has slipped around the transgressor's neck?

TALK.START.PARA: —It took only 20 years to work in South Africa!
—The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: These are uncomfortable questions.
And I note Senator Macdonald's discomfort. It goes on:

The basic answer is that so much rhetoric and costly effort has been invested in the other melo- dramatic track of the policy-military build up, threatening war-that the slower burn of sanctions can't be stressed. Mr Bush cannot afford to wait.
No, Mr Bush could not afford to wait 15 years; he has a re-election coming up before 15 years are over. The article continues:

And when, as now, he pauses in anxiety, seeking an extra mile of diplomacy, his own previous dismissals of sanctions seem to leave that policy hanging irrelevantly as some wet, wimpish, purely delaying tactic.
It needs to be calmly observed that this is not so. Pouring men--
and, these days, some women as well-

and munitions into Saudi Arabia has not yet persuaded Saddam to leave Kuwait. Maintaining the current level of economic squeeze upon him would certainly do that, and more with time. Of course, tins of baby food and bottles of Jordanian beer seep into Iraq. Of course, the country can grow more food and hang on for months without appalling starvation. But Iraq cannot, in the end, survive if it can sell none of its oil: and the world, as the present situation makes manifest, can maintain that embargo for years to come.

Probably, foolishly, the manic drumbeating about war has now rendered any return to a sanctions-centred policy politically impossible. But the embargo, rigorously maintained, is too important to be forgotten. If there is now, somehow, to be one last chance for diplomacy, oil sanctions are an integral part of the bargaining. Politicians talk freely in private about a nightmare scenario where a full or partial Iraq withdrawal from Kuwait leaves Saddam Hussein somehow triumphant, his war machine intact, his reputation bizarrely enhanced. They worry that he may steal a few oilwells in the subsequent haggling. But there is no cause for nightmares if the economic noose is kept drawn tight: there is no triumph of any sort for Saddam in a country brought to financial collapse by his own hand. Sanctions have-idiotically-become a codeword for ``appeasement'' in the current context. They are much more than that. They are already a formidable success: and they could have a greater role yet to play.

That statement was made in December. Since then, of course, we have seen the reality and the truth of that strategy put forward by the United States and supported by this country's leadership, to our shame.

We also need to look at the questions of the impact and the effectiveness of this war. On the first day of this war the Pentagon trumpeted its success in having destroyed most of the Iraqi Air Force and its elite Republican Guard. Just today, we hear that only 11 or 12 of Iraq's 700 aircraft are confirmed destroyed, and the Republican Guard is again the target of the massive bombing raids led by the United States Air Force. President Bush has been quoted as saying:
I am somewhat concerned about the initial euphoria in some of the reports and reactions to the first day's developments. This effort will take us some time.

There is always a possibility that the conflict will be cut short by an Iraqi surrender, and we would certainly welcome that. However, that possibility is low and it is our contention that the risk should not have been taken in the first place, especially given the existence of an alternative non-violent strategy based on sanctions and diplomacy, as I have outlined.

Not only has truth yet again been the first casualty of war, but also we are now becoming aware that this war will cause tens of thousands-perhaps hundreds of thousands-of deaths, and even more injuries. There will be massive damage incurred by the civilian infrastructure of Iraq, Kuwait Israel, Saudi Arabia and possibly a number of other nations in the region: damage, destruction and death which, as I have said, could and should have been avoided. There will be enormous damage, and Senator Evans himself has noted the likelihood that Kuwait City will be destroyed once the ground war moves there.

There are political implications flowing from this war. We are already seeing demonstrations taking place, or being banned, in Muslim countries throughout Asia, such as Indonesia, Bangladesh, Pakistan and Malaysia, as well as nations in the Middle East. The resentment arising from this resource war-and, make no mistake about it, that is what this war is-has enormous and ominous implications for the so-called new world order which President Bush and Prime Minister Hawke appear so enamoured of. We are not constructing a new world order by going to war; we are galloping backwards down the path to the past when that was the only option that national leaders could see-the option of attempting to solve international problems at the point of a gun.

Of course, those problems have never been solved at the point of a gun. After the death and the destruction, the people involved in the conflict have had to sit down and talk, and that will be no less the case in this instance. The question must be asked: is all this damage proportionate to Iraq's crime? The answer is no. The death toll and the destruction of infrastructure will far exceed-probably already has exceeded-that already caused. The conflagration throughout the Middle East has only just begun. As I said earlier, we need to look towards a result arising from activity of a diplomatic and peaceful nature which will create the best balance of our concern for peace and justice.

Mention has already been made of the response within our own community in respect of Arabic people and Muslims in this country. It is astonishing to know that as early as at least two months ago a very comprehensive report was put down about the problems-the discrimination and the violence-experienced in the early days amongst our Arabic and Muslim community. The staggering silence of the Government and the Opposition in that instance was quite notable.

It is only in the last couple of weeks that we have heard anything from either the Government or the Opposition in support of the right-it is good to now hear it-of those people in our community to have concerns and to dissent, if they wish, from the decision of a government in a democratic country.

There are others of us, too, who claim the right to dissent, the right to voice that dissent. It is of deep regret that only 4 per cent of the parliamentarians in this place are prepared to oppose the action taken by our Government and by the United States. That 4 per cent clearly represents at least a majority of Australian citizens. Those Australian citizens-probably a considerable majority by this stage-have today been dubbed by the Prime Minister, who has been strongly supported in all of his statements by Dr Hewson in the other place, as mindless. That is an insult, first, to the democratic system and, secondly, to ordinary citizens of this country who have already mounted a wide range of demonstrations and protest actions of a size which took years to achieve at the time of the Vietnam moratorium.

The Government and the Opposition need to think about what they are doing. After an historic decision in the post Cold War context of the United Nations-an historic decision imposing universal and strong sanctions which did work, which are working and which will work-this Government followed the path of a United States administration which clearly never intended to endorse, support and allow the implementation by non-violent means of the resolution of this conflict in the Middle East. Quite clearly, for whatever reasons, this Government decided that this United States Administration would be backed by this country.

That is not good enough for the people of Australia-a people who have been told by this Government that we have an independent foreign policy and that we have a self-reliant defence capacity. All of that has gone right out the window. That has been a fraud perpetrated on the Australian people. The Australian people now understand that and the Government and the Opposition, in its unanimity, will suffer from the backlash of that as time goes on.

The rise in dissent against this Government represents far more than just a feeling about this particular action; it represents disillusionment with the Australian political system-with the old parties, which, to their shame, go as far as binding the consciences of their members who sit in this place. It is an utter disgrace. I have made a call to the Leaders of the old parties to free their members-people of conscience, wherever they sit in this Parliament-so that they can act according to their consciences when this motion, put before both Houses of the Parliament, finally comes to a vote at this special sitting.

We ask people-good people-to stand for election in this nation, in a free democracy. We need good people in this place; we need them to be able to bring what they say to the people out in the community into this place and to follow it right through to the point of the vote in the chamber, which is, after all, what this democratic system is all about. Nothing has more clearly shown the failure of the old political parties to bring genuine people's democracy into this place than this exercise-this futile, dangerous and unnecessary war.

This motion has a very interesting omission. It speaks not at all about further deployments. It certainly is a matter of enormous concern to the Australian Democrats, I am sure that it is a matter of concern to many members of the Australian Labor Party Government and it ought to be of concern to the wider Australian community, particularly in an environment in which the Government knows that there is enormous concern about the potential for escalation of this war, on a day when escalation is occurring, when there is another aircraft carrier on its way, when the British have committed further troops and when we face the possibility of President Bush making yet another telephone call and saying, `It's going to be a long one Prime Minister. I think we're going to need some more support from the Australian nation'.

We will need to take the opportunity-and I do so here-to ask the Government: Why that omission? Why is there no commitment against further deployments? Is this the open door that we need to leave for George Bush in case his fairyland scenario-to quote Senator Gareth Evans-really does not come off; in case the one-day war does not happen; in case it will not be a one-week war. If it is a one-year war there is certainly the potential for further requests of Australian personnel to go in there and fight and die in this futile war.

The other question relates to the fact that it is not only three ships that constitute the Australian involvement and support in this exercise. The United States bases on this soil, about which many of us have had concern for a very long time, about which many of us have protested on the streets and on site for many years, are playing a significant role-probably a more significant role than even the ships. There are questions to be asked of the Government on that score. What is their role? How much does Australia know about what is happening? How much control does Australia have over what is happening?

It is absolutely essential that a comprehensive approach be taken to Middle East security. As I said, after the death and destruction, all the parties will need to sit down and talk. The problems in the Middle East are not just a question of border and resource conflict between Iraq and Kuwait. The conflict is historic and cultural in nature. The problems relate to the whole area. Nobody has mentioned the problem of the Kurdish people. That issue should be on the table in a comprehensive discussion of the issues in the Middle East.

There is also, of course, a whole range of concerns in that area. The Prime Minister's own motion refers to the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel. We agree that that is one of the major issue in the Middle East which needs to be addressed. But we ask the question on the whole range of issues: why not now? Why wait until death and destruction have been wreaked across the Middle East? It is quite clear, with the escalation of shelling of Israel and Saudi Arabia to begin with and the increased deployment of forces by the United States and the United Kingdom, that this conflict will be massively destructive even if we are able to bring it to an end relatively speedily.

But the question is: Why go through that? Why not sit and talk now? Why did we have to get into the entrenched provocative positions of those mindless old male leaders of this world, who can think of nothing but to take us back into the past and reject the peaceful options which are available in the post-Cold War era, when we could have had a new world order.
