—It has to be said at the outset that the Australian Democrats--

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It has to be said that neither the Australian Democrats, nor the lady in the gallery, nor anyone else who opposes this war has any monopoly on the moral perception that war is a hateful business. All of us share that perception.

SPEECH.PARA: But sometimes wars have to be fought because the consequences of not fighting them are worse: postponing the destruction to another time and guaranteeing that it will occur on a greater and even more horrifying scale when it does. World War II was such a war. The only mistake of the civilised world was to wait too long to confront the Nazis with the only response they understood. The Korean War-the only previous example of the United Nations (UN) collective security process at work-was another such example. The war in the Gulf, which is now being fought under UN authority with the participation, the support or acquiescence-not just of the United States and its acolytes, as Senator Powell would have it-of all but three of its 160 members, is now the third such example.

It is not a case of my country right or wrong, or even international majorities right or wrong: some of the wars in which Australia fought this century were avoidable, should never have involved Australians and should never have been fought at all. However, the Gulf is not World War I; the Gulf is not Vietnam. Hateful as it is, destructive as it is-and will continue to be-and more sickening as it may well become in terms of lives lost, the Gulf war is a war which has to be fought and has to be won.

I want to spend my time today justifying that statement and in particular answering two questions which seem to be at the heart of the objections of the Australian Democrats and indeed those of others in the community who are anxious about the course of events that have unfolded. Those questions are these: in the first place, are the things for which we are fighting in the Gulf ones over which the international community and Australia in particular should be prepared to fight at all? Are the issues at stake that important? The second question is: are they things for which we have to fight now? Was peace given a chance? Could sanctions have worked? Could diplomacy have worked? Should we have been more patient?
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer all those questions but not in the way I think the gallery wants me to. Are the issues in the Gulf then ones for which we should be prepared to fight? The answer is unequivocally yes. The issues and the objectives involved have been very clearly defined by the UN Security Council resolutions. Two of those resolutions were explicit, for Iraq to get out of Kuwait and to restore the legitimate government of Kuwait, and one was implicit, to create the basis for achieving future peace and stability in the whole region.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting Iraq out of Kuwait is something for which we should be prepared to fight and the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has made amply clear why. It is important for the people of Kuwait, who have been murdered, tortured, raped, humiliated, brutalised and looted. It is important for other countries in the region, which are confronting a warmongering state which has the ambition to conquer and to assume leadership of the Arab world. It is a state which has the capacity to conquer within the region-a state which has one million men under arms, which has a chemical weapons capacity, which has possible biological weapons capacity and which is well on the way to achieving nuclear capacity. It is a country with a demonstrated instinct for brutality and aggression-by the use of chemical weapons against its own people, by its unprovoked aggression already against Kuwait and, as we have now seen, by its unprovoked aggression against Israel. It is important for the world economy and those dependent on it, not least the Third World countries already devastated by the high oil prices which have been maintained by the tension since this crisis began but also, of course, by an industrial world that could well have been held to ransom had Iraq been allowed to move on to Saudi Arabia and to capture in the process fully 45 per cent of the world's oil reserves.

Getting Iraq out of Kuwait is important, above all else, for the future peace of the world, which depends crucially now, as has been said so often-most recently and most effectively today by the Prime Minister-on the effectiveness of collective security under UN institutions. The irony is that as the discipline of the Cold War fades, there is not only a set of new opportunities for peace but of new dangers of war. It is not just a matter of wanting peace; one has to create the conditions for peace. The founders of the United Nations always knew that peace enforcement was a necessary last resort.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —One does not get peace by chanting for peace; one does not get peace by wishing for peace. One does not get peace just by relying on conciliation; one does not get peace just by relying on UN peacekeeping forces after the event; one does not get peace just by relying on disarmament negotiations before the event and arms control-all of which are the proper responsibility of the United Nations. One only gets peace in the last resort by being prepared to enforce it through exactly the mechanisms that were anticipated by the founders of the United Nations in 1945. And it is important, finally, to get Iraq out of Kuwait to ensure Australia's own future security--

—Getting Iraq out of Kuwait is important not only for all the objectives I have already mentioned; it is important in a very direct way for Australia's own future security. We do have a profound self-interest in comparatively strong countries in our region knowing that aggression in the future is simply not an option that the world will ever allow them.

SPEECH.PARA: The second objective which is being pursued under UN auspices is that of restoring the legitimate government of Kuwait. I think it has to be acknowledged that this has less immediate intuitive appeal for many people than the primary objective of getting Iraq out of Kuwait. Indeed, as a US official said to me at one stage, whatever else we are fighting for in the Gulf, it is not to make the world safe for feudalism. It is not, however, a principle with which one can toy; it is a fundamental principle-and must remain one-of international affairs that no sovereign nation, whatever its democratic or other deficiencies, can legitimately be invaded or annexed by another. The best we can hope for, acknowledging that the situation in Kuwait is in fact for the most part-and has been in the past-more democratic than elsewhere, is that the force of events and internal pressures will create an evolution towards a more democratic and responsive environment in that country. I for one am confident that will occur.

The third United Nations objective, and it is essentially an implicit one, is to create a basis for achieving peace and stability in the whole region in the aftermath of this crisis. It is not an objective of the UN or anybody else involved in this process at the moment to destroy Iraq, but certainly it is an objective to create conditions under which that country will not in the future be able to repeat its actions. Securing and putting into place an appropriate security regime for the region is obviously one of the world's highest priorities in the aftermath of this affair. It is also an objective shared by everyone, whatever the reluctance to accept the principle of linkage before the event, to move on from the Gulf crisis and, strengthened by the principles to emerge we hope from the successful resolution of the Gulf crisis, to address all the longstanding problems of the Middle East, including conspicuously among them that of the Palestinian people.

I would like to spend a little more time following Senator Hill on what that post-war, post-crisis environment might look like, but that will have to wait for another occasion. All I want to say in summary of this part at the moment is that all the objectives that I have described-the objectives which we and, in effect, the whole world now are fighting for in the Gulf-are honourable objectives. They have been understood as such by the international community and that is why the international community has reacted with such unprecedented solidarity to support the process in which we are now engaged. Moreover, by and large they have been objectives which have been understood within the Australian community, as elsewhere, which is why there is, notwithstanding what we are hearing today, clear majority support in the community for the course that we have taken. But still there are questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 28 nations out of 159.
—And are there others supporting Hussein?
—Order! Senator Vallentine and other senators interjecting know what their reaction will have on the people in the gallery. I ask them not to interject on the Minister.

—But still there are questions obviously being asked, which must be answered. Was peace by non-military means really given a chance? Were sanctions given a sufficient chance? Was diplomacy given a sufficient chance? It is to those questions that I now want to turn.

SPEECH.PARA: We all hoped that sanctions would work and do so within a realistic timeframe, but the unhappy truth is that they have not worked and will not work within such a timeframe. The trouble is that for sanctions to work not just one but three things have to happen: in the first place, the net has to be tight, stopping the flow of goods in and out; there is no doubt about that. Secondly, the net has to produce real hurt, and not be compensated for by neutralising internal activity of one kind or another. Thirdly, and in many ways most crucially, a hurt when it occurs has to produce a change of policy by the government in question.

What has, in fact, happened in relation to those three elements? In the first place, it is the case that the net has been drawn tight-unprecedentedly so on the best available estimates, which happen to be those of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), and which I noticed Senator Powell had pleasure in quoting-to the extent of some 90 to 95 per cent of all goods moving in and out of Iraq. That is what I and others meant when I said some three months ago that the evidence seemed to be that sanctions in that respect were working.

I refer now to the second point-the hurt. Has the hurt been as great as we hoped and as we expected? The answer is that that has not been the case. Militarily there has been no hurt at all, but that I guess is to be expected in a country of this kind where all resources are given priority so far as the military is concerned. There has not been great pressure on food because of compensating internal supply increases, not to mention some looted and supplied from Kuwait. In any event, food is a legitimate humanitarian exemption under the UN regime. There is some inflation of a significant kind in non-staple, non-subsidised areas, but that has not proved crippling and will not, on everyone's estimates, for the infinitely foreseeable future.

So far as industry and infrastructure in Iraq are concerned, there has been significant hurt but not yet massive hurt where it matters. There has been a massive windback in oil and fuel production as Senator Powell-again relying as I did on the CIA-acknowledges, but the impact of that has been financial only, and that financial impact is not enough to produce the kinds of results that we are talking about.

There has been some hurt of a very visible and obvious kind on non-essential manufacturing. That has largely stopped, but that has not in any way significantly impacted on the economy or the welfare of Iraq as a whole. Regarding essential manufacturing-heavy industry and so on-the percentage impact so far, despite early expectations to the contrary, has been small, with many of those factories managing largely by ad hoc arrangements, by cannibalisation, again not least assisted by the looting that has been done from Kuwait. So far as transport, water supply and energy considerations are concerned, again despite some expectations and hopes to the contrary, the impact has been marginal. There are no clues as to when the impact will be anything more than that.

As to the third element in the equation-when does hurt, when it does occur, get translated into policy change?-we have to appreciate that there is a real weakness in dealing in this respect with a dictatorship as compared with a democracy; a dictatorship in particular whose raison d'etre is warmongering. Sanctions are always important for the psychological effect they have at least as much as for their real effect, but dictatorial societies, regrettably, operate on a different psychological basis from our own. Governments decide by reference to different criteria, and community fear makes the pressure from that source rather less obtrusive than might otherwise be the case.

How long do we have to wait for sanctions to satisfy not just one but all three of those preconditions? It is probably the case that sanctions would work in the long run, but how long can we afford that long run to be? How many more Kuwaitis are to be killed, maimed, raped, robbed, brutalised and looted before we say that enough is enough? How many developing countries are going to suffer economically for how much longer with oil prices driven up as they have been by the tension that was generated before these attacks took place? How much more time is Iraq to be given, not just to dig in to Kuwait, not just to consolidate its hold on Kuwait, but to fully develop and further develop its chemical weapons capacity and to find ways of fixing those chemical warheads, if it does not possess that technology already, onto its missile systems? How much longer are we to wait while it further develops its biological weapons capacity?
Senator Powell interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Powell, you have made your speech.

—How much further time is Iraq to be given to work through to develop its nuclear option, which may be as little as a year away from realisation? A reasonable additional question, although it is not a comfortable one, is: how long can we wait before the international coalition begins, for whatever reason, to crumble a little around the edges? There is always a risk of aggression becoming a fait accompli if wrongs are not righted quickly. It is an often remarked fact of international life in international affairs that longevity promotes legitimacy. Saddam is relying on time being on his side. Time was on his side in this respect; it certainly was not on the world's side. The UN made its decision on 28 November, resolution 678, that sanctions were not likely to work within a reasonable timeframe. Essentially we had the debate then about the likely efficacy of sanctions and nothing has changed subsequently.

SPEECH.PARA: What about diplomacy? Was that given a sufficient chance before 15 January? Honourable senators will not be surprised to hear that I believe it was. I say that not just as a matter of intuition, not just as a matter of assertion, but on the basis of the very systematic exploration of that issue in which I was able to engage by virtue of being overseas for the last 10 days engaged in intensive discussions in Washington, New York at the United Nations, Ottowa and in three European capitals-London, Paris and Madrid.

I will not retail the whole course of those discussions which paralleled exactly the last minute diplomatic efforts that were being made in a number of quarters to try to bring this matter to a resolution without the necessity to implement the use of force. I can make the point by referring to just two sets of discussions that I had. One was with the United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar on the afternoon of 15 January, just half an hour before he delivered his final statement, his final appeal to Iraq-an appeal that held out a variety of olive branches. In his conversation with me, he made the following points: no-one could have done any more to achieve peace than had been done by him and all the others who had been promoting in one way or another this or that peace plan; there was no sign at any time that Saddam was prepared to withdraw under any condition put to him, least of all those that Perez de Cuellar was about to put once again to Hussein via the public media; Iraq simply did not seem to want peace.

Let me refer to another set of discussions I had in France. They coincided with and followed the last-minute initiative that France engaged in in the Security Council on 14 and 15 January-an initiative that generated a huge amount of international interest but one that was rejected in the Security Council by the United States and by the United Kingdom because, among other things, it was seen as going just too far in offering unacceptable linkage between Iraq's withdrawal and addressing other outstanding Middle East questions.

My question to the French-it was put to the Prime Minister, to people in the Foreign Ministry and to a whole range of interlocutors over two days of conversations-was: would it have made any difference if the French resolution, more explicit in its offerings than any other in terms of the last-minute diplomatic olive branch, had been adopted by the Security Council? I can tell the Senate that the answer I got, in absolute honesty and with absolute frankness from all my interlocutors, was no. There was simply no sign that Saddam was likely to be responsive to such an initiative. There had been ample previous opportunity in a less public and a less conspicuous way for him to give such a sign. The auguries were hopeless. In the aftermath of that exercise in the Security Council there was no bitterness on the part of the French: they believed they had made one last gesture in that respect but in practice it would not have made any difference.

There is a further consideration we need to bear in mind when we think about the diplomatic efforts that were made, not just those up to the eleventh hour, up to the stroke of midnight on 15 January, but in the short period that was left open after that. There is quite a widespread sense around the place-certainly in the conversations that I had-that maybe Saddam was never going to make a concession in accordance with the timetable imposed upon him by the United Nations. Maybe he was never going to make an eleventh hour concession, but maybe he would be prepared to make a thirteenth hour concession. He was given a thirteenth hour and a fourteenth and a fifteenth and almost another 24 hours to make such a concession by the fact that the United States, the coalition operating under the UN authority, did not launch an attack until nearly a full 24 hours had elapsed after the initial deadline. There was that opportunity given, had that been the reason why it was impossible for Saddam to accept the kind of offer that had been put to him to withdraw before the deadline that was set.

We all want peace, but we do not want peace on the terms of someone like Saddam Hussein. We want a credible basis for pursuing peace-not just waiting for something to turn up and not just appeasing and hoping each time that a little bit more will be enough. There comes a time when patient diplomacy simply runs its course. The world was too patient when Japan invaded Manchuria in 1931. It was too patient when Italy attacked Abyssinia-now known as Ethiopia-in 1936. The world was too patient again when Hitler invaded the Rhineland in 1936, and it was too patient when he invaded Austria in March 1938 and too patient again, finally, when he invaded Czechoslovakia in September 1938.

The truth of the matter is that sanctions had run their course and diplomacy had run its course by 15 January. The choice the world faced, and the choice that Australia faced, was whether to follow the logic of our own intellectual and moral commitment to collective security or to turn our backs and let a monstrous precedent take its course.

Let me conclude by saying this-it comes back to what I said at the outset: it is a real irony, it seems to me, of the political process that, when it comes to war and peace, every generation tends to remember the lessons of only the most immediate political past. Governments which appeased Hitler in the 1930s did so because they remembered the failure of diplomacy to prevent a wholly avoidable and a wholly unnecessary war in 1914. I think it is fair to say that governments which took us into the wrong war in Vietnam did so because they remembered the failure of the appeasers and they were determined to stop what they perceived to be the onward march of communist aggression, failing, of course, to appreciate that they were confronting a quite different phenomenon-that of anti-colonial nationalism. Those who now, with their minds full of the Vietnam failure, think that governments are leading us into the wrong war in the Gulf have also misremembered and misapplied the past.

What we are dealing with in the Gulf is not a Vietnam situation and not a pre-World War I situation, but a 1930s situation of naked indefensible aggression by a strong, ruthless and ambitious sovereign country over a weaker neighbour-a situation that other governments in the 1930s and the collective security apparatus at the time utterly failed to address, with consequences that proved horrendous.

The new collective security that was put in place in 1945 to enable these situations to be addressed was, as it turned out, reduced to impotence for 45 years by a new set of international dynamics-the Cold War-that made it in practice impossible to mobilise across-the-board support for action against any indefensible aggression that did occur.

The position now, and it cannot be said too often, is that with the end of the Cold War that UN apparatus-that optimistic apparatus, that far-reaching, forward looking apparatus-put in place in 1945 arising out of the ashes of the diplomatic and military failures of the past is capable now of working again. The situation in the Gulf-it is on a smaller scale than Germany in the 1930s but the parallels are immense and obvious-is exactly the kind of situation that that collective security apparatus of the United Nations was designed to cope with. The world has a responsibility, remembering not just selectively but remembering all the lessons of the past, to make sure that this time it works.

All the preconditions for measured, responsible, effective and moral international action have been satisfied. Nobody wanted to plunge into war on or after 15 January. But if aggression was not to be turned back by sanctions, and it had lost the capacity to be so, and if aggression was not to be turned back by diplomacy-and I believe that diplomacy for all the reasons I have stated, had run its course-then that aggression had to be met by the only language it could understand if the world of the future, the world which is our responsibility to try to create, is ever to be peaceful and secure.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate has a very distasteful but certainly a very predictable and solemn responsibility. We are addressing a motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government, Senator Button. I do not propose to read it in full, but the main features are--

—The Senate is asked to affirm support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in its resolution 678 and for supporting the implementation of that resolution. That resolution authorises member states cooperating with the Government of Kuwait, unless Iraq on or before 15 January 1991 fully implements a whole series of United Nations resolutions, which are set out, to use all necessary means to uphold and implement Security Council resolutions and all subsequent relevant resolutions to restore international peace and security in the area and requests all states to provide appropriate support for the actions undertaken in pursuance of that resolution. The motion before us also expresses the full confidence of the Senate in and support for the Australian forces serving with the multinational forces in the Gulf which are there not only with the sanction but also at the request of the United Nations.

SPEECH.PARA: In exercising that great responsibility we have today in deciding whether we are to support the motion that has been proposed by the Government, I want to dwell at some length on the situation with which we are faced. I think anyone who soberly considers the problem confronting the whole world-not just Australia-as the situation has unfolded since 2 August last, despite the hatefulness of war, would have no--
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the attendants to remove from the gallery those people who have thrown papers.

—The Senate should have no difficulty, Mr Deputy President, in supporting the motion that is before us. I want now to turn to the events as they have unfolded since 2 August last year, nearly six months ago. On that fateful day-fateful for the world-the Iraqi forces, under the control of the dictator Saddam Hussein, invaded and, in a short space of time, commenced their brutal occupation of Kuwait. They did so without any justification, without any provocation. It is the most clear-cut case of naked aggression which has occurred in the world since the end of the Second World War. It is not just another dispute; it is not just another of the many instances of aggression and invasion which have occurred over that period; it was and continues to be a uniquely gross violation of the principles which have been established in the United Nations charters and adopted by the world community since 1945.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation which has developed in Iraq under Saddam Hussein, in defiance of all the attempts made at the diplomatic level-as Senator Evans has very clearly pointed out in his speech-has developed in defiance of the sanctions to which the Australian Democrats attach so much significance. Those sanctions have failed, apparently, to make any impact whatsoever on the decisions taken by Saddam Hussein and the Iraqi dictatorship on that day, which they have maintained ever since and continue to maintain, despite the inevitable consequences which occurred last Thursday, 17 January, in the form of the action taken by the multinational force, clearly in pursuance of that resolution of the United Nations which I have read.

People who believe that something more could be done, that further diplomacy would be possible, that sanctions may work, must be completely deluding themselves about the nature of the situation with which the world is faced. We have had this demonstrated by the nature of the invasion, by the conduct of Iraqi troops and the Iraqi Government in Kuwait over that period, but what have we seen from Saddam Hussein himself since the multinational force commenced to give effect to the resolution of the United Nations?

One of the most obvious steps that Saddam Hussein took following the action against him was not to respond to that but in fact to attack Isreal. He has directed his missile force, such as it is, not so much until today at those forces which are arraigned against him, but at a separate nation, Israel, which was and clearly still is endeavouring to avoid involvement in this conflict. This is the action of a man whom the Australian Democrats, whom Senator Powell and no doubt Senator Vallentine, say we should still be dealing with. Not only has he taken that further nakedly aggressive step against Israel, as he had done against Kuwait in August, but also this person the world is faced with is a man who has been constantly calling for a holy war by the whole Islamic world against Israel and those forces standing firm against his aggression.

Here is a man who not only has defied the whole world community and the United Nations but also is seeking greatly to enlarge the war which he has brought upon himself as a result of his actions on 2 August. There is a unique problem here facing the world community. Hateful as a decision to go to war is, there is clearly a time when it is justified. If ever there was such a time, this is surely it. It is essentially for that reason that the Opposition will be supporting this motion.

As Senator Hill has pointed out, the motion has been drafted by the Government and presented to the Senate with very little opportunity for consultation with the Opposition. The Opposition has some difficulty with certain aspects of it. Some of those have been pointed out by Senator Hill. We believe that the motion should have emphasised more clearly the nature of the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq.

An expression of confident support for our forces who are operating with the multinational force in the Gulf has been amended by the Government to recognise that it is not a United Nations force but a force which has been sanctioned by the United Nations Security Council. In other words, it is not actually being commanded and directed by the United Nations; it is a multinational force. Twenty-eight nations have joined together to give effect to the decisions of the United Nations and the call that has been made by the Security Council.

We in the Opposition would certainly want to emphasise the leading role that the United States has played in putting together that coalition of multinational force over these months. It has been a notable piece of diplomacy and leadership by the United States. But, of course, we must give credit to all those nations who have responded-as the Australian Government has responded, with the support of the Opposition-ever since these events commenced in August.

Also, the Opposition wants to make it quite clear that although we will support the fifth limb of the motion as being a factual statement-one which I think has been recognised as the course that events will take-we do not want to suggest for one minute that there should be any linkage between a peace conference in the Middle East and the decisions that are being taken to remove Iraq from Kuwait. The invasion of Kuwait stands alone in all its naked infamy. The efforts of the United Nations and of all the nations in the multinational force are directed without any conditions whatever to the restoration of the status quo, as far as possible, and the removal of Iraq from Kuwait.

What may follow after that is a separate question altogether. We recognise that this will occur in due course, but it is not to be linked with the actual decisions and the course of action on which the multinational forces, and all the nations who are participating, have embarked. We have taken this view in light of all these events, in light of all the failures of the sanctions and the failures of the diplomacy, and in light of the enormity of the crimes that are being committed by Saddam and his henchmen in the leadership of Iraq. We do not quarrel with the Iraqi people but with the situation into which they have been led by Saddam Hussein.

This is a unique situation which has arisen in the world and there is a unique opportunity for the world to do something about it. As I said in this chamber in December when we last debated this subject, this is really the first opportunity that has arisen for the United Nations to take the step which it has taken. It has been able to do so because of the end of the Cold War. It has been able to do so because of the Soviet Union's neutrality and the support which it has given-although it is not giving physical support as part of the multinational force. This has been the first opportunity in 45 years for the United Nations to operate as was intended by its founders in 1945.

This is a unique situation for a number of reasons. It is an extraordinary failure on the part of the Democrats that they are not prepared to join with the Opposition and support the Government in the circumstances that I have outlined. I have just been looking at a very interesting summary of what I have been trying to say-and perhaps it is better expressed. An article published yesterday in a Western Australian newspaper says:
The Iraqi killers have already been responsible for more than a million deaths, inflicting hideous pain through chemicals and by terrible acts of torture on their own people.
Now they imperil the economic and political stability of the entire world.

They jeopardise the hopes and happiness of hundreds of millions of people in newly emerging eastern European economies who have not known financial security for 50 years. If the 28-nation task force in the Gulf succeeds, it will certainly begin a new era in world politics where it can be proven that the United Nations can provide peace and safety for small nations.

The author of this article is one Don Chipp, the founder of the Democrats and the former distinguished leader of the Democrats in this chamber. Former Senator Chipp is expressing-as I am not surprised, knowing him-the very views which I have tried to express in this debate and which the Opposition has certainly been expressing very firmly and clearly for nearly six months.

I believe that what former Senator Chipp has said is an utter repudiation of what the Democrat Leader, his rather undistinguished successor, has said today. Senator Powell, under the influence no doubt of Senator Coulter and other Democrats, has taken a stance today-it is the stance that the Democrats have taken throughout-which totally repudiates the views of her former leader and founder, Senator Chipp.

I regret that the whole of the opposition to the stance taken by the Government, with the support of the Opposition, throughout this unhappy period since 2 August has been motivated not by an appreciation of the factors which we have been emphasising in this debate, which the Government has been emphasising and which Senator Evans emphasised so clearly in his speech, but by a reaction based at best purely on a pacifist view of the world.

I have respect for the views of those people who are genuinely pacifists, although I totally disagree with them. But that is the best one can say for the case that has been put against the actions that have been taken. The protesters that we see today-the sorts of people who have been calling for peace for the last 30 or 40 years-claim to support the United Nations. They argue: `We have the United Nations; there ought not be this Cold War between superpowers; and the whole of the world's problems must be solved by the United Nations'. We have the situation in which the United Nations from the very beginning of this problem has acted in remarkable concert with the authorisation, imposition and enforcement of sanctions. Australia decided to support the United Nations final resolution, which I have read out, and we have committed our forces to support it.

For those who have had a genuine interest in preserving peace in the world, through the medium of the United Nations we can have no better example of how that can be achieved. I would have thought that for those people, in particular, there would have been the clearest support for what has been done. If that view about preserving peace is that of the Democrats, I cannot understand why they are opposing these steps.

Today Senator Powell talked about giving sanctions a greater opportunity to work. I do not want to add anything to what Senator Evans has said in response to that, but let me remind the Senate that when we had a debate in this chamber on about 20 August, following the United Nations' decision not only to impose the sanctions but also to authorise actions to be taken so as to give effect to and thereby implement those sanctions, the Government, again with the support of the Opposition, of course, approved the sending of a naval task force to implement those sanctions and to give some meaning to the enforcement of those sanctions. That was the one very limb of the resolution which the Democrats opposed. The Democrats supported the principle of sanctions but were not prepared to support the enforcement of them in that way. So, at all stages in this debate, I regret to say, the Democrats have sought to make some excuse as to why Australia should do nothing and, presumably, why the world should do nothing to meet this naked aggression with which it has been faced.

In conclusion I will say a few words about the role of the Australian defence forces in this current war which is now well under way. We have already debated that role on a previous occasion and I do not want to add anything further to it. But I would emphasise the fact that the 800 or so young Australians who are serving in the Gulf region in this war are bearing the real responsibility for the actions that we are taking in this place and the decisions which have been made previously and which are going to be made in this chamber today or tomorrow. They have already shown the prowess and dedication to duty which we would expect of them and which is in the finest traditions of the Australian Defence Force. It is not just those who are there now but those who were in the first ships which went there and those who have returned to Australia and who may well have to return again and maybe again.

This is an ongoing and what may be quite a long process. So there will be not only the 800 or so who are there now but also others who will almost certainly take their place in due course. There are others who have done their duty and have returned. Even if they do not return to the Gulf, they have also done their duty. All those young men, and now some women, deserve our great gratitude, but they also deserve our support. It is also most important that they should know that, overwhelmingly, not only the Government and the Opposition, not only the Parliament of this country, are behind them, although I am sure that is important, but they should know that the overwhelming majority of Australians are supporting what they are doing and are concerned about them and their welfare and that of their families.

Those members of our defence forces who have been engaged already have conducted themselves in a splendid manner, and I think we should be proud of them and we should be giving them our full support. I hope that there will not be the sort of conduct that we had here this afternoon from a very small and noisy minority in this community. I hope that that will not be the impression they have of their fellow countrymen. I am sure it is quite wrong and I hope that they will not be misled by that sort of demonstration, because even if there were a genuine feeling of opposition to Australia's involvement, by those who may not agree with that for some reason, I believe that all Australians should be standing behind those members of our Defence Force, giving them moral support and encouragement as well as, of course, the physical support which is to be given and is the responsibility of Government; the moral support of the whole of the Australian community should be with them in the great challenge that they have ahead of them in this war.

I have not had time this afternoon to deal with some questions which I would like to raise with the Government about the future of the Australian Defence Force both in this particular situation and for the future generally. Senator Hill has attempted to go into some of the major problems. There are some major problems for the world in what is, perhaps, a new world order, as it is being referred to. These are grave, weighty and vitally important questions which this Parliament should be debating and will have to debate even though the Government wants to cut off this session tomorrow. But it is something we will have to come back to time and time again. There are some vital new problems and new questions that arise regarding Australia's defence, our role in the world and our role as an effective member of the United Nations, because that is, in the end, why we are taking part. We are taking part because we believe in the international community under the United Nations and the new role that that will have, we hope, for the future.

We are required to play our part as a member of that international community. We are playing it for that reason and also for the reasons of our own defence. If we, ourselves, were confronted with this sort of threat we would expect the international community to give us assistance. So these are new and weighty questions which we have to ponder in the future. At this stage, let us give full support to those members of our Defence Force who are carrying out the responsibilities which we have given to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that it would give any government any pleasure to be involved in a conflict situation, and this Government has given serious consideration to the factors that would compel us to commit armed forces to the region. I would also say that, having visited and having had contact with members of the Australian Defence Force so constantly over recent days, they take no joy out of it at all. Having been trained all their lives to fight, their reaction was extremely sombre. Let me assure anyone in this Australian community that there are no Rambos and no-one in the defence forces is taking pleasure out of the current situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that I would like to say is that this war did not start four days ago. This war started on 2 August; it was only the response that started four days ago. I know that my colleague Senator Tate will spend some time examining the circumstances surrounding 2 August, but just to recap: here we had a situation where Kuwait was threatened, negotiations occurred in the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries and assurances were given to people such as President Mubarak, all of which were just a disguise for what eventually was naked aggression against a sovereign country. When Iraq invaded Kuwait, I wonder where the demonstrators were that day-outside the Iraq Embassy? No, they were not. Not a peep; not a whimper; no response whatsoever.

The initial reaction of the international community, I thought, was a most sensible one in which a two-pronged attack was made-firstly, sanctions and, secondly, on the diplomatic front. Both those have been adequately dealt with by my colleague Senator Evans. But I remind the Senate that 28 nations are involved in this exercise and many others are giving support where they cannot make a military contribution. Some people would assert that this is just the crusty conservative Western world intervening in its old imperialistic ways. I do not think that is true of anyone who has intervened, but it is not this Government by itself that has made these decisions. It is a social democratic government. Neil Kinnock, the Leader of the British Labour Party, has been in fulsome support of British intervention. Mitterrand and Rocard from France and probably the greatest Italian socialist leader since the Second World War-Craxi-have similarly expressed views. The President of Czechoslovakia, a man who spent many years in prison, has come out in full support. So these decisions are not just `American lap-dog responses'. These responses are made from the widest section of political ideology, from conservatives right through to radicals. They have come to the conclusion and to the world view that aggression in this region must be resisted.

When we look at the nations which in the last four days have come out in strong opposition, we see that the first to do so was Cuba-the paragon of democracy in the Caribbean which has exported terrorism and revolution throughout Central and South America. What a great example to have to align oneself with. The second country was North Korea-one of the worst autocracies and military dictatorships in the world which is hell-bent on a nuclear weapons program. The third was Yemen-hardly the most progressive country, even by Middle East standards. Those are the three countries that have been so bitterly critical of the decision.

Australia's intervention in these matters is based very firmly on our supporting the United Nations. I cannot stress that too much. Someone said to me this morning, `How would Evatt have felt if he had been involved in this debate today?'. He is someone who spent many years of his life, with the support of others, trying to get a constructive United Nations and a new world order in which countries could live at peace with each other. I certainly know on which side of the debate he would have spoken if he had had the opportunity.

Our commitment in this region is commensurate with our size and the role that we see ourselves playing in the world. It is not a large one; we are not a world power. However, our contribution has been crafted to where deficiencies exist. When the Chief of the Defence Force, General Gration, was touring the Middle East in November, in advance of my visit, it was made very clear to him by the coalition forces that the shortage areas were escort ships and medical teams. That is precisely where we have made our contribution. Currently we have two escort ships and a supply ship in the Gulf. That contribution will continue. When Success has finished its rotation of duty it will be replaced by Westralia. We have four medical teams of 10 also because there was a major shortage in that area. On top of that, we obviously have a logistical support team. Finally, 20 of our serving personnel are on exchange rotation in the Gulf doing a diverse number of jobs.

I thank Senator Durack for his tribute to those serving Australians. I do not think anyone in this chamber would criticise those who are merely doing their duty. They do it not with enthusiasm, other than enthusiasm to do a job; they do not do it out of a sense of militarism-they are as scared as anyone else when the occasion arises-but nevertheless they will do their job with resoluteness, efficiency and a sense of duty to their country. We on the Government side salute them and thank them for their contribution.

It is not true to say that the whole of Australia supports this commitment. I cannot put a figure on it. In political terms, the two major parties support it. The Australian Democrats have made it quite clear here today that they do not. I was intrigued by Senator Powell's assertion that sanctions should have been given a chance to work. I was sitting in this chamber on, I think, 23 August when Senator Powell made her big Middle East speech opposing this Government's decision to enforce sanctions. Using a geographical pun, when did the road to Damascus conversion occur?

TALK.START.PARA: —Get it right; read the speech.
— I have the speech right here. In her speech about the commitment of Australian ships to enforce the sanctions, Senator Powell said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we cannot agree that this sort of action should have been taken.

The real problem with the Democrats' position is that, as it is not quite a pacifist position, the Democrats have enormous difficulty in defining what sort of world order they seek. Too often I get the impression that the Democrats think that, by being nice and talking incessantly, a result will come out. They are entitled to that view, but it is not a view that historically can be substantiated. I am quite sure that if we got in a time machine today and this was 1934 to 1940 they would be saying, `Well, the Italians have gone into Abyssinia; let's talk to them; they'll be talked out of it. Let's talk the Japanese out of Manchuria. Let's talk the Germans out of Sudetenland, Austria and Czechoslovakia'. Too many people did that. Too many people in my Party marched just for peace, putting off the inevitable day until the conflict would become bigger rather than smaller. That is the difficulty we have with the Democrats' position.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have supported the sanctions since they were imposed.

— Senator Powell raises the question of sanctions. I thought that Senator Evans gave a fairly good response. From my perspective, I supported sanctions. What I did not anticipate was that in that time Kuwait would be dissembled and abused in the way it was. If sanctions took another 12 months to work, what would happen to the Kuwaitis? What would happen to them as their economic assets were stripped away, as everything that could be moved was shipped back to Iraq, and as anyone who voiced the slightest bit of dissent was shot? The Kuwaitis did not have the privilege of coming in here today and debating these issues. The first person to open his or her mouth with dissent would have been shot.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell should read the Amnesty International reports on Kuwait and say that we, as responsible nations, should stand and watch that continue-hoping that sanctions would work in six, eight or 10 months, knowing what the climatic conditions are in the Middle East and that Saddam Hussein could have delayed things until those conditions made conflict impossible for several more months, and knowing that people's observance of the various religious festivals in the Middle East would make it very hard in four months time. Saddam knew that. Why can the Democrats not understand that he was just playing for time until the forces would eventually have to be withdrawn? Sanctions would mean nothing then and Saddam Hussein would have been in control of the Kuwaiti oilfields and the resources of Kuwait, and potentially in control of the critical parts of Saudi Arabia. Imagine what sort of war machine he would have built. This all comes back to the question: why does a country of 17 million need a standing army of nearly a million, counting reserves? Why does it need 4,000 tanks and 700 war planes, and why does it need to develop a chemical, biological and nuclear capacity? Why has it developed that and why has it never once hesitated to use any weapon at its disposal?

The most sickening and obscene thing that I have seen in this episode of events-it was not the result of Democrats' action-was a demonstration on Saturday against the American Embassy. Fair enough, but why stop and demonstrate against the Israeli Consulate in Sydney on the way through? People going about their daily lives have had missiles rain down on them for no reason whatsoever. The real problem, I guess, in trying to confront opposition to this is that it is so disparate. There are the pacifists on this side, whom I respect-as Senator Durack does-and there is the other person with a misconceived world view, whom I can understand.

But also running through it, not necessarily in this chamber, is the old pathetic anti-Americanism. No matter what the Americans do, ipso facto it is wrong. As soon as America takes some action, down to the consulate, burn the flag. In the meantime Saddam can march through wherever he likes. It is as though there is a vacuum, as though he does not exist. That is the problem; we are trying to confront some of this opposition.

There is nothing more obscene or stupid than the argument that it is blood for oil. There is a whole range of strategic imperatives involved here, a whole range of international principles that go much beyond simply the protection of oil reserves. A variety of things has been said by the Democrats here today including the plea about the old parties' argument, but we are used to that. It is more electorally based than anything else. Senator Durack has already covered what I was going to say regarding Senator Chipp's views.

I wish to say only one other thing as I do not believe I need to detain the Senate as I have said a fair bit elsewhere. I think that the worst opposition to the war comes from the Queensland antibases coalition. Essentially that coalition accuses me of allowing the Australian-American facilities at Nurrungar to be used to give early warning time to citizens of Israel that missiles are coming. If I am guilty of that, Mr President, that is my proudest moment in politics.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Parliament of Australia has been recalled to seek support for a motion put before both Houses, and to support the Government's decision to be part of a 28-member coalition to enforce United Nations resolution 678 carried on 29 November.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the National Party of Australia I support the motion. Resolution 678 reaffirmed 11 other resolutions calling on the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from the sovereign country of Kuwait which Iraq unlawfully occupied on 2 August, and to determine to secure full compliance with its decision. The decision authorised member states, unless Iraq withdrew from Kuwait by 15 January, to use all necessary means to uphold and implement resolution 660, and all subsequent resolutions, and request all states to provide appropriate support for the actions undertaken. The National Party fully supports any actions the Government would need to take to enforce the final United Nations resolution, resolution 678.

Although Australian farmers will be affected by the conflict that is taking place in the Middle East at present through the loss of markets for primary products, and the fact that the $600m wheat bill will not be met by the Iraqis, I can say to this Parliament quite clearly that I do not believe there is one farmer in Australia who would not support the Government's actions which were taken in sending forces to the Middle East to enforce the removal from Kuwait of Saddam Hussein. Primary producers know that unless problems are tackled at the source they invariably lead to much greater problems in the end.

On 2 August 1990 the world was shocked and horrified when it learned that Iraqi forces had attacked and invaded the much smaller country of Kuwait. In hindsight we should not have been surprised by any actions taken by Saddam Hussein, a man who has committed the most dreadful atrocities against his own people, using chemical weapons against the Kurdish minority; a man who has risen to power by eliminating and exterminating all opposition in Iraq and being involved in a war that used the most hideous weaponry-poison gas-against his Arab neighbours; a man who has ruled by terror and fear, eliminating any voice raised in opposition or even offering an alternative point of view. That is the type of person the world is dealing with, and anyone here who believes this person will negotiate or be willing to listen to reason is being totally unrealistic himself.

The world has tried reasoning. The United Nations has tried to negotiate since the occupation of Kuwait on 2 August. The United Nations has carried 12 resolutions, all calling on Saddam Hussein to evacuate Kuwait. Sanctions have been tried but have not worked. On 29 November resolution 678 was carried almost unanimously by the Security Council giving Iraq until 15 January to hand back Kuwait. Despite the pause of seven weeks, and all-out diplomatic efforts by all nations which had any influence with Iraq-the French, the Arab summits, its ally Jordan and many others-all overtures were rejected by Iraqi Government spokesmen.

On 9 January 1991 the Secretary of State of the United States of America, James Baker, after many attempts to arrange an acceptable date, finally got the Iraqi Foreign Minister to a meeting in Geneva. The meeting lasted 6 1/2 hours. After 6 1/2 hours discussion the only result was that the Iraqi Foreign Minister refused to accept a letter from the President of the United States of America to take back to his leader because the tone of the letter was impolite.

On 13 January, in a last ditch attempt to avert war, the Secretary-General of the United Nations met with Saddam Hussein. He was kept waiting for a number of hours, cooling his heels in the foyer, and was then rebuffed, confirming once again-if any confirmation was needed-that Iraq is not interested in peace. The only statements that ever came from any of those meetings were bellicose, indicating that there was no intention of a withdrawal by Iraq from Kuwait.

Mr President, there can be no other conclusion than that the President of Iraq wants war with the full knowledge that his forces will be ultimately defeated, and then salvage political status out of a military defeat as happened with President Nasser in 1967.

Saddam Hussein's intentions would not stop at Kuwait. He has already attacked Iran. If the world stood idly by and took no direct action against Iraq, and by its indifference condoned the invasion of Kuwait, Saddam's appetite for conquest would be fuelled again and again. His next target would be Saudi Arabia, and then the United Arab Emirates. With the invasion of Kuwait Saddam Hussein controls 19 per cent of the world's oil today. With Saudi Arabia it would be 44 per cent, and with the Emirates it would be getting close to 50 per cent of the world's oil reserves.

I am not ashamed to stand up in this Parliament on behalf of the people who elected me and say that the world cannot accept a position where a person with Hussein's track record of aggression to his neighbours, a record of terror and fear to his own people, and a record of total arrogance to the rest of the world can be allowed, by his aggression, to take control of up to 50 per cent of the world's oil supplies. That would ultimately be used to blackmail the rest of the world and to fund his war machine to achieve more and more conquests, which would lead inevitably to a much larger conflict.

There can never be compromise with people like Saddam Hussein. Any form of compromise would be interpreted as weakness on the part of the world and would strengthen Saddam. To those people-and I include the Australian Democrats-with the view that the sanctions were not given sufficient time to work, I say to them that whilst the sanctions may have been weakening the economy, in no way were they ever weakening Hussein's resolve to conduct war. To give sanctions further time to work would have given Hussein further time to prepare for war, a war that he is determined to have, and further time to put pressure on the coalition he has so far unsuccessfully tried to wreck by linking the invasion of Kuwait with the occupancy of the West Bank, a completely unrelated matter.

Negotiations, sanctions and compromise will have the same effect on Hussein as they had on Hitler-they will be completely ineffective. Peace in our time at any price was unsuccessful in 1939, and it will be just as unsuccessful in 1991.

The world has supported through the United Nations resolutions Kuwait's right of independence. If that is not achieved, then no country will ever be able to live in peace. All smaller countries will live in fear of larger and more powerful nations. That is the principle I put to the demonstrators who are here today, who have a mental capacity of no more than an hour, and who are having peace marches throughout Australia: if we want peace we will get it only through strength, not weakness. That is why there was resolve between the two massive powers, the United States of America and Russia-they both showed strength. In the end it became a stalemate, but it became peace by strength, not peace by weakness.

There is not one person in Australia who wants war. Everyone in Australia wants peace. Christians are praying for peace. The actions of the demonstrators are wrong. I accept that they have a right to demonstrate-that is their prerogative. They would not have the same rights and freedom in Iraq. I will stand here today and disagree with them, but I will defend their right to demonstrate. But they are causing concern amongst our defence forces, who are already worried; they are causing hurt to the families of the people who are serving in the Gulf; and they are building up a division and resentment in Australia.

They must ask themselves whether they can trust a man who has developed chemical and biological warfare to an art form, a man who has a nuclear capacity and is continually trying to upgrade and develop that capacity. Do people such as the Democrats honestly believe that Hussein is interested in peace? Unless they are prepared to address the issues, the Prime Minister is correct in accusing the peace demonstrators-and I include the Democrats-of uttering mindless slogans and falling into the trap of appeasement.

Last week I was in Washington. I was able to see at first hand the concerns of the people of America. When I come back here and see people mindlessly, as Senator Robert Ray has quite correctly said, marching and demonstrating in front of the American Embassy I want to put forward some of the fears and concerns that those people have over there. They were asking: `Why do we have to have this action of going to war when we are the strongest nation in the world? The Gulf is offering no threat to us. Why do we have to protect the world's oil supplies when America uses only 8 or 9 per cent of the Gulf oil? When other countries such as Japan and Germany are drawing their oil resources from the Gulf, why are they not pulling their weight?'.

Despite all these questions and concerns, both the Congress and the Senate voted to support the President's action of a total commitment. Where ours is a contribution, theirs is a total commitment and they are the ones who are putting everything on the line. The commitment has been endorsed by 83 per cent of the people. Those people want peace as much as anyone in Australia wants peace. They have been through the years of the Vietnam war. They paid the toll, but they know that peace will be a reality only if dictators like Hussein are stopped in their tracks.

Today it was my firm hope-I suppose an expectation rather than reality-that this motion would be carried unanimously by every member of this Parliament. But I acknowledge that people have a right to disagree. They do not have the same right in Iraq, Kuwait or any other place, but everyone in this Parliament has the right to disagree. I said that I hoped, but, unfortunately, I am not going to be satisfied.

That action would have signalled to the world that we support the United Nations' effort to restore Kuwait's sovereignty totally, and to our defence forces and their families that Australia's elected representatives have total confidence in and support for their cause. Most of all, it would have shown the world that Australia is totally committed to standing up against dictators such as Saddam Hussein who, by their atrocious actions displayed over a number of years, have threatened world peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the motion before the chamber relating to the Gulf crisis in the Middle East, but I do so in a very sombre and reluctant frame of mind. I believe that that mirrors very well the mood of the Australian people, who show no enthusiasm for this conflict at all but regard it as a duty which has been thrust upon us in concert with other members of the world community.

SPEECH.PARA: I have come to the conclusion that I believe most Australians have, that Saddam Hussein must be ousted from Kuwait by force. I will outline the reasons for coming to that conclusion. It goes against every inclination of my personality and the reason why I entered politics. It has not been an easy path but, as I say, I believe that I share the general mood of the Australian people in that regard.

We are not a nation of warmongers. We take no delight in waging war. The Australian characteristic is to honour the dead-those who fall in conflict-and to look after those who are repatriated to Australia having served in the armed forces abroad, but we do not glorify war.

I believe that that is an immediate and absolute contrast with the society controlled by Saddam Hussein. He is undoubtedly a murderous despot. He has moulded that society so that its very being requires the waging of war to give it political meaning and cohesion. It seems to take its very identity and substance from the waging of war, whether it is against Iran over eight years at the cost of one million lives for no territory gained at all, or against its own inhabitants, the Kurds, whose crumpled bodies we saw huddled in the alleyways of their villages-women and children. We saw in the hospital beds the blistered bodies of those who survived, as opposed to those corpses that were heaped in the quarters of the Kurdish villages.

As I say, by contrast and thankfully, there is no enthusiasm for the war here. To my mind the contrast is well epitomised by the fact that whereas Saddam Hussein has called for a jihad-a holy war-there is no call for a crusade here in Australia. We are not back in medieval times. There is no underlying religious or racist sentiment-whether express or covert-motivating or fuelling the commitment of the Australian people to this conflict.

I believe that we come to this position very reluctantly. I have heard no speech here of a warmongering type. There is a reluctant sense of doing what has to be done. I do not believe that it should be any other way. We have been chastened by the Vietnam experience into being cynical about the motives of those who undertake war-whether our allies or others-and we properly scrutinise those commitments to conflict involving, as they do, the killing of other human beings. But I believe that, while we do not glorify war, we have to make the commitment in this particular instance.
An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The parliamentary attendants will take the appropriate action.

— I also wish to refer especially to the Arab and Muslim communities in Australia because I am quite sure that they, too, do not share any of that warmongering sentiment which sometimes can be shared by those in the community who see the former homelands of their ancestors--

SPEECH.PARA: An incident having occurred in the gallery-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the attendants to remove that person from the gallery.

—I believe that the Australian Muslim and Arab communities also ought to be commended for the way in which they have conducted themselves during these weeks and months of the very tense times in the Australian community. Two Fridays ago I had the honour and privilege of attending the Friday prayers at the Lakemba Mosque in Sydney and I visited the mosque in Hobart, the capital of my home State. I spoke and listened to the sermons of the Imam al-Hilaly in Sydney and the Imam Fattah in Hobart. I heard each strongly commit his community to the non-violent and peaceful expression of either support or dissent in respect of government policy. They assert it and they are entitled to the same rights as all other citizens of Australia and inhabitants of this great Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I assured them on our part, as has the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) constantly, that the rest of the Australian community was expected to show tolerance and decency and allow them to go about their life in Australia and express their dissent, if they so wished, without harassment or intimidation or certainly any violent outbursts against those communities. It is a great sign of the strength of our multicultural maturity now in Australia that, thankfully, that has largely been the case.

I now outline the facts and values which lead me to support the motion. If I speak in terms of a just war, it is only in so far as it may serve to establish a just peace. Peace is not simply the absence of war but a situation where justice prevails. It is quite clear that peace did not prevail in Kuwait between 2 August and 16 January. Peace was not shattered by the use of force to oust Saddam Hussein on 16 January. This is a matter which the opponents of Australia's commitment and the United Nations commitment to the use of force refuse really to come to grips with. There was no situation of peace in Kuwait from 2 August onwards; there was a state of violence, an absolute lack of peace. There was a regime of terror, which has been the fate of the inhabitants of Kuwait since that fateful day of 2 August.

What has occurred there is revolting to human decency and has been totally outlawed by the world community. There has been a call for the liberating of the inhabitants of Kuwait and the remedying of a situation in accordance with international law. I will use only one source to illustrate the lack of peace since war was waged by invasion of the aggressor, Saddam Hussein, against Kuwait-and that is the Amnesty International report entitled Iraq/Occupied Kuwait: Human Rights Violations Since 2 August. It is a publication dated 19 December 1990. Amnesty International is a well respected organisation. In fact, many members of this chamber on all sides of politics are members of the Amnesty International Parliamentary Group. The index indicates the reading contained in this report. It includes:
3. Arbitrary arrests, detention without a trial and ``disappearances''
4. Torture and ill-treatment of detainees
5. The death penalty
6. Extrajudicial executions

They are just some of the headings of the pages and pages that catalogue the horrific oppression and brutality undertaken by the occupying forces. I note some of the covering remarks made by Amnesty International. In the press release accompanying the report, Amnesty International states:

Amnesty International has called on the Iraqi government to follow the release of hundreds of Western nationals by ending the imprisonment, torture and killing of thousands of people in Kuwait . . . Amnesty International details how Iraqi forces have tortured and killed many hundreds of victims, taken several thousand prisoners and left more than 300 premature babies to die after looting incubators from at least three of Kuwait City's main hospitals.
I will go into that later. The press release continues:

The report catalogues 38 methods of torture used by the Iraqi military, including cutting off people's tongues and ears, shooting them in the limbs, applying electric shocks to their bodies, and raping them.
Another press release states:

Doctors who worked in Kuwait's hospitals following the invasion said Iraqi soldiers brought in scores of bodies of young men, many of whom were shot at close range in the heart and head. The doctors were forced to issue death certificates saying the victims had died after arrival at the hospitals.

Scores of hangings have also been reported in the grounds of Kuwait University of people suspected of opposing Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. Those hanged were summarily executed after being accused of criminal offences.

There are case examples. This is a well documented report, as one would expect from Amnesty International. I will read the case of Sana' Al-Nuri, a 25-year old law student at Kuwait University. The report states:

According to eyewitness reports, she was killed on 8 August when Iraqi troops fired at a group of some 35 women demonstrating peacefully in al-Jabiriyya against Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. Another woman in her mid-20s was also reported to have been killed in the same incident, as well as two boys aged 13 and 16 who died after being shot in the head and heart respectively.
What moved me most in the catalogue of horror in this report is contained on page 56. I will read it in full:

In addition, over 300 premature babies were reported to have died after Iraqi soldiers removed them from incubators, which were then looted. Such deaths were reported at al-Razi and al-'Addan hospitals, as well as the Maternity Hospital. According to a Red Crescent doctor:

``Premature babies at the Maternity Hospital died after Iraqi soldiers took them out of the incubators. This happened in August, in the early days of the invasion. A total of 312 babies died in this way. I personally took part in the burial of 72 of them in al-Rigga cemetery.''

Another doctor working at al-'Addan Hospital, whose brother was a volunteer grave-digger, reported that 36 premature babies were buried in one day alone in August. An eyewitness account of such deaths at al-'Addan Hospital was provided by a 15-year-old Kuwaiti girl, who testified before the United State Congressional Human Rights Caucus on 10 October:

``The second week after the invasion, I volunteered at the al-'Addan Hospital . . . I was the youngest volunteer. While I was there, I saw the Iraqi soldiers come into the hospital with guns, and go into the room where 15 babies were in incubators. They took the babies out of the incubators, took the incubators and left the babies on the cold floor to die. It was horrifying.''
And there is more. Having read that report, I find it impossible to maintain that it is never justified to use military force to remove a tyrant.

I have moved to the same painful conclusion as Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the great famous German pastor, who found himself against every previous understanding he had of the claims of the gospel. This great pastor, particularly amongst the youth of Germany, involved himself in the assassination plot against Hitler because he came to the painful, reluctant conclusion that he had to be part of the process of removing a tyrant who was claiming the lives of so many innocent victims. I may be grievously wrong in coming to this conclusion; I may be being mislead by the same demonic force which animates the Iraqi regime-and I believe it is. But if so, I will have to bear responsibility for acting against the purpose which the creative spirit has for humanity. I have concluded that there is just cause for the world community to have resolved to act as it is acting.

To reiterate: quite apart from the invasion, itself a clear breach of international law, the behaviour of the occupying forces, which is totally consistent with the atrocious cruelties meted out to the Kurds, is a clear breach of the Geneva Conventions. The Fourth Geneva Convention-and Iraq is a party to this convention-which is meant to humanise, so far as is possible, the conduct of war, states the following in article 147:

Art. 147. Grave breaches to which the preceding Article relates shall be those involving any of the following acts, if committed against persons or property protected by the present Convention: wilful killing, torture or inhuman treatment, including biological experiments, wilfully causing great suffering or serious injury to body or health, unlawful deportation or transfer or unlawful confinement of a protected person, compelling a protected person to serve in the forces of a hostile Power, or wilfully depriving a protected person of the rights of a fair and regular trial prescribed in the present Convention, taking of hostages and extensive destruction and appropriation of property, not justified by military necessity and carried out unlawfully and wantonly.

In regard to almost all those matters there has been clear, documented violation of those particular requirements of the Fourth Geneva Convention. The perpetrators can be held personally responsible, if they can be identified at the end of this conflict, and their superior officers, of course, can be prosecuted in any domestic jurisdiction. They have clearly breached international law, as documented by Amnesty International, and common decency would say they are in breach of all those bonds which ought to unite the human family, of whatever race or creed, which shares this very small planet. Unless conventions such as the Geneva Convention are upheld and enforced, the horrors of warfare experienced by innocent civilian inhabitants of an invaded country like Kuwait will continue. I do not believe anyone can stand by and ignore the pleas to our common humanity.

I see that Senator Jo Vallentine is not in the chamber. I think Senator Vallentine has a total pacifist position, which accorded with my views, and I can respect that total commitment to the principle that one should never kill another human being for whatever apparently just or good reason. I may still pray to be able to resist killing an aggressor against me personally, but I do not believe I could in good conscience refuse to kill a barbarian killing babies in a maternity hospital. The wails and pleas of those babies cry out for our aid. I say `our' aid because it is our collective responsibility to come to the assistance of the most vulnerable and the most weak. Certainly, the babies of Kuwait are only one example of that vulnerable and weak population of inhabitants of that very small nation state, a member of the United Nations.

Even if I am right-and I think I have illustrated just cause for our intervention-it would only be justified if it were truly as a last resort. Many people have spoken of the exhaustion of diplomacy and I do not completely want to go over that ground again but I need to in order to exhibit why I have come to the conclusion I have. There is no doubt-and it is often forgotten-that when people speak, for example, of an Arab solution being preferable to that imposed by the United Nations, that Arab diplomacy exhausted itself in late July. In a press clipping from 27 July 1990 President Mubarak, the Egyptian President, who, the article says:

. . . made a whirlwind peace-keeping tour of Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia on Tuesday, said the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, had assured him he would not launch his million-strong armed forces against his small southern neighbour.

Arab diplomacy thought it had secured Kuwait from the threat of invasion, aggression and occupation when it got that undertaking given personally by President Hussein to President Mubarak of Egypt. Within two or three days the invasion took place in complete contradiction to the undertakings which were given. It indicated Saddam Hussein's contemptuous disregard for his Arab brothers and a repudiation of the undertaking he had given them. The invasion of 2 August indicated he would be unmoved by the pleas of the Arab world, and why would he not? After all he is the one who aspires to leadership of that world-his pan-Arab pretensions.

I think it also has to be emphasised, because these things are forgotten, that the date originally set by the United States in, as I recall, the pre-Christmas period was 1 January 1991. However, the world community said, `No, that is too early' and the Security Council set 15 January as the date. That was to give world leaders, particularly those such as the Russians and the French, who had historic alliances with Iraq, time to negotiate and to seek a compromise. I do not refer to all the leaders of the world who came to the same sad conclusion, but let us listen to what President Mitterrand said in relation to the vote of the National Assembly of France. On 16 January the National Assembly approved the use of force by 523 votes to 43 votes after Mitterrand and his socialist Prime Minister, Michel Rocard, said:
. . . Iraq's stubborn silence on a withdrawal from Kuwait had left France no other option.
