I say this to my Australian Democrat senator friends: They have to take into account the very close historical alliances and understandings that nations like France and Italy-and in a moment I will quote Craxi-have with Iraq. This is what President Mitterrand said:

I say it with regret but with determination: the use of armed force to oblige Iraq to evacuate Kuwait is now legitimate . . . France is not Iraq's enemy . . . Unfortunately not a single sign, not a single word from Baghdad gave hope that it would submit to the requirements of law.
In Italy, Craxi, the leader of the Socialists-I quote him because they are from fraternal parties-said in his speech to the Italian Parliament:

Yesterday, on his way back from his talks in Baghdad Daniel Ortega told me that the one word Saddam Hussein intends not uttering is the word withdrawal. But that is the very first word that he should utter-and should have already uttered.
Craxi goes on:
It is hard to see how what is happening can still be called an American affair, a product of American imperialism, an adventure generated by American interests.
He went on:
Never before has the international community been so united, so determined to achieve a common goal, in asserting a principle, in asking that the UN resolutions be respected.
Let me quote him a little more at length:

We have seen many dictatorial regimes throw themselves into military adventures in the conviction or the illusion of victory. But never before have we witnessed a regime issuing a challenge of war, knowing full well that it will lose. All this has coloured the conduct of the Iraqi regime with such irrationality and fanaticism, that it is beyond our horizon, removed from the principles in which we believe, from our desire to see every contest be the subject of dialogue and negotiations. It is removed from the peaceful and pacifist spirit of our tradition, the tradition of men and women of peace . . .

I believe that I stand, as do other senators in this chamber, in that tradition of dialogue and negotiation and of the seeking of peace, but we are confronted with a phenomenon that we, in our blessed Commonwealth of Australia, have never had to confront before. It is that of the absolutely fanatical and obdurate decision of Saddam Hussein to conduct his country's affairs in this warlike way, to the great terror of surrounding neighbours and indeed to the inhabitants of his own land.

There was an exhaustion of diplomacy amongst the Arabs and amongst the members of the European community, including the Russians who were very close to Saddam Hussein's regime. I think it was all summed up for me in the face, which I recall seeing on television, of the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Perez de Cuellar. One could see the failure of his mission, the great disappointment, the fact that he had been kept in humiliating circumstances waiting in the foyer hour after hour by Saddam Hussein; he was deliberately humiliated. He came away with a great sadness which he so eloquently expressed on behalf of the world community. On 15 January, the Secretary General issued this statement from New York:

. . . I most sincerely appeal to President Saddam Hussein to turn the course of events away from catastrophe and towards a new era of justice and harmony based on the principles of the United Nations charter./ . . . I wish to assure him, on the basis of understandings that I have received from governments at the highest level, that neither Iraq nor its forces will be attacked by those arrayed in the international coalition against his country./ . . . Peace in the region requires that all of its problems be resolved justly and equitably, in accordance with the principles of the charter of the United Nations.

I have every assurance, once again from the highest levels of government, that with the resolution of the present crisis, every effort will be made to address, in a comprehensive manner, the Arab-Israeli conflict, including the Palestinian question. I pledge my every effort to this end.

So the Secretary-General of the United Nations, in the tenth and final year of his tenure of that august office on behalf of all the nations of the world, made that heartfelt plea, and he was repudiated. Diplomacy has been exhausted. It is a very sad conclusion to come to, but I believe it is a conclusion shared by persons who are naturally in our tradition-the Australian tradition-of seeking everything short of war in order to resolve international conflicts.

That having been exhausted, I have to ask my friends, the Democrat senators: How many more weeks, how many more months do we give to Saddam Hussein before we are forced to oust his occupying forces carrying out the brutality and the pillage that they are undertaking under his orders in Kuwait? I have to pose these questions. I do not do it in a way that is meant to put blame or guilt.

What further atrocities are tolerable? What further attacks will there be on the maternity hospitals of Kuwait and the laying of premature babies on the bare, cold tiles of the maternity hospital today? How many more are to be allowed to die before we invade and try to oust those particular torturers and brutalising militaristic agents of Saddam Hussein? We really have to ask: Where do the killings, the rapes, the disappearances, the forced deportations of not tens, not hundreds but thousands of Kuwaitis end? When is the threshold reached where our compassion requires active intervention even though that active intervention will bring about death? The fact is that people are still being tortured, still being raped, still being murdered and still being deported and they are crying out for our help. I believe that there is a case for international solidarity. I believe that there is a common humanity.

As I say, I have come to the conclusion that, whereas I may resist, I hope, the urge to kill an assailant or an aggressor who is attacking me personally, when I hear the plea of the innocent, vulnerable and the especially weak I realise that I must stand between that person and the aggressor. But, further, with the greatest sadness if one has to kill the assailant or the aggressor, having exhausted every type of negotiation and diplomacy then I believe that is where we must stand as a nation in concert with other nations around the world. We have every evidence of Hussein's preparedness to terrorise civilian populations. The lobbing of scud missiles which of themselves are inaccurate into the civilian centres of Israel-Tel Aviv and Haifa-and the most cruel gassing of his own populations indicate that this man has no respect for human life.

Carnage will result from the waging of this further phase of combat. The war commenced on 2 August; the battle has been joined. The carnage that will occur over the next hours, days and weeks will be immense, but it can be brought to an end tomorrow, it can be brought to an end tonight if Saddam Hussein announces his withdrawal and occupation. He is the aggressor. He only has to make one simple statement.

I am quite confident that the Secretary-General of the United Nations would ensure that Saddam and his country are permitted a cease-fire and the ability to rebuild their relationships with the world community of nations. I certainly hope that he does so, so that the suffering of many peoples can be alleviated and true peace, which is a just peace, can be restored to the people of Kuwait. For that reason I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by congratulating Senator Tate on the speech he has just made. I thought that it was a superb speech. We do not hear many superb speeches in this place, but we just heard one then. I congratulate him on the content, but probably most of all because it was a personal statement. It was not an obligatory alignment with a stated position of his Party but was a compassionately and intensely argued personal statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I will attempt to make a similar statement, a personal statement. I stand proudly before my Senate colleagues tonight as a member of the peace movement and in support of the position taken by the Australian Democrats on this profound issue. Over the last 20 or 30 years my values have changed enormously. I was born in 1937, therefore the whole of my life-54 years-has been within the time when the ethos of war has prevailed. The ethos of war has prevailed throughout history until now. It is still prevailing. It has certainly been evident to me during my life.

My father fought in the Second World War and my earliest memories are of the impact of war on my own family and my own life. I was conscripted in 1956 in the post-Korean war flurry of conscription known as the national service scheme. For 20 years I spent my life in and around the Army-first of all, as a reserve infantry officer and later for 10 years in the Regular Army as a training specialist. During those 20 years I was left with a couple of very profound impressions. The first impression I have is in relation to people who serve in our military services, our armed services. I have extreme admiration for their courage, commitment, devotion, intention and professionalism. They rightly have and still enjoy the reputation of being among the best in the world. I admire them enormously for that.

We are not a nation of warriors; we are essentially a nation of peace seekers. I in no way detract from that very positive association with those who serve, who have served and still serve. I think I understand why and how they serve and I admire them enormously for it.

The second impression I have is reinforced by the fact that essentially I am a teacher-I was an educator most of the time in the Army-and student of history. As a senator, at the age of 54 I have slowly but surely reached the conclusion that all war is profoundly futile and obscene. As Senator Bjelke-Petersen rightly says, nobody wants it. I will turn to the question which was so adequately and appropriately addressed by Senator Tate of what is a just and necessary war later on in my remarks. I have not reached the conclusion that no war is necessary. What I am wrestling with now is whether this war is necessary. I think many people are wrestling with that question.

I have reached the conclusion that the greatest obligation on me as an individual is to contribute to the transition from the ethos of war to the ethos of peace. We are the critical generation. That transition must occur in our lifetime. The transition from the ethos of war to the ethos of peace is in our hands and it is especially in our hands as elected representatives in one of the world's great democracies.

I do not stand here as a member of a rent-a-crowd; I stand here as a sincere and committed member of what is known as the peace movement. Nobody has bought or rented me to go out and take my place in parades and on the street in support of ordinary Australians now or in the future. I simply believe that it is our profound responsibility to ensure that the transition from the ethos of war to the ethos of peace occurs now in our time.

Of course, I agree with everything that has been said about Hussein. He is a loathsome dictator. We all acknowledge that. It is a question of how we deal with such people, it is a question of method. Why are wars fought? Many wars throughout history have been fought at the whim and will and to satisfy the egos of dictators. Probably the majority of wars have been fought for that reason. Many wars have been fought to defend territory, home, house, farm, crops, one's place on earth. Many wars have been fought to defend territory. Many wars have been fought to save lives and limbs of young children and of ourselves. Many have been fought to defend values. Many lives have been sacrificed for democracy and for the rights of minorities to assemble freely and to state what they truly believe freely.

Most of the wars in my lifetime have probably been fought in defence of value sets. The most profound value set is the one that we hoped would prevail in the 1990s-the decade of democracy, the decade of freedom of assembly and the right to speak out, the right to be heard as Australians are being heard in the streets of this country now. Frankly, I believe that today was a sad day when our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) referred to the members of the peace movement in the terms in which he did. He said that they were mindless, that they were chanters of slogans. Sure, they sang the songs of John Lennon about being dreamers about peace. Sure, they chanted `Give peace a chance'. Slogans are brief, short and profound statements of what people feel. The fact that they were chanting slogans and singing songs does not make them mindless.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't they do it when Hussein invaded Kuwait?

—They were not there. They are doing it now, today. They have the right to do it here and now, today. I am not going to pick with them about why they did not do it before or somewhere else. I congratulate them on the fact that they did it today. These people were described as rent-a-crowd. That is a term that another Minister of this Government applied to 3,000 veterans when they gathered at the request of the leaders of the veterans 18 months ago in the town hall in Sydney-a meeting called by knights of the realm, the leaders of a generation of fighting soldiers and ex-servicemen. They went along and made a statement to the Government, only to be called a rent-a-crowd. The same mindless expressions were used then. The same mindless, appallingly insulting tags were placed upon people who fought for the freedom of assembly and the right of speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, I think that the debate in this country today took a very sour note when the Prime Minister mindlessly abused people exercising the right of freedom of assembly and freedom of speech. The same Prime Minister was desperately emotional when referring to a crowd of people who assembled in Tiananmen Square, who were exercising, pleading, with their dictators and tyrants for the rights to assemble, for the rights of democracy. Could they be reasonably described as rent-a-crowd? Who rented them?

Were the people who assembled in the streets of the countries of East Germany and overthrew the tyranny of communism rented? Who rented them? This is mindlessness, to abuse ordinary Australians exercising their most fundamental rights today. To abuse them for the exercise of those rights for which Australians have died previously is mindlessness. The Prime Minister did not call them silly old buggers. That was probably an equally mindless phrase that just dropped off the tongue some months ago.

The second line of allegation is that we are seeing the same faces. For some reason or other people who have been in support of the peace movement for 20 years are supposed to be ashamed of the fact that they come out time and time again and support the same value sets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were they when Hussein invaded Kuwait?

— I am not going to ask them that. I do not abuse them or call them mindless because they have supported a value set-freedom, peace, democracy-for 20 years. The same faces appear in churches on Sunday week after week, month after month and year after year, the same groups of people supporting and exercising their value set. Are they a rent-a-crowd? Are they mindless because they hold to a set of values and express them in a particular way for decades or perhaps even the whole of their lives? What an offensive comment to make. Are we as parliamentarians a rent-a-crowd because we come in here and sit and argue and debate and support the value sets for which and by which we have been elected? I believe that a greater exhibition of mindlessness occurs in this place month after month than we are seeing on the streets of Australia at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Frankly, I believe that it is mindless to belong to a political party that says, `You will not walk into your parliament and express your own point of view, but like sheep you will go in and in blocks like sheep vote for decisions that have been taken somewhere else'. I believe that that is probably a greater demonstration of mindlessness than we have seen on the streets of Australia in the last few days. Senator Boswell said a few minutes ago in his speech, and he had the right to make the statement, that he hoped that the motion before this chamber now would be supported by every senator, that every hand would go up mindlessly in support of a motion without an attempt to amend, debate, analyse, vary from or make personal contributions to the debate about it. That is what happened in the Iraqi Parliament six or seven days ago. Every hand went up. That is what happened for years in the Soviet Union. Every hand went up in support of every proposition. That is mindlessness.

I turn briefly to the issue of conscription. The Australian Democrats will be attempting to bring on a debate about the critical issue of conscription. The Prime Minister of this country yesterday-I do not want to misquote him because I have not actually read the words-suggested that the discussion of or debate about or even the consideration of, I am not sure what he meant precisely, the issue of conscription was criminal and irresponsible. I think it would be criminal and irresponsible not to deliberate and not to debate the issue of conscription in relation to a war which could be a massive and prolonged war and for which Australians could be conscripted unless we obstruct that possibility. Do not tell me they could not be conscripted. They were conscripted for the First World War, the Second World War, the Vietnam War and they were conscripted after the Korean War, when it was all over, in the spurious belief that there was going to be a pouring out of Asia of a red mass that would overrun us.

We have embraced conscription at the drop of a hat. Historically we are a conscripting nation. To suggest that we should not consider conscription and debate it, and to suggest that to do so is nothing short of being criminal and irresponsible, is a mindless statement to make. Senator Ray has suggested that our attempt to bring forward the issue of conscription for debate is a publicity stunt brought on in recent days. I remind Senator Ray that eight years ago my predecessor, Senator Colin Mason, put before the Senate a private member's Bill which, had it been passed by this Parliament, would have said that conscription could not be introduced without a referendum. He introduced it twice and I have introduced it twice, and it is still before the Parliament.

The issue of conscription is not a new-found issue for the Democrats. We have had it before this Parliament in the form of private member's Bills for the past eight years. Senator Ray is being either mischievous or deliberately dishonest in his statement of what our intention really is. I will give him the choice. Frankly, I do not think he even knew that such a private member's Bill was before the Parliament. It not only addressed the issue of conscription but also said that Australian troops should not be committed to theatres of war overseas without the approval of both Houses of Parliament. That has been a private member's Bill of the Democrats for eight years.

The Prime Minister offers his assurances that there will not be conscription. Senator Ray offers assurances that there will not be conscription. I remind the Senate that on 25 April last year the Prime Minister stood on the shores of Gallipoli and offered assurances that Australian troops would not be committed to wars on foreign soil. I wonder whether he meant also foreign waters or foreign airspace. I wonder what he really meant to say when he emotionally offered that assurance to the Australian people on 25 April last year. I am sure that it was said with good intent, but it is now history. It is of no consequence; it is gone. I do not believe that it would have been a mindless statement. I believe that it would have been a deliberate and sincere statement, but even sincerity can be pushed aside by the demands of international relations in war.

I wish to cite the double standards that are inherent in this whole debate. We are hearing about the hideous Hussein, and we all accept that. We are not hearing much about the United States' invasion of Panama or the Soviet Union's invasion of Afghanistan, or the Australian endorsed invasion of East Timor by Indonesia. We could go on and on. We are not hearing much about that. There is a lot of selectivity in the posturing about the need for us to commit ourselves to a military strategy when there are workable alternative strategies available. Senator Powell has convincingly, I believe, put before this chamber earlier in the day the arguments that there are alternatives; that we can shift towards the ethos of peace and the methodology and the techniques of peaceful resolution and shift away from the resolutions of the warriors.

When I was driving to Canberra yesterday afternoon I listened to a discussion on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). Fortunately, the ABC still has spiritual programs on Sundays. We hear a lot from experts these days. I must admit I am a little sceptical about who is expert in what these days, but I am prepared to accept the fact that the two people who contributed to this program were expert in what the spiritual dimension of Islam says about war: why would Muslims go to war? Then we heard the argument about why Christians would go to war. It was really a theological debate-which has been so superbly touched upon earlier by Senator Tate-about the theological question of when war is just and justifiable.

I listened to the argument about Islam and what the Koran said, but I did not really understand it. Then I listened to the Jesuit priest explaining the Christian concept of a just war. There were a number of criteria that had been laid down by people like Saint Augustin, Saint Thomas Aquinas and others to support the theological concept of a just war. Of the five criteria discussed, the Jesuit priest believed that three were fulfilled and two of them were questionable. Of the two criteria of a just war that he believed were questionable, one was, in my terms-I hope that I am not misrepresenting it-that essentially one must make a judgment as to whether there will be greater good in the outcome of a war than the evil involved in the conduct of it. One has to make a judgment as to whether, finally, in the outcome of the war, the good will outweigh the evil.

He said that he thought it was utterly impossible to make a judgment about the good that would emerge from this war-and who knows how this war is going to finish up? Five days ago I was told that 600 aircraft had been destroyed within an hour; that the technology of modern warfare was prevailing. I am increasingly convinced that the technology of modern warfare has not prevailed. I am told that there could be-who knows?-seven aircraft destroyed by that extraordinary display and execution of the technology of war. Who knows where this war is going to go?

While waiting to be interviewed for a radio interview about two hours ago I listened to the preliminary remarks, the update from the Gulf. Essentially it said that a whole series of leaders of nations are now saying, `If they do this we will do that', and, `If that happens we will do that'. Nobody knows what the outcome of this war is going to be or how long it will continue. Nobody knows whether the good will outweigh the evil, because the whole thing is evil. It is an obscenity from beginning to end. It is futile from beginning to end, and to attempt to apply such logic is equally futile.

The other criterion that stuck in my mind was that it must be a measure of last resort. I think this is the criterion that the Democrats feel most strongly about. The theological argument was that the war is just if it is a measure of last resort. Our dispute with the Government and the Opposition is that we have not reached the point of last resort. Senator Tate asked me: how many babies have got to die? I do not know; nor does he. We do not know when it is justified to say that this now is a measure of last resort. The fact is that these criteria cannot apply to the circumstances which we find ourselves addressing in this particular situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the evil continues while you do not know.

—The evil will continue while we do not know. I can only agree with that. The conclusion I have arrived at-and I said this was a personal statement-is that all war is obscene. The statistics will probably throw light on the level of its obscenity. I do not think they will really help us in any way to arrive at the answer to those two criteria of whether more good will come from it than evil or whether it is truly a measure of last resort.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly, I would like to address myself to a question which was put to me earlier in the day by my friend-and I mean that quite sincerely-Senator Michael Baume when, during demonstrations in the gallery, he turned to me and said sincerely, `Paul, does this make you proud? Does it make you proud to hear people expressing to this chamber their feelings about this issue?'. I can answer him now that I certainly do not feel ashamed that Australians are able to come into their Parliament and listen to debate. I do not feel ashamed of the fact that Australians felt moved to assemble outside their Parliament and to come in here. I do not feel ashamed that some of them felt strongly enough to interject and shout out. I was proud of the way in which the President of the Senate responded to that. It was handled with justice, understanding, perception and sensitivity.

I must admit that I was not particularly proud of the fact that some members of the Senate shouted out that they should go and have a wash, have a bath and that perhaps it would be the first bath they have had. I do not know whether there is a smell test applied in this country as to who can and cannot have feelings, and who can and cannot express their feelings. My answer to Senator Baume is that I was not ashamed about what occurred in this chamber today; nor was I ashamed about the manner in which we responded to it. The fact is that this is a very profoundly challenging issue. I congratulate Senator Tate for addressing it as such in personal terms. He genuinely attempted to convince us and the Australian people as to why he has taken the position he has.

I believe that my position is a sincere one, arrived at as a result of personal experience and deliberation over this issue. I believe that there are millions of Australians out there who hold their position sincerely and not mindlessly. Frankly, I believe that today the debate in this nation took a tragic turn when the Prime Minister of the country failed to acknowledge the fact that in this beautiful democracy that we have we should expect and be proud of the fact that Australians can protest about things with which they do not identify.

I commend to the Senate the amendment which my colleague Senator Coulter will later move on behalf of the Democrats. Hopefully, a motion will be put before the Senate for its consideration which is not designed exclusively to endorse a military solution to these problems but which acknowledges openly and honestly the fact that other solutions are available and could possibly be effective if given a chance. My statement essentially has been a personal one. I make it in complete support of the position that has been taken by my Party on this issue.

I would like to congratulate Senator Powell on the manner in which she has placed the position of both the Democrats and the people in the peace movement before the Australian nation over the last several weeks. The fact that we are placing it before the Parliament now in the form of an amendment to this motion makes me extremely proud. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues would know, I am not accustomed to prefacing the speeches I make in this chamber by commending Government members for their speeches. But today, the speeches of Senators Gareth Evans, Robert Ray and Tate, each in their separate ways, have made an important contribution to this debate, which has to be probably the most important debate that most of us in the Senate will ever take part in. Indeed, in many respects I could have put my name to Senator Robert Ray's speech. I welcome the very clearly demonstrated concern for the troops under his authority and his understanding of their commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said earlier today, and I dare say it will not be said for the last time, that probably the most awesome responsibility that a Prime Minister of a nation can ever undertake is that of committing the men and women of his Defence Force to war. The Opposition, as is now well known, has supported the Government and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in that decision. We must not forget that the aggression that has led us to this stage took place five long months ago; five long months during which there has been negotiation after negotiation and United Nations resolution after resolution. What I found so interesting in Senator Gareth Evans's speech was the tracing of the history of efforts to maintain a peace.

When I was a child-a long time ago, I am afraid-the United Nations seemed to most of us to be a bright hope for the future. We had been told of the failure of the League of Nations and we hoped that this new body would solve the problems of the world and give us peace forever. But the growth of the United Nations coincided with the growth of the Cold War and, sadly, we saw the United Nations fail, as the League of Nations did before it.

When we think about this whole issue we should give credit where it is due and recognise the important role which the United Kingdom and the United States of America, particularly under the leadership of Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan, played in ending the Cold War. It is only because the Cold War has ended that at last aggression of the sort perpetrated by Saddam Hussein is able to be dealt with by the nations of the world. It is now possible to get resolutions such as resolution 678 and its predecessors through the Security Council. It has meant that action can be effectively taken to deal with aggression against a United Nations member. Our fellow members of the United Nations have properly formed a multinational force to do so.

We may not like or approve of the form of government in some of the countries which are members of the United Nations, but members of the United Nations are entitled to the support of their fellow members when under attack, especially when the United Nations so resolves, as it has in this case. The Australian Government has very properly contributed to the force in the Gulf first of all to enforce sanctions and, secondly, to contribute to the allies' war effort.

Despite the constant barrage of the anti-American propaganda of some anti-war groups and despite the strong leadership role taken by the United States, this is not a US-Iraqi war. It is the sad but proper response by members of the United Nations to the refusal of Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.

In recent days we have been hearing a great deal about the need for the Arabs to resolve their own problems in their own way. In fact, that has been debated quite extensively this afternoon. I do not intend to go into it in any detail, except to say that while it is a superficially attractive proposition, it does not recognise that the Arabs had failed to find a solution to this problem back in the middle of last year. Iraq's approach to solving what it sees as problems has not been acceptable to most of its neighbouring Arab countries. Their presence among the multinational force demonstrates their determination to halt the aggressor before his ambitions extend beyond Kuwait.

There will still be long term political problems to be dealt with in the Middle East when this war ends, but that is no argument for allowing Hussein to sit tight in Kuwait now. The rape and pillage in Kuwait, spoken of so eloquently this afternoon by Senator Tate, seems to be given merely perfunctory recognition by some peace activists when the justification for this war is debated. It is too easy for some to concentrate on anti-American propaganda and to ignore the cruel abuse of the people of Kuwait.

The absence of a democratically-elected government in Kuwait seems to allow some people to ignore the monstrous and cruel deprivation and treatment meted out to the people of Kuwait. I have been astonished and, I must say, even appalled at the depth of hatred of America and Americans which seems to be present in some of the anti-war protesters. These people, who one would expect and hope would use rational debate and reasoned argument, seem to be so corroded and blinded by their prejudices against America. Where are those protests? Where have those protests been? Outside the Iraqi Embassy? We have not been sucked into this by the United States, as some would claim. We have major national interests to defend and matters of international principle for which to fight.

As I said before, negotiations and diplomacy have been continuing at a constant and urgent pace since the invasion on 2 August, and the decision by the allies cannot in all honesty be described as the result of manipulation by the United States. The United Nations Security Council made 12 separate resolutions on the issue, and 28 independent nations have taken the decision to commit troops to remove Iraq from Kuwait. I trust that if ever the day should come that Australia were invaded, our fellow members of the United Nations would see fit jointly to take action to remove the invader from our land.

I recognise that there are people of genuine views who oppose all wars and some who oppose this war in particular. I respect their views, and I am glad that they live in Australia where they are free to express those views rather than in Iraq or Kuwait where such views expressed bring death. Peace in the Middle East will not come by wishful thinking, nor even by demonstrations, let alone by stunts such as we have seen in this chamber from the gallery today. But it cannot come by appeasement. Sadly, it seems, too few have studied the history of dealing with tyrants, because tyrants cannot be appeased successfully. Saddam Hussein is a tyrant who supports world terrorism as well as gassing his own people.

We are dealing with a man who has called on Iraqis to mount a terrorism campaign around the world against civilians. Even in the furthest point in the world from Iraq, peaceful Tasmania, the need to guard against terrorism can now be seen. People, Australian citizens, going about their lawful business cannot leave a car unattended for five minutes beside an airline terminal while they help the elderly or the infirm with their luggage. That such measures should be necessary speaks volumes for the type of war that we are facing and the mentality of the man whom some would appease.

All wars are indeed evil, but I am convinced that there are occasions when the greater of two evils is not to go to war against an aggressor. To sit by and allow others to be treated as the people and the babies of Kuwait have been treated and as the people of Israel have now been treated is quite unconscionable. I could not pass by on the other side.

Our part in the war effort can only be hindered by a lack of unity in our country now that we are at war. There have been cruel and misguided efforts by some people in this country in recent days to turn their protests not upon the Government, which in a democracy must take the responsibility, but on our service personnel whose duty it is to obey the duly elected government. This idiocy is not only heartless; it shows no recognition of the long term and disastrous effects of similar action taken against the men who fought for Australia in Vietnam.

Three years ago we had the welcome home parade to the men from Vietnam. It was a small way of saying thank you to those who felt rejected by their country when they returned home from that war. It was only necessary because so many of those men were embittered and psychologically affected by the misguided attacks on the defence forces rather than on the Government which sent them away.

Today this country is still caring for many of those veterans with psychological counselling and long term psychiatric care. We know what that treatment did to those men. How dare another generation, with the knowledge of the effects of the previous attacks on the Vietnam generation of soldiers, do that to the current generation of servicemen. As one who spent a ghastly and worried year while my husband served his country with the infantry in Vietnam, I cannot bear to once again see these mindless attacks on our loyal defence forces.Around the country, defence establishments have been defaced, imitation blood has been daubed and service personnel have been harassed and abused. It is disgraceful, and it must stop in the name of justice and humanity.

Also abhorrent are the tactics being used by some to frighten Australian families about conscription. The Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) yesterday announced the theft and misuse of Department of Defence letterheads to frighten Australians about conscription. I have also been informed of doorknockers in some suburbs in Hobart who claim that they need to know of 18-year-olds in the household to facilitate arrangements once the call-up is introduced. Former servicemen are also being told that the reserves will be called out and are making inquiries as to the details. Truth may be the first casualty of war, but these hoaxes can only be utterly rejected as cruel and anti-Australian.

International relief agencies have predicted one million displaced persons from this war. This surely is a mighty challenge to all Australians, including those protesters, to start working to help the victims of war. Mindless chanting by a tiny raucous minority in this chamber, as we have endured today, will achieve nothing except a flush of excitement as is usual with exhibitionists.

Peace now will not come until the invader is removed, but in that process the world will need to give care and help to those displaced by the fighting. Yet let those who claim to have a monopoly on morality in their hope for peace work to help the victims of war. Let them not delude themselves, however. This debate is taking place today by the duly elected representatives of the people of Australia representing the majority of Australians. I believe in the power of prayer and I believe that it is important that those who believe should pray for peace, but let those prayers extend to prayers for the young men and women who have been sent by the allies to fight for peace and for their families who wait and worry at home.

The precision bombing that has been undertaken by the allied pilots day after day has not come about just through technology, vital though that is. That high state of technology is obvious and is also present on our Australian ships. That technology would be as nothing if it were not for the professionalism, training and discipline of the people who operate it. Keeping those planes in the air and keeping those ships and weapon systems operating effectively can be done only by people. These are the people we tend to ignore in times of peace but who are essential if peace is to be won. These are the people who, having been trained so highly, must be retained in the Defence Force for the defence of Australia.

We cannot afford to go on watching while so many of these young people leave our Defence Force, because it is young people who fight wars: young, active human beings who train hard to achieve professionalism and who need to be ready when called upon, as we have done in this case to help the Kuwaitis. Some people would portray our service men and women as militaristic, seeing the uniform only and not the human heart inside. They do not go to war with a gung ho approach, although they sometimes use that as a cover for their fear; for mostly they are fearful of their duty.

Those watching television in the last few days will recall seeing a young British pilot being asked what it was like to go to war. He said that it was absolutely frightening; there was the fear of failure and the fear of dying. Other servicemen have expressed it in different ways, often with a self-deprecating attempt at humour. But we have also seen the exhaustion in the eyes of those pilots as they came back from the raids. Some of those servicemen have already been killed or taken prisoner, or are still hiding behind enemy lines. How many more of these young servicemen will die or be wounded before peace is won?

I have previously drawn to the Government's attention the fact that there are outstanding issues of concern to the Opposition which relate to the protection of our men and women on active service. To date I have not had any word from the Government that they have been resolved. The Opposition is dissatisfied and angry at this failure because these issues urgently need attention. It is not enough for us to sit for two days debating our commitment of our personnel if they are not given fair and equitable treatment for their service.

There are three areas that need particular attention. I am glad that the Minister for Defence is in the chamber so I can emphasise the points to him. First of all, all inequality of treatment between male and female servicemen under the Veterans' Entitlements Act must be removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be.

—It was never fair but, now that women are on operational service in combat-related positions, it is imperative that the inequality be rectified. I was going to say that the Government must give an undertaking to do so. I take it from the Minister's interjection that that is an undertaking from the Government and I welcome it.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, for the first time since 1917, young men and women-some regulars, some reservists-will not be eligible for war service loans if they die or are invalided out as a result of their war service. This is intolerable and must be urgently addressed.

Thirdly, we are relying on senior Reserve medical specialists-general surgeons, orthopaedic surgeons and anaesthetists-to supply our commitment of medical personnel to the force. They are there because the Australian Defence Force is now an integrated force of regulars and reservists. Officially, they are volunteers because there has not been an official call-out. However, they are subsidising their own service to the tune of $15,000 to $30,000 for their three months on duty.

The Government has said that it is government policy not to reimburse Commonwealth employees for the cost of private business overheads incurred while undertaking government service-in this case, staff salaries, rental of professional rooms, et cetera. Only today I received a letter from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Bilney, in which he pointed out that these people volunteered to join the Reserve and volunteered to go to the Gulf. The letter states:
I believe these allowances and the invalidity provisions available are fair and equitable in the circumstances applying so far.

By that he is referring to the allowances available to all reservists. He is not referring to the special case of the medical people. It is desperately short-sighted because the Government has not recognised the danger of this approach and its inconsistency with the principles laid down in the Defence White Paper of 1987. It is incredible that urgent action has not been taken on the matter. It has been an important area needing reform since the integrated force was introduced. It is not just an issue of justice and equity for these servicemen. It also will have a serious impact on our defence capability.

While I have no doubt that those who are asked to volunteer will try to do so, as have those who are already there, I believe that when this current deployment is over we will be seriously embarrassed by the resignations of senior Reserve doctors. These are the people who currently enable us to operate in peacetime with only a minimum of senior medical people on the regular payroll. Yet, come an operational deployment, they are absolutely essential to our forces. It is awful to contemplate sending our forces away to war without the necessary senior and experienced surgeons and anaesthetists we can currently call on from the reserves. This then is the third question urgently needing attention and a satisfactory answer from the Government.

Today, in supporting the motion, we in the Opposition cannot forget the invasion and occupation of Kuwait. We recognise that our forces are implementing resolution 678 of the United Nations Security Council. We have full confidence in and support for both our own and all the US-led forces serving in the multinational force and we deplore the unprovoked attack on Israel. Above all, we recognise the need to intensify efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East.

For those men, women and children who live in all the Gulf countries, the daily developments are more than changing images on a television screen, as they are to us. They are intensely personal matters of life and death. They crave peace, as we do for them. We cannot, however, support any suggestion that a just resolution of the Palestinian issue can be dependent upon the behaviour of the aggressor, the invader. We will continue to work for peace and stability in the region and the first step has to be the unconditional withdrawal of the invader from Kuwait.

There are already countries which deserve public recognition for their efforts to stop the invader: first of all, the United States, with its strong leadership role in establishing and maintaining the coalition of nations; secondly, Turkey, which has had the courage to allow the United States Air Force to use its facilities, and Turkey's North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies which have publicly declared their support for Turkey; thirdly, the Arab nations which are serving with the multinational force despite the emotional blackmail of Saddam Hussein. Also there is Israel which has shown such incredible restraint after attacks on its civilian population. We must recognise their contribution towards obtaining peace.

We in this country, at home, have a role-that, having sent our forces away, we must demonstrate our support for them by our unity of purpose. No matter how professional and how well-trained and dedicated the members of the multinational force are, one thing is certain: there will be casualties. Indeed, there have already been casualties. That time, above all, is when we must maintain unity and continue to give them our support.

Field Marshal Sir William Slim, a former Governor-General of Australia, a brave soldier and a great and loved leader of his soldiers, spoke at Rabaul in New Britain many years ago in a ceremony to commemorate the dead from Australia of two world wars. He asked whether our dead of those two world wars had died in vain. He answered his own question by saying that we should never believe that they died in vain. In a most moving speech he concluded by saying:

. . . in pride and faith, let us who follow them be resolute in duty as they were. Let us leave this ceremony with ringing in our ears a message that was once delivered at such a gathering as this almost three thousand years ago in Ancient Greece. It is a message that those whom we commemorate today lived and died by, and they would, I think, in these uneasy and perilous days, have us remember it:
Only those deserve freedom who are prepared to defend it.
That, Madam Acting Deputy President, is why I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most Australians agree absolutely on many aspects of the current situation in the Gulf and, similarly, most of us in this chamber agree absolutely on many aspects. No-one in this chamber wants war. No-one in this chamber believes that the Iraqis should be allowed to get away with invading Kuwait. Everyone here agrees that sanctions against Kuwait were a good idea. Everyone agrees that the United Nations (UN) should play, should have played and should still play a major role in the correction of the situation. Absolutely no-one doubts the courage and the commitment of Australian personnel in action in the Gulf.

SPEECH.PARA: United Nations Security Council resolution 678 of 1990 authorised the use of all necessary means to ensure that Iraq was removed from Kuwait. Obviously our differences of opinion arise over what is necessary. UN Security Council Resolution 678 has one objective, and that objective is to remove Iraqi troops from Kuwait.

It is interesting to note that the British Prime Minister announced last Friday that the anti-Iraq coalition had no intention of imposing a government on Iraq once it had been beaten into submission. All this must mean that this war will stop as soon as Iraqi troops leave Kuwait. We will then take no further action against Saddam Hussein.

Saddam Hussein is a torturer and a bully. No-one disagrees with that. We have not gone to war over any of his tactics, except for the invasion of Kuwait. If we want to talk about human rights violations, there are a few more places in this world where human rights violations occur with monotonous regularity and a truly gruesome and sadistic efficiency. What about Birundi, what about Somalia, what about Mauritania and the Sudan? What about Sri Lanka where so many thousands of people have died? What about the places where people are tortured every day? Hundreds of people are tortured every day. What about Brazil where young people are picked up by the military police, tortured and thrown on rubbish heaps to get rid of the crime rate in the country? There are many countries in this world that Amnesty International has reported on; there are many countries in this world that Amnesty wants brought to justice.

I for one am very pleased that that one report on Iraq seems to have had so much influence on people that sanctions were put in place against Iraq. This is excellent. Let us see a few sanctions against other places.

Some of the key points made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in support of the Government's support for war were contradictory, we believe. The Australian Democrats welcome his admission that the sanctions imposed would probably have worked in time. There is no doubt that all the evidence supports this view. A study of 115 sanctioned regimes, done at Georgetown University in the United States of America, concluded that sanctions have worked where they affect 25 to 35 per cent of a nation's external trade. Iraq is especially dependent on trade and its trade has been cut by 90 to 97 per cent.

We are convinced that had Senator Evans been left with the carriage of the Gulf crisis, our support for war would not have materialised so soon. The tragic fact is that this Minister had this issue wrested from him by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who chose to justify war with the following specious judgment given in his speech to the Parliament on 4 December when he said:
Further economic hardship is (not) likely to change the minds of Iraq's leaders. Sanctions . . . cannot force the hand of a dictatorial leadership . . .

Clearly the Prime Minister has redirected Australia's Gulf policy away from sanctions and towards war against the better judgment of most sanctions experts. Senator Evans made great play of the fact that diplomacy had already failed. What he failed to acknowledge was that the timing of the recent last ditch attempts at negotiation was driven by the totally artificial war deadline of 15 January. Had those initiatives been timed to coincide with the time at which sanctions really began to bite-which Senator Evans admitted would have happened, and which was expected to occur only a few months from now-then the outcome may have been altogether different.

As of last August the Minister held this view. He stated correctly that there was no point in holding serious negotiations until the sanctions had started to bite. He now appears to have forgotten that point. This demonstrates that the push for war, which began within two weeks of the invasion of Kuwait, has dismembered the sanctions strategy, at least for the time being. Senator Evans also claimed that there was no time to wait for sanctions to work because Kuwaitis are suffering. The fact that they are suffering is indisputable and Iraq stands condemned for that, but on 6 November last, Senator Evans told the Senate:

It is acknowledged that, if full-scale war does break out in the area of Kuwait, there is a very real danger indeed that the city-state will be very largely destroyed. That is an outcome that nobody prefers.

As we know, full scale fighting in Kuwait city is highly probable. Senator Evans also claimed that war was needed to destroy the Iraqi nuclear weapons program which may produce a bomb within a year. This is obviously a blatant furphy. A British arms expert, and a former nuclear physicist, Frank Barnaby, on 12 December said:
The stories released recently are more propaganda than technical reality.

He was referring to the Iraqi capacity to make its own nuclear bombs. We believe it would take Iraq about five years to get to the stage where it could actually drop nuclear weapons on another state-if it could get there. The fact remains that a maximum amount of time was not given for the economic sanctions against Iraq to work and consequently for war, hopefully, to have been prevented.

We have been told today that those sanctions were failing to achieve their objective. This is despite the evidence provided by the United Nations committee given the task of monitoring the sanctions, evidence which proved that even as early as mid-December Iraq was suffering badly from the effects of the international embargo.

From the start of the crisis, however-particularly in the United States of America but also here in Australia-there seems to have been an unseemly haste to go to war. Given that the main strategic objectives of the United Nations Security Council in the Gulf could have been achieved by a firm and long haul strategy of containment and sanctions, we need to ask why there has been this hurry.

The reasons given for the start of hostilities last week are nowhere near convincing enough when one considers the tragedy of what is involved in going to war. As the months ahead will no doubt show us, we face one of the most lethal wars since 1945 involving over one million troops and a strong possibility that weapons of mass destruction could be used. President Bush in relation to this war against Iraq has claimed:
. . . raises the greatest moral issue since World War II.

When we hear this statement we must recall several international incidents which have taken place over the last 45 years, for which the United States response has been totally at odds with the present day situation. We have heard much in recent weeks about the importance of upholding numerous United Nations resolutions in relation to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. We are therefore entitled to ask: how has the world taken action to fulfil innumerable and similarly worded United Nations resolutions concerning East Timor, Tibet, Cyprus, and of course the other occupied territories in the Middle East? Why is it that in none of these cases has the United States felt it necessary to go to war to fulfil United Nations resolutions?
There is a strong moral argument here that will need to be addressed in the months ahead and it is very understandable that tens of thousands of Australians have taken to the streets over it.

We should also note that this war will undoubtedly involve huge costs for all the countries presently involved. There should be no mistake about this. There will be an enormous loss of life in any war, and especially during the months ahead. Massive damage will be inflicted on the major cities, oil production facilities, harbours and other communication facilities which are so vital to the well being of the international community.

The United States military Gulf commander, General Norman Schwarzkopf, has said that in his estimation it could take up to six months to win this conflict. Of course, once the ground troops commence their campaign, and if they get bogged down, that six month campaign could go on much longer. Once again we are being subjected to the militaristic view which promises a short, sharp conflict, but the undoubted air superiority of the United States brought to bear in this huge pre-emptive strike is just the beginning. We accept that the United States led air forces have had some remarkable success in these early days, but the fact is that air power alone does not win wars.

Sooner or later there will need to be an attempt to dislodge the Iraqi ground forces from Kuwait. We do not believe we should underestimate the Iraqi forces. They are acclimatised and they are used to operating their equipment in the extremes of climate in that desert. Much more importantly, and a point not to be underestimated, they will be fighting in defence of their homeland and in defence of their religion. As opposed to this force, the United States led forces are largely untried under such conditions, and they face an enormous logistic tail that will prove to be a negative factor in the weeks ahead. Efforts to actually eliminate Saddam Hussein or to occupy Iraq will naturally take much longer and cost more in human suffering as well as in economic terms.

The fact that Australia is now involved in a war situation also raises the very important issue of the way such decisions are arrived at here. Honourable senators may recall that in October last year I moved amendments to the Defence Legislation Amendment Bill which attempted to ensure that Australian troops could not be sent overseas without the agreement of both houses of parliament. As I said at the time, such a provision is one which already applies in other countries, as we have seen, and it would allow a full and proper debate and a vote to take place before our forces are sent off to war, not after the event, as we are doing at the moment.

I would also like to say a few things about the way in which those of us in the peace movement, including the Democrats, have been somewhat hysterically accused of being mere appeasers in this crisis. Let me say that I believe it is a sad truth, accentuated in recent weeks, that few politicians in this country understand that to advocate alternatives to war or to oppose war does not equate with a policy of appeasement.
