TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting we heard a fair bit about the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1938, I think it was. We have not heard an awful lot about the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, when there were not a great many people running to go to war over it or even to impose sanctions. Would those who now accuse us of being appeasers also have accused the United States and the European Community of appeasement simply because they choose not to go to war against the Soviet Union because of that country's actions in Hungary in 1956, in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and, more recently, in Afghanistan just over a decade ago?

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of Afghanistan, all sorts of alternative measures were employed in an effort to achieve the West's strategic objectives, short of an all-out war. The United Nations was not in the business of appeasing Iraq over its occupation of Kuwait. It took unprecedented action through economic sanctions, enforced by an embargo so effective that even the Central Intelligence Agency had to admit that the sanctions had managed to stop an incredible 97 per cent of all Iraqi exports. Sanctions were depriving Iraq of most of its revenue and of the imports which it needed to develop its military capabilities.

Exactly five months and two days-the period between the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the start of hostilities last week-cannot be argued convincingly to have been the maximum time for sanctions to do their job. Giving sufficient time for sanctions and diplomatic pressure to work is far preferable to the tragic loss of life which the whole world will shortly feel. This has always been the Democrats' stated position in relation to the Gulf. Instead, we have rushed into the war option with such enthusiasm that few of us seem to have realised the enormity of the road upon which we have now embarked.

In finishing, I would like to associate the Democrats with calls which have been made by the Government and, I imagine, by the Opposition that we should have a lot more tolerance in this community towards our own Arab community. Indeed, I believe that some intolerance has been shown towards our Jewish community as well. We should realise that these people are exactly the same as us. They are all Australians and none of us want a war.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to support the motion on the Gulf crisis that is before the Senate this evening. The decision made by the Government is correct. I have said that on numerous occasions at the many press interviews I have given since 2 August when Iraq invaded Kuwait.

SPEECH.PARA: A decision to commit armed forces by any government is the most serious decision a government can make. It can be made only with the full support of the major parties of the Parliament and only with the support of the majority of the people of the nation. Any other formula is bound to end in disaster. It is absolutely imperative, as it is the right decision, that it is supported, and supported by a unanimous decision of this Parliament. We simply cannot put the lives of service men and women on the line and have bickering and a fifth column running within the country, particularly when the issue is beyond dispute.

Having said that, when I read the motion this afternoon I wished that it had been worded slightly differently. For example, the first section of the motion talks about the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait. What the United Nations (UN) is concerned about is the occupation of Kuwait by the Iraqis, and the motion should reflect our concern to see the occupation ended.

In the third paragraph we express full confidence in and support for the Australian forces serving with the United Nations multinational forces in the Gulf. But we also fully support all the other forces that are there on behalf of the United Nations. It is remiss of the Government not to have seen the necessity to include those two points in the motion.

I do not propose to go through the history of the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq; it has been done by many speakers on both sides of the chamber. Quite simply, without any warning or provocation, one country was invaded. It was seized; it was annexed; the legitimate government was expelled; a puppet government was set up; and there followed a chain of rape, torture and murder of thousands of its citizens. Material possessions were taken and the nation was stripped of any assets.

One of the reasons why Kuwait was the object of Iraqi aggression was not any territorial claim but simple lust for money. The Iraqis wished to seize the billions of dollars in overseas assets that the very rich country of Kuwait had. Of course, the promptness of the United Nations action denied that booty to the robbers.

It is interesting to reflect that, just before the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, Iraq gave undertakings to Egypt and Saudi Arabia that it would not invade or use force against Kuwait when it was arguing about the payment of reparations for the debt that it had engendered through the terrible eight years of the Iraq-Iran war. Yet, within a few days of giving those undertakings-to be precise, at 2 a.m. on 2 August-the Republican Guard regiments surged across the border. Hopefully, those Republican Guard regiments are fewer in number as a consequence of the United Nations action tonight, but since then Iraq has stayed in occupation.

As other speakers have said, this is an absolutely clear and unambiguous case of the use of force to seize another sovereign country. What we have here is the international law in respect of sovereignty challenged, and challenged by people who simply cannot be described as anything other than a criminal gang. They are murderers and they are looters. They are not driven by a political ideology; they are not driven out of necessity to do this; they are purely a criminal bunch on the international stage.

There is a basic morality in life, and there is a basic morality in international affairs. There is right and there is wrong. Nations have the right to live in peace, free from aggression from marauding neighbours. It is very hard to set up a rule of international law. There can never be a stage where international law is as complex or as detailed as the law within nations, because the styles vary so much. But there is universal agreement around the world on the sanctity of properly constituted boundaries of land. There is no dispute that nations have a right to the territory that is legally within their boundaries.

If one agrees with the proposition that there is a right to have a rule of international law dealing with sovereignty, then one has to agree that there has to be a means of enforcement. Just as every country has its internal laws and a police force to apply those laws, so we have to have a means of applying the basic international law in the international arena. Sadly, the only way that can be done is the same way that it is done in the ultimate case within nations-through a police force. In this case, it is through the application of military power.

It was because of the universal recognition of the rule for international law that, out of the terrible turmoil of the Second World War and the millions of dead and the destruction that took place then, the nations of the world came together and said, `There has to be a better way. There has to be a way we can preserve peace and stability between nations'.

One of the most moving experiences I have ever had was when I was at the United Nations as a parliamentary observer in 1983. General Carlos P. Romulo, the Philippines Foreign Minister, spoke at one afternoon session at a meeting of one of the committees of the United Nations. He talked about the ideals which led the founders to found the United Nations. He was then in his eighties. He is dead now. He was the last living member of those signatories of the United Nations charters. His exposition of the ideals as to how they sought a system to prevent the outbreak of war was one of the most moving experiences I have sat through.

Since 1945 we have seen the United Nations paralysed by the great polarity between the east, in the form of the Soviet Union, and the western liberal democratic nations. It is only recently, in the last two years, that that has changed. This is why the last speaker was so erroneous in drawing comparisons between what happened in Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Afghanistan, where the powers of the United Nations were circumscribed and, in fact, paralysed by the polarity between the East and the Western bloc. That has all gone. After many false dawns, we now have the opportunity, in the United Nations, to provide a system of enforcing international law with respect to the sovereignty of individual nations. That will go an enormous way down the path of guaranteeing the peace that we want. That is why it is so important that Australia-the Australian Parliament and the Australian people-gets behind the United Nations to the very limit of its resources on this occasion.

However much we dislike war, as I said before, if one agrees with international law one has to have a system of enforcing that international law. That means that however unpleasant it might be, one has to be adult enough to recognise that peace has a price. We are paying that price at present in taking a military position vis-a-vis the invading forces of the Iraqis in Kuwait. I look forward to the United Nations being supported on this issue. That will bring with it the prospect of peace for generations ahead with an opportunity for success that we have not seen for thousands of years. Even though the price will be quite high in lives and in monetary terms, it is a low price to pay in the long haul.

There is another very important point in supporting the United Nations on this issue, and that is the growth of the democratic movement around the world. It has not been noticed; it has not been commented on. Just look at what has happened to the old democratic systems of the western liberal democracies-western Europe, the United States, and the old countries of the British Commonwealth, joined after the war by Japan and India. India, the second most populous country in the world, is also the largest democracy. In the mid-1970s Spain, Portugal and Greece took significant steps down the road towards democratic government. We have seen changes in Latin America: Peru, Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay and Paraguay, even Chile and Nicaragua, have all moved away from or abandoned military and/or authoritative governments. In Asia, we are seeing changes in South Korea, Taiwan and the Philippines.

The greatest change of all has taken place in the Soviet Union. The Russian Parliament, under Yeltsin, is moving very strongly on a purely democratic path. It is true that there have been enormous reversals such as in Tiananmen Square, which was a very great blow to the democratic movement in China. What we have seen in the last few weeks in the Baltic states, where the Soviets have moved to crush the independence of the democratic movements, is really quite tragic. But they are temporary reversals in the onward march towards democratic systems. If we can have a rule of law established by the United Nations, the growth of democratic systems around the world will do far more towards generating peace than all the waving of banners and talking about blood for oil that the mindless empty heads are talking about at present.

The trouble with the democratic movement in the past was that there were too few countries. We have now gone past the critical mass and it is a spreading worldwide movement. If we can get that, supported by an international rule of law, we can look forward to a great deal of peace and stability. Liberal democracies do not declare war on other liberal democracies. It is no exaggeration to say that if Kuwait and Iraq were modern democratic states we would not be here today debating this issue.

At this point I would like to convey my unqualified support and the unqualified support of all the members on this side of the chamber for those service men and women in the Australian Defence Force on exchange postings who are doing such a marvellous job for the country in the Gulf region-the ships' companies of the Royal Australian Navy and the medical teams. I take great pride in the way in which they are discharging their duties. But tribute also has to be paid to those from other nations for the courage, professionalism and skill they have shown.

On the subject of skill and professionalism, it is worth commenting on the loss rates of the aircrews engaged so far. Looking at tonight's news, it seems that probably 20 aircraft have been lost. With a sortie rate of about 2,000 operations a day-and by now in excess of 10,000 operations have been flown-it is an incredibly low loss rate that we have suffered. It is something like one in 500 sorties-it is a very low figure. If we look at the loss rates in the air war during the Second World War we see that by this stage we would probably have lost, with the number of aircraft committed, somewhere in excess of 600.

The other extraordinary thing about the skill of the crews involved has been the absolute minimum collateral damage. We have all seen pictures on the television of the incredible precision with which ordnance has been delivered on the targets. What is not generally appreciated is that some of those crews that have been killed have paid a price for that precision with their lives. They could well have delivered that ordnance at a greater distance at a risk of a higher inaccuracy had they chosen to put their own safety first, but they put the lives of innocent civilians before their own. We are all very grateful that they made that sacrifice.

When we start in a situation such as this we never know how long it will take. I believe it will be a short operation. When I say short, I think it is measurable in terms of months. It is important that the community is held together and supports what is the correct and only decision. The primary responsibility for that is the Government's.

I now turn to the Australian Government's action in this debate. As I said at the outset, the Government has been correct in everything that it has done. But I want to go on to qualify that. This is the most serious of situations that the Government can be involved in and it must be supported by the community. But while the decision has been correct, it is not open to the Government to take the line that it should do the barest minimum in supporting the decision. If it believes in the decision, it should support it to the limits of its resources.

As an aside, after listening to the previous speaker in this debate, who talked about the need to bring the matter before Parliament, it is quite obvious that the Australian Democrats never understand the Westminster parliamentary system. Decisions in relation to foreign affairs and defence matters are matters for the Executive Government. The Executive is answerable to Parliament in turn. But these motions do not originate on the floor of the Parliament itself.

While I am on the subject of legal confusion, I draw attention to the fact that at times the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) seems to think that he is the President of the United States. During some of his press conferences in the last week he talked about instructing the services what they will do and what they will not do. I am pleased to say that the Prime Minister is not the Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Force; the Governor-General is. If he has a view, he should convey it to the Commander-in-Chief as a request; not issue a dictate from the rostrum when he is doing a television interview.

The Government's problems are of its own making. Its first problem arises from the fact that it has abandoned the public rostrum to the loonies, the lefties, the anti-UN group, the appeasers and the pro-Iraqi factions. In a democracy there is no reason to deny these people a voice. But the Government has failed-and it has been at this task for seven months; it should have known what was ahead because it was clearly foreseeable-in that it has not got out and argued the correctness of its action. It abandoned the stage; it left it to its opponents. It did that because it is, of course, paralysed by its left wing; it cannot take the decisions it needs to take in the interests of the nation. The Cabinet had a collective responsibility to argue that it is proper to support a United Nations decision. It did not do it. We saw a few exposures of the Prime Minister reacting to situations but never leading and never dominating the public debate the way he should have. There should have been a coordinated campaign outlining the importance of Australia supporting the United Nations on this issue for the benefit of us and of all mankind in the future, and it was not done.

Secondly, the Government failed in closing off future options. The Government claims to have moved from a position of high principle, and that is true. Well, if that is true, one does not limit the support. The Government made a minimal contribution of two small warships. If the decision was correct, it needs to be supported, but again the Government was paralysed by the left wing. The Prime Minister was blackmailed into the position where he said, `We cannot make any more contributions.' I put it to the Senate that there may well have been value in Australia having made a greater contribution. One of our assets is the reconnaissance F111s of No. 6 Squadron. They have certain photographic capabilities. Had those aircraft been deployed to the Gulf, it may well have been-although one cannot prove it-that they would have found some of the mobile Scud sites and may well have kept Israel free from being raided and may well have kept Israel, if it chooses to do so, from taking an active part in hostilities.

The Government paid the minimal price to be a part of the UN team. It is also fair to point out that the naval commitment is the least risk. Certainly there is a risk associated with being in any theatre of operations when hostilities are on, but there is a lower risk with a naval force than there is with a force on the ground or with an air component. One of the other questions in relation to this that the Government needs to answer is why the United States did not request the Government, in the face of the minimal contribution we made, for more support.

The Canadians had made quite a considerable commitment; they were approached and in the week before the deadline on 15 January they committed more CF18 aircraft to the theatre of operations. The United Kingdom, which had made a very heavy contribution-putting the 7th Armoured Brigade in, plus a number of naval units and three or four Royal Air Force squadrons-heavily added to its commitment again in the weeks beforehand. I wonder why the Australian Government was not approached by the US Government for an increase in its contribution.

I said this is purely because the Government is a prisoner of the Left. One of the important secondary effects of the Left's control over the Government has been the complete run-down of Australia's defence capabilities. One of the great revelations to the general public of the present situation is how inadequate Australia is in a defence role. Out of the whole Royal Australian Navy we can put four ships into a hostile area and only then after probably $20m or $30m has been spent in a rush on close-in weapons systems and on communications and navigation systems. Four ships in the entire Australian Navy are safe and competent to operate in a theatre of operations.

What do we have in the Australian Army? The sad truth is that the proud Australian Army does not have one unit it can put into a conventional land battle. It has a very highly trained unit in 3 Brigade in Townsville, but that is not trained for conventional warfare; it is trained for light-scale warfare. We are wholly unable to put any of the 30,000 or 32,000 members of the Australian Army into a situation of conventional warfare in a combat role.

The Royal Australian Air Force is a bit better off, but again it is very short. It has a strike capability; it has an air superiority capability; it has a reconnaissance ability; and it has a broader range of capabilities ready-to-go than the other two services, but it lacks the essential intelligence gathering capability of an airborne warning and control system (AWACS) component. This has all come about because the public has been fed a diet of `No threat; 10-year warning time; time to prepare in an emergency; continental defence; low scale insurgencies' and all the rest of it-all things designed to justify a very low expenditure on defence. It may be a very salutary lesson for the people of Australia that we are really in a very poor state in respect of our own defences. I hope the Government recognises the inadequacy of the position we are in and does something about it.

I would like to devote a few minutes to the protest movement. The first cab off the rank is the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). I opened the Australian this morning and found a whining letter by Mr David Hill, who was complaining about somebody saying unkind things about the ABC. I always thought the ABC through this was the public relations agent for the pacifists' groups. I watched the news in Brisbane at 1.00 a.m. on Saturday and the lead story on the ABC was how 64 Israeli aircraft had been positioned in Saudi Arabia. This was despite the fact that all the other stations had been running a story disproving this report and had been running it for three or four hours; some of the other channels even had Henry Kissinger denying it. However, the ABC with its meticulous research into the situation ran it as the lead story; it was very prejudicial.

The second story was how the protest groups were taking over Australia and were out on the streets in droves. I forget what the third story was but it was something about loss rates, which again put an unfortunate construction on the Gulf operation. The fourth story-surprise, surprise-was how the protest movement was taking over all around the world.

It was hardly balanced reporting. I did an interview on one of the ABC programs on Monday morning last week; on Tuesday afternoon an irate taxpayer rang and said, `Look, I listen to the ABC all the time. You led the story with an interview at 9.00 o'clock Monday morning in Brisbane on the Rod Henshaw program; since then there have been nine experts and all nine have been totally opposed to Australia's involvement in the Gulf. Where is the balance?' I suggest Mr Hill ought to look at some of the programs that his ABC has been running. I do not know whose letter it was that initiated Mr Hill's response, but on the evidence presented to me I think it is fully justified.

Now I will deal with the protest movement itself. The sad thing about it is that all the old Vietnam professionals of 25 years ago have been recycled. They are all desperately seeking a re-run of their past. They have a small group of people like the ones we had in the gallery this afternoon, who are the failures of the education system of this country-or the failures of the teaching profession-having been brainwashed by elderly Vietnam protesters. They are all running the same old argument; we have heard it all before.

According to them, we are the lackeys of America and the agents of the multinationals. The really worrying thing about it is not the immaturity, illogicality and irrationality of the argument, but its sheer racial bias. The argument quite bluntly is anti-American and anti-semitic. One sees these people on television; they are absolutely quivering; they cannot get the venom out about America or about Israel and the duplicity of the multinationals of those countries. It is a blatant, nasty, racial argument.

However, the Gulf is not Vietnam. It is totally different; it is a different place geographically and these are totally different circumstances. What are the arguments of the pacifists? Firstly, that it is a border dispute of long standing. That is not true; it is not true that the borders are suspect in any way at all. They would stand up before any international court of law. I have dealt with the comparisons with Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Afghanistan; they are quite false.

The analogies with Timor, Grenada and Panama are not true. I do not have time to go through them tonight, but I was in New York at the time of the Grenada uprising. I remember waking up, turning on the television set and seeing the Columbia Broadcasting System, the American Broadcasting Corporation and the National Broadcasting Company wheeling up an unbroken procession of experts saying that what had happened there was totally wrong and that Reagan had gone mad, insane. By 10.00 o'clock that night the C130s were landing in Atlanta and other southern American cities. Students in their hundreds were pouring off the planes, kissing the servicemen, kissing the ground and talking straight to the television cameras and saying thank God they had got out. The American Marines and the Army had got them out. The truth of the situation in Grenada was that its Prime Minister had been murdered and its Government had been seized by a rebel bunch. American lives were in danger and as soon as the American citizens were extracted, the Americans left.

The other proposition that the pacifist groups are running is that we try some diplomacy. Senator Gareth Evans dealt with that, the Secretary-General of the United Nations dealt with it and Mr Woolcott, the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade dealt with it. The other thing we are told is to give Iraq time; give peace a chance to work.

If I am a mass murderer, having killed one million people, I cannot plead for time-for 12 months, 18 months or two years-while I make up my mind whether I will recant and comply with the law. There is a need for action now. People are dying. We cannot argue; we cannot talk. If we could stop wars by talking, we would never have had wars in history because there are always people who are loquacious. There are always the Senator Vallentines of this world who will talk the leg off an iron pot. But that is not what happens in the world. A time is reached where something has to be done. The point of the protest movement is that they cannot recognise that there is a time when action has to be taken.

The other objectional argument the people in the protest movement have is moral equivalence. They talk about Kuwait being as bad as Iraq. I would not want to live in any of those countries in that region. From a human rights point of view, Kuwait is a model state compared to Iraq. The opponents of the ruling family were not tortured, they were not murdered, the gangs did not rule the streets, and lawlessness did not take place that took place in Iraq. Above all are the double standards of the opponents. There was no protest movement and Senator Vallentine and Senator Powell were not out throwing rocks at the Iraqi Embassy on 3, 4 and 5 August after the invasion of Kuwait. They did not say a word; there were no rallies from them and no crowds in the galleries. Why do they not go with the followers of the movement and live in the deserts of Saudi Arabia on the border. No, it is too risky for them.

The final worrying thing about the protest movement is that there is every sign that those service men and women who serve in the Gulf will be vilified and persecuted the way the Vietnam veterans were. There are two reports in the press indicating that people who turned out to support the Australian involvement in the Gulf have been physically attacked by the pacifist movement.

What we are involved in is not uncontrolled blood lust as the pacifists would have us believe. It is not greed; it is not support for the multinationals-the better half of human nature is involved here. It is our love of justice, our love of freedom, our belief in the right of countries to live secure within their own borders that leads us to make the self sacrifice on behalf of others to see this operation through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. Supporting the commitment of Australian men and women to war is never easy. It is particularly difficult, I suppose, for those of us with a long history of opposing war and whose political career commenced, in my case, with the opposition to the war in Vietnam. Therefore, it is an action which I have come to support after a great deal of personal examination of the issues not only of the case for the action that has been taken and the consequences of acting in the manner we are, but also of the consequences of failing to act.

SPEECH.PARA: In considering this matter I have looked at the origins of the war and the appropriateness of the response in the light of those origins.

TALK.START.PARA: —Holier than thou.

—I am not trying to disparage other people's motives, but Senator Walters can go for her life, she probably cannot resist. I want to refer to the positive opportunities for a new world order which could emerge from this unfortunate war. I also want to examine the alternatives which have been put forward and, on balance, consider what would constitute justification for military action if these circumstances do not.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say from the outset that I have not been uncritical of the process and the timetable of decision making during the development of this dispute. However, these are side issues which should not divert us from consideration of the primary issues of war and peace.

In one sense the origin of the war is very simple: on 2 August Iraq, under the leadership of Saddam Hussein, invaded Kuwait and ultimately annexed that country as its so-called nineteenth province. It is interesting to ask why the Iraqis now think it is a province of Iraq. Initially there were attempts to set up a puppet government, which seems to me to indicate that they actually thought it was a separate country at the time. When attempts to set up a puppet government failed they then annexed it and declared it the nineteenth province of Iraq and decided that it had always actually been part of Iraq. Although whatever one's version of the history of the relationship of the two countries under the Ottoman empire, it is impossible to find a time when they were both ever part of the same country other than both being part of the Turkish empire.

Much is being said about the ostensible arguments for this invasion. In my view it comes down to two issues-oil and the need of dictatorships for threats, internal or external, to justify the continuing repression of their own people. On the issue of oil, it is clear that Iraq has a dispute with Kuwait over oil wells near the border. I am not in a position to determine the merits of the argument. Even if there were some legitimacy in the Iraqi claims, there is nothing in them that would make war the appropriate avenue for resolution of the conflict. Civilised nations know that there are other more appropriate forums.

More fundamentally, I believe that Saddam Hussein needed, as all dictators need, a diversion, a justification for the continuation of repression. Dictators always need a constant state of war-civil war, an external or internal threat, real or imagined, to justify their continued repression which keeps them in power. It was this combination of the thirst for oil and the need for a diversion that led to Saddam Hussein's attack upon Iran in 1980 with such awful consequences and to some of the actions which he took against his own people, particularly against the Kurds. He has now attacked two other countries in the region-Kuwait and Israel-without provocation during the past six months.

A massing of the Iraqi troops on the Saudi Arabian border after the invasion of Kuwait left me in no doubt that, unchecked, he would have constituted a very real threat to Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states-if not now, then the next time he needed an excuse to continue his military dictatorship.

Let me now turn to consider the nature of the response. Internationally the response has been remarkably broad and uniform. This has facilitated a unique opportunity for the United Nations (UN) to play the role which its founders hoped it would play at the conclusion of the Second World War. I want to return to the UN and the significance for the UN of these developments shortly.

I think it is particularly significant that the governments of all the democracies are supporting the United Nations sanctions against Iraq. There is scarcely a party which has ever been in government or seriously aspired to government in any democracy which does not support the action being taken to implement resolution 678. It would be mere duplication to reiterate the arguments being put by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others, both in the Senate and elsewhere, as to the underlying reasons for this unanimous support.

Let me quote the views of two outstanding international leaders with long histories of commitment to international peace. Firstly, I refer to Gro Harlem Brundtland, the respected Prime Minister of Norway and the author of the famous Brundtland report. In that report, she said some very important things about the perils of war and the nature of international relationships and their economic and environmental consequences. In this instance, Gro Harlem Brundtland, whose Labour Government in Norway has committed ships to the allied cause, said:

These acts of war could have been avoided if Saddam Hussein had listened to the appeals and warnings from the world community. I deeply deplore that the diplomatic efforts and repeated appeals have yet not been heeded. I sincerely hope that Iraq as soon as possible will realise that the annexation of Kuwait is totally unacceptable and that continued armed confrontation is pointless and destructive.

We hope that what is now happening will be of short duration and that it will be carried out with the least possible loss of life and human suffering. The use of force has been authorised by the UN Security Council and is based on the request from Kuwait in accordance with the right to collective self-defence as set out in the Charter of the United Nations.

There is no enthusiasm for the battle from Prime Minister Brundtland. As Senator Tate said so eloquently earlier today, there is no enthusiasm in Australia. In Prime Minister Brundtland's words, in my own case and in the Government's case, there is merely a grim determination to do that which we do not wish to do, but which we feel needs to be done.

From amongst the hundreds of other international figures that could be quoted, let me also refer to Bettino Craxi, the leader of the Italian Socialist Party, former Prime Minister of Italy, in an outstanding speech to the Italian House of Deputies this month. In that speech, Mr Craxi referred to a conversation he had with Daniel Ortega, the former leader of Nicaragua. On his way back from talks with Saddam Hussein in Baghdad, Ortega told Craxi, `The one word Saddam Hussein intends not uttering is the word ``withdrawal''. Craxi went on to say, `That is the very first word he should utter and should have already uttered'. I think that is one of the core reasons why we have made the transition from sanctions to military action-that determination, that evident, apparent repeatedly expressed determination of Saddam Hussein not to withdraw from the country which he has occupied.
While I am quoting Mr Craxi, let me make one other reference to his speech on a matter to which I will subsequently return. That is the situation of the Palestinians. Mr Craxi said:

Iraq did not first invade Kuwait and then declare its annexation in order to place the Palestinian cause once more on the world agenda. Saddam Hussein has not torn asunder the relations of the Arab world, placing himself against most of the nations making up that world in order to help the Palestinian people in their battle.

It was not against Israel that he declared war, but against the Arab state of Kuwait, a member of the Arab League, an upholder of the Palestinian cause, a country that hosted hundreds and thousands of immigrant Palestinian workers.

I want to come back to the Palestinian issue subsequently. I think that is a very accurate, eloquent and important statement by former Prime Minister Craxi and it pricks the bubble of one of the important myths about this debate. Much has been said during the debate in the Parliament and elsewhere about the positive possibilities of what is called a new world order. I think the significance of this should not be underestimated or disparaged. Some people tend to find that perhaps the phrase is a bit too grand but the idea underlying it is fundamentally important.

At the end of the Cold War we have for the first time in living memory, perhaps the first time ever, the opportunity to develop an international community in which the United Nations plays the predominant role in resolving international disputes in accordance with the rule of law. If on this first occasion when the United Nations seeks to enforce its authority in this way it should fail, it will be reduced to the status of the League of Nations-capable of carrying pious resolutions with which all people of good will concur; but which dictators and aggressors can ignore with impunity.

The consequences of failure for the United Nations in this instance are too awful to contemplate. Even those who might have preferred that the attempts to enforce resolution 678 had never been started should reconsider their opposition to its continuation on an analysis of the consequences of failure and on an analysis of the consequences of withdrawing now. The issue is more complex than simply whether one would have preferred the option which is now being undertaken.

I supported the decision to undertake it then and I am not equivocating on that. But I say to many people of good will who, on the basis of their consideration, came to the view that the United Nations through these 28 nations should not have taken that action, that even if that is their view, they should contemplate the consequences of the United Nations now failing to enforce its decision having once attempted to do so. That is the end of the possibility of the United Nations playing any such role in any dispute internationally. Its credibility will be finished. It will return to being an organisation capable of pious exhortation and sometimes playing a useful role in bringing together the parties once they have decided they wish to conclude hostilities.

But the role it has the capacity to play importantly in many disputes around the world at the moment, most particularly in our region in Cambodia, and the new role it has shown the capacity to take in resolving issues such as those which are now confronting the world in the Gulf, will be irreparably damaged if, having now started upon this course of attempting to enforce resolution 678, it were to fail.

Another issue which flows from this question and the so-called new world order is the issue of the rights of displaced people in the Middle East, in particular the Palestinians and the Kurds. I have to say that the Kurds tend not to get much attention in this particular matter. A lot of people pay attention to the displaced Palestinians because Saddam Hussein is trying to make them an issue and because they have a legitimate grievance. I have not actually heard Saddam Hussein saying that he is also in the process of trying to find a homeland for the Kurdish people. The only land he gave them in Iraq is that under which they are buried. He has been brutal in repressing those people.

If the new world order to which so many have referred can be achieved and the role of the United Nations can be significantly enhanced, then these displaced people have their best ever opportunity to have their claims considered and justice prevail. Their position will not be resolved if we, by failing to act, enhance the status of aggressors. Their problems are the result of aggression. It is action to resist and overturn the consequences of aggression that is necessary to assist these people to achieve just resolution of their concerns.

It is only through enhancing the status of a body such as the United Nations and saying that people will not gain the fruits of their aggression that the opportunities to resolve those issues will be enhanced. This is the fundamental responsibility for us all after the war is over. Those who oppose our military commitment other than those few who might support the Iraqi position-there are none in this Parliament and very few in this country-advocate the continuation of sanctions. Others have mounted the argument to explain why these sanctions were not working and almost assuredly would not have worked. Let me say, before somebody picks up and uses this magic statistic that 97 per cent of exports were being stopped and that proves that sanctions were working, that it proves only that sanctions were working in stopping exports. It does not prove in any way that they were working in changing the intention of the Government of Iraq.

Bettino Craxi-on the basis of advice from a supporter of Saddam Hussein, Daniel Ortega, who went to supportHussein and came away saying that the one word he will not utter is `withdrawal'-has established as clearly and unequivocally as he could that sanctions were not working in the sense of achieving their desired objective. Sanctions are not an end in themselves. They are designed to be a means to achieve a desired end and they were not working in that sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were not stopping a lot of essential imports as opposed to exports, also.

—That is probably a valid additional point. I want to refer to one other aspect about this issue of saying that we should not be taking military action; we should be allowing sanctions to work; we should be giving them more time. That sounds like the ultimate in sweet reason from the luxurious distance of Australia. It might mean peace for Australians. There would be no Australians committed although probably they would be there enforcing the sanctions. I want to come back to that point in a moment. But it assuredly would not mean peace for Kuwait and the citizens of various nationalities living in Kuwait.

SPEECH.PARA: The catalogue of atrocities outlined by Amnesty International on 19 December is too horrible to repeat here. It was very eloquently outlined in some part by my colleague Senator Tate but suffice it to say that it runs to some 80 pages of detailed documentation on atrocities committed during the first four months of occupation. These are only those which Amnesty can document with its usual level of concern for its reputation.

Months and years of relying on sanctions means months and years of condemning the people of Kuwait to extrajudicial executions, which Amnesty International records in the hundreds; so-called judicial executions, after some sort of trial, by firing squad; and numerous rapes and other atrocities that are the inevitable consequences of an occupational army of half a million in a small country. It means saying, `Let us have sanctions for the months and years it takes'; it means the continuation of the 38 different types of torture documented by Amnesty International being undertaken by Iraq against the people in Kuwait. It is not an advocacy of peace to say, `We have sanctions'; it is an advocacy to say, `Let the Kuwaiti people pay the price, not us'. In addition, these sanctions can succeed only by condemning the ordinary people of Iraq to deprivation and starvation. I assume that nobody believes the first person to go without food in Iraq is going to be Saddam Hussein or that the first cut in government expenditure in Iraq is going to be military expenditure.

It is ironic also to note that those who now advocate the benefits of sanctions are the very people who opposed the original decision to seek to enforce those sanctions. I spoke at a meeting here at which people were saying that we should not have ships in the Gulf enforcing the sanctions. I spoke on behalf of the Government as to why I thought we should. I do not wish to criticise all of the people at that meeting; many were people of goodwill and consistency. But many of the people at that meeting who attacked my position and said that we should not have ships there enforcing the sanctions are now saying that we should give the sanctions more time to work and that sanctions are the answer, as though they had always thought sanctions were a wonderful thing to have. There is no more important debate than the debate about war and peace. In this very important debate we are entitled to demand consistency.

Obviously any normal person would prefer peace to war, but `peace is more than the mere absence of war', to quote someone slightly more famous than I. We need to look at what we mean by peace when we make those sorts of demands. The comments which I made about the people in Kuwait are designed to illustrate that peace is more than the mere absence of war. It is a state beyond merely refraining from taking military action.

But even in terms of that very familiar phrase about giving peace a chance-a song which I sang out of tune many times during the Vietnam conflict-I have to say that the world through the United Nations, the Arab League, the European Community and the individual attempts by countless men and women of goodwill has sought for five months a peaceful resolution of the dispute arising from the Iraqi invasion. The lack of success of these efforts is entirely attributable to Saddam Hussein and the attitude so accurately described by Daniel Ortega and quoted by Bettino Craxi.

Whatever our reservations about the previous regime in Kuwait, and in my case they are many, it is fundamental to the future of a peaceful international world order that aggression is resisted. The consequences of saying that an invasion of one country by another and an occupation of one country by another are legitimised by the fact that we disapprove of the system of government of the adjoining country is an invitation to international aggression, to regional conflicts throughout the world, and to the proliferation of those regional conflicts. That is one of the risks we face as the old, awful stability of the bipolar Cold War breaks down, which we welcome-but it is a not unqualified blessing because it opens the possibility of regional conflict. We need a system effectively to manage that regional conflict, and the United Nations and its enhancement is the only mechanism.

To continue reference to some of the tragic ironies we confront, it is ironic that that it is the democracies which are defending the al-Sabah regime. There are a few that are not so democratic as well, I hasten to comment, but it is fundamentally the democracies of the world committing their people and resources to defend a regime that is far from democratic. I accept Senator MacGibbon's point that it is more respectful of human rights than the country which has invaded and occupied it, but it is far from a model of democracy also. I note and welcome indications of intentions to review the system of government after the war. It is entirely appropriate that the people in the democracies should get in return for the very significant personal contributions they are making some democratic reform in Kuwait. It is another issue which must be a priority after the war, but it is not a precondition for saying that we will resist aggression only if we like the government against which the aggression has been undertaken.

Let me conclude my comments on this difficult decision with the following points: if this military action is not justified in the circumstances of blatant aggression by a powerful nation against its neighbour, resulting in its occupation, when the response is authorised by the United Nations and has the overwhelming support of the world community of nations, what circumstances would justify military action? If this military action against a country which continues to commit atrocities against the citizens of the country which it is occupying, where strenuous efforts for peace have been pursued at multinational and bilateral level, where a five months pause has been allowed to try to achieve a peaceful solution-all of which have been rebuffed, and the Secretary General of the United Nations rebuffed in a humiliating manner-is not justified after this time, in what circumstances is it justified?

I accept that some people take a pacifist position which says that military action can never be justified. That is a position which at one stage of my life I held myself, so I am the last to condemn it. It is not my view now. I accept that. It is a minority view, but a legitimate view. But once one passes that point and accepts that it is possible to accept the concept of a just war, if this is not such a struggle, what criteria would one set beyond those existing in this circumstance to justify such a dispute?

It has not been an easy decision, but I, like everybody else in this chamber-at least in the Government and the Opposition-accept the responsibility that being in government imposes to accept the consequences of actions or failure to act.

Democratic governments around the world have taken the same decision that we are proposing to endorse here in this debate. They have not taken it lightly but rather because they accept that the consequences of the United Nations failing in its attempt to enforce its decisions are too awful to contemplate, and because the hopes of the world for a new world order flowing from the end of the Cold War depend upon the capacity of the world community, through the United Nations, effectively to resist aggression wherever it occurs. Therefore, I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin, I hope that while I am speaking some copies of my amendment will be circulated to other senators. First, I think it is appropriate to say that I appreciate-as others have said-the sincerity with which everybody has spoken in this debate. While we disagree with the position taken by the Government and the Opposition, nonetheless many of the speakers from the other parties have clearly spoken from a sense of deep conviction that what they believe to be in the best interests of world peace is indeed in the best interests of world peace. We happen to believe, from a very strong conviction, that that position in some respects is wrong, as several of my party predecessors have outlined, and we believe that a different course of action is more desirable.

SPEECH.PARA: I will pick up later some of the points which have been made by other speakers, but I want to make several points in beginning. Firstly, the Australian Democrats unreservedly reject any claim by Iraq to Kuwait, and totally oppose the use of force by Iraq in the annexation of Kuwait. We are not in any sense in this debate or in public utterances or rallies attempting to give any sense of satisfaction to Saddam Hussein or the Iraqis over what has happened. We totally oppose their action and totally oppose the method of that annexation.

Because several senators have raised this issue, I state that the Australian Dem- ocrats do not in any sense hold the service personnel who are currently in the Gulf region or who may subsequently be in the Gulf region to be in any way responsible in the sense of the actions for which we criticise the Government.

We believe that those people have in all good faith volunteered their services to this country, to the military. They are doing their duty and in no sense should be criticised for that. We note in passing that it was many years before either the present Government or the previous coalition Government overcame their reticence in relation to recognising the service paid by Australian service personnel in Vietnam. There was very little done over a long period to address the social odium that attached to many of the service personnel who came back from that war. That odium should rightly attach to the governments which sent those personnel there-not to the military personnel themselves.

The point of entry for me into this debate is to pick up on a remark made by Senator Newman when she quoted a former Governor-General, Sir William Slim, who said that soldiers who died in war should not have died in vain. Several other speakers have mentioned a new world order. Certainly, those who die in this war will have died in vain unless that new world order is remarkably different from the world order which I think is being presaged by some of the remarks that I have heard this afternoon. If we do not address the very large differences between the rich industrialised countries and the poor resource starved countries we will simply perpetuate the factors which have led to this war and which, indeed, led to the Vietnam war.

Senator Button and several other speakers have attempted to say that there is no parallel between the Vietnam war and this war. There are exact parallels. The Americans and the other people who joined in the Vietnam conflagration were very concerned about the resource rich regions of South East Asia falling into communist hands. That war was very much an attempt to keep access to those resources to the industrialised resource requiring nations of the world.

It is quite clear that the war in this case is about resources. Senator Tate and several other senators have spoken very eloquently about the atrocities which have gone on in Kuwait; atrocities committed at the hands of the Iraqis. There is no doubt that, as they have indicated, a long catalogue of those atrocities has been compiled by many international agencies. But, it is equally true that those sorts of atrocities are by no means unique to Kuwait.

On our own doorstep we have seen the invasion of East Timor by the Indonesians. Some hundreds of thousands of people have died, including babies and premature babies. There has also been torture, rape, pillage and all those things which Senator Tate catalogued. Not only did we not lift a finger to help the people of East Timor but we have actually continued to supply arms to the Indonesian nation. There was no question of sanctions against Indonesia whatsoever.

Senator MacGibbon and others may well argue that there are niceties of international law which separate the situation in both positions-that of East Timor and that of Kuwait-and certainly there are. Senator Tate's argument was very much a moral one. But, surely, if the argument is about morality-about people losing the ability to self-determine their governments; about people being raped; about people being murdered; and about people being summarily executed-morally there is no distinction to be drawn between East Timor and between the situation in Kuwait today. Yet we and the world have done nothing in that situation. And that situation has multiplied a number of times over around the world.

So one must look for another explanation as to why we are so concerned about the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and, of course, that explanation is not very hard to find. It is indeed access to oil. It is indeed the concern that the West, which is heavily dependent upon fossil fuel use, may lose its ability to extract at very low cost the resources in the Middle East. That is what distinguishes this conflict from many others in the past. So the slogan `No blood for oil' is not without very considerable foundation, because that really is the issue.

I would also say to Senator Tate that the cost of the build-up to this war in 1990 to the Americans was $30 billion-that is, $30,000m-and that thousands of children are dying every day from malnutrition, from dehydration and from diseases which can be readily cured. I just pose the question: if we are really about saving the lives of children, would it not be better to spend $30 billion directly addressing those problems? If we did, we could save far more children and far more lives and provide far more health care and far more education for the world's poor and disadvantaged.

It seems to me that the argument which Senator Tate raised, whilst very appealing, falls quite simply on the grounds of its inconsistency-its inconsistency with the enormous costs of the war; its inconsistency with the failure to act in many other situations; and its inconsistency with its cost in terms of lives which inevitably will be paid as the war is prosecuted.

As I say, if we are to learn from this episode-as I hope we will because it is important that we look ahead-we need to look closely at what has led us into this war and how we should behave as we come out of it. I am reminded of a speech by then Mr Winston Churchill, later Sir Winston Churchill, when he said:

When the situation was manageable it was neglected and, now that it is thoroughly out of hand, we apply too late the remedies which then might have effected a cure. There is nothing new in the story. It's as old as the Sibylline books. It falls into the long dismal catalogue of the fruitlessness of experience and the confirmed unteachability of mankind . . .

Want of foresight, unwillingness to act when action would be simple and effective; lack of clear thinking; confusion of counsel until the emergency comes, until self-preservation strikes its jarring gong. These are the features which constitute the endless repetition of history.

Sir Winston Churchill made that speech in 1934 about the situation in the Middle East. If we do not learn that the precursors to this situation lie in the way in which the world has mismanaged its resource use and do something about that, as I said in one of my speeches on this subject back in August, we are in for endlessly repeating these sorts of resource conflicts. I have said on a number of occasions, and I think it is quite clear from the evidence now coming forward, that we need drastically to reduce our use of fossil fuels.

With the first oil price shocks of the early 1970s, I recall in 1972 writing to Mr Doug Anthony, who was then the Minister responsible, pointing out the need to address this question and to reduce substantially Australia's dependence upon the importation of foreign oil as well as cutting down its use of a non-renewable resource and reducing the release of greenhouse gases and other pollutants. Successive governments have taken no action. Had action been taken to address that problem, we would not be so dependent upon that particular resource and the situation may well have looked very different.

So the new economic order which has been talked about must not be simply the continued dominance of the industrially rich, advanced countries at the expense of an increasingly impoverished resource-poor world. If that is the new economic order that comes out of this, and I very much fear that that is at the backs of the minds of many people who have spoken this afternoon, we will indeed see a continuation of these sorts of resource wars. If, on the other hand, we directly address the problems of the differences between rich and poor nations and attempt to redress that imbalance; if we attempt, on the part of nations like Australia, the United States and the nations of Europe, to reduce substantially our use of resources and the impact on the environment and to reduce substantially the burden of debt of Third World countries, indeed, we may enter a new economic order. I think we need to keep that clearly in mind as we go forward in this conflict because we will at some stage come out the other side of it and something must be put in its place.

Our position, quite simply, is that it was not necessary at the time when, shortly after 15 January, active war was engaged upon. Our position is that while United Nations resolution 678 allowed the use of force, it did not mandate the use of force. Many people, Senator Evans included, as Senator Powell pointed out this afternoon, were well aware that it was essential to maintain sanctions for a much longer period for them to have become effective. That is not appeasement. To those who on other occasions have interjected, `How about South Africa?' I point out that this is the first occasion in world history when sanctions have been universally applied by all countries and have been very, very tightly maintained. Sanctions were not tightly maintained against South Africa, and it is not a reasonable comparison.

The figures have been mentioned before. Sanctions were some 97 per cent effective in terms of exports, and they were certainly very effective in terms of imports. As for the assertion which has been repeated by several honourable senators that if we allow more time Hussein may well have built up his arsenal of weapons, I simply pose the question of where he builds that arsenal from if he is cut off from imports. That really does not make sense. That is a non sequitur.

Andrew Mack, writing in the Australian Financial Review of 14 January, pointed out that the oil blockade alone has denied Hussein 97 per cent of his export revenues, and the ban on imports of spare parts poses a grave threat to the viability of Iraq's industrial infrastructure. It is quite true, as Senator McMullan said before me, that possibly the last equipment not to be serviced with spare parts would be the military machine, but most of Iraq's military equipment has come from other countries. That, of course, is another aspect of the new world economic order which must change.

Criticism has been made of the Democrats and also of the peace movement. Where were we when Iraq invaded? I pose the counterquestion: where have the Opposition and the Government been when we have called for Australia not to supply uranium to France, a nation which has not signed the non-proliferation treaty and a nation which was building the nuclear facility in Iraq? Where were the Government and the Opposition then? They are terrified now that Hussein might have access to nuclear weapons. Where were they when we were supplying uranium to Germany? Germany, just before the outbreak of the Iraq-Iran conflict, was supplying six nuclear reactors to Iran and, what is more, building a reprocessing plant so that Iran would have access to plutonium for the manufacture of bombs. Fortunately, in retrospect, that Iraq-Iran war ended that.

Where was the Opposition when Saddam Hussein was using poison gas against the Kurdish people and a number of nations around the world were supplying Hussein with the precursors of that poison gas? Were they objecting to that? The fact that Hussein is a dangerous madman, an extremely repressive person with respect to his own people, a person who is prepared to march into another country, and who has behaved in that irresponsible way, has been quite obvious for years. Yet nations on our side of the global political scheme have been quite prepared to supply all the makings for Hussein's war machine and for his poison gas and to allow him to get on with the extermination of the Kurdish people and to invade Kuwait. Now we throw up our hands in horror and say, `My, my, isn't that terrible? Isn't he a bad person?'. Where were we when this was going on? We were calling for countries of the world not to be engaged in the transport of military equipment from one country to another, and that has been our consistent position for a very long time. That has to be part of the new economic order if the world is going to enter a safer period after this is over.

Several speakers have said that there must be no connection between the invasion of Kuwait and the Israel-Palestine conflict, yet those same speakers and, indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself have said that when this conflict is over we must address the situation in Palestine. Where have they been for the last two decades? Why have they not been addressing that problem? Why have they not been putting some pressure on Israel? It is absolutely remarkable that the situation we are now in is going to make a resolution of that problem more difficult simply because the attacks on Israel have now made it almost inevitable that the West will have to do deals with Israel and they will have to sweeten Israel to keep it out of the war and make a resolution of that conflict even more difficult. So, far from helping to resolve that conflict, the way we have gone is to make that conflict less resolvable.

We do not know that the imposition of sanctions for a longer period would have caused Hussein to withdraw. It may have been that the imposition of sanctions for a further three or four months may have led Hussein to begin a war himself, and we would inevitably have been in a conflict situation. But at least, given the first occasion on which the world community has applied sanctions as a peaceful means of conflict resolution against another nation, we would have given those sanctions a chance to work. That would have been an extremely useful lesson for the world to have learnt. Unfortunately, we have gone backwards and we have resorted to war.
There are a number of other points I would like to make but I think it is appropriate at this stage that I move the amendment. I move:
Omit all words after ``That the Senate:'' substitute:

(a) reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the self-determination of nations, and in particular the resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait by means of sanctions and diplomacy;

(b) affirms its support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in Resolution 661 for support in implementing comprehensive sanctions against Iraq until it leaves Kuwait;

(c) condemns the Australian Government's warlike interpretation of Resolution 678 of the United Nations Security Council, and calls for an immediate ceasefire, and the withdrawal of Australian warships from combat duty, which is consistent with that resolution;

(d) expresses its full confidence in, and support for, Australian forces in the Gulf, and places the burden of responsibility for the misguided decision to deploy them to that region solely on the Federal Government and Opposition;
(e) deplores Iraq's widening of the conflict by its unprovoked attack on Israel; and

(f) recognises the need to intensify non-military efforts to establish peace and stability in the Middle East, including a just resolution of the Palestinian issue and the continuing security of Israel.

The Australian Democrats move this amendment in the light of the statements which senators from our party have already made and which other senators will be making later in this debate. We are rewriting the Government's motion in an attempt to pick up some of the differences between the position as we think it should be and the way in which the Government has worded its motion.

We feel that, given the gravity of the situation, the Government's motion is extremely light. We understand from press reports-and there is no reason to doubt them in this case-that the motion was weakened somewhat to satisfy certain factions within the Australian Labor Party. We would like to see the motion strengthened and the emphasis returned to sanctions and the application of those sanctions for a longer period. Page 2 of the document circulated to honourable senators explains the changes which we seek to make. It is, as it were, an explanatory memorandum. At the end of the first paragraph we seek to add the words `by means of sanctions and diplomacy'. Therefore, the paragraph would read:

. reaffirms its support for an on-going role for the United Nations in promoting world peace and the safe-determination of nations and in particular the Resolutions of the Security Council directed to end the aggression of Iraq against Kuwait by means of sanctions and diplomacy.
We believe that is the appropriate way to go until those options have clearly been shown not to work. We believe that all the indications are that they would work.

In the second paragraph, which is split into two, we want to pick up another United Nations resolution-that is, we want to affirm our support for Australia's positive response to the request made by the United Nations Security Council in resolution 661 for support in implementing comprehensive sanctions against Iraq until it leaves Kuwait. I feel that that should not receive any objection by honourable senators who have strongly endorsed Australia's support for the United Nations. The existing second paragraph would be substituted-and I guess this is the kernel of what we are saying-for the following paragraph:

. condemns the Australian Government's warlike interpretation of Resolution 678 of the United Nations Security Council, and calls for an immediate ceasefire and the withdrawal of Australian warships from combat duty, which is consistent with that resolution.

What we are saying is that, while resolution 678 allowed any means which were appropriate, that resolution did not mandate the use of force, nor did it set a time limit on the resolution. I think it was Senator Tate who pointed to the despondent nature of the Secretary General of the United Nations after his last bid at a resolution in meeting with Hussein. I suspect that his despondency was, as much as anything, not due to the failure of the immediately concluded attempts to find some reconciliation with Hussein but rather to the fact that, knowing the build-up of forces which had gone on in Saudi Arabia and the ships in the Gulf, he realised that that failure meant the imminent outbreak of war. I think that quite a different interpretation of his appearance on television can be put on that. We feel it is quite consistent with support for resolution 678 to continue with sanctions but at this stage not to continue with active warfare.

In the third paragraph we would like to see the words `serving with the UN-sanctioned multi-national forces' deleted because we believe there is a euphemistic terminology in that initially the forces were multinational forces and only later were sanctioned by the United Nations. It is misleading to suppose that right from the beginning they were United Nations forces or that they are under direct United Nations control. They are not. They are under the direct control of the United States on behalf of the implementation of the United Nations resolution.

In the next paragraph we express our full confidence in, and support for, the Australian forces. As I have outlined before, we deplore Iraq's widening of the conflict by its own provoked attack on Israel. Several people, both in this chamber and outside, when speaking on this issue have used the term `innocent civilians'. I find some difficulty with that term because, to the extent that Australia has become involved in this conflict, it is a decision of the Australian Government and it is supported by the Opposition. Both those parties have been selected by the Australian people to make these sorts of decisions. So in an indirect sense the Australian people, individually and collectively, are responsible for the decisions of this Government. In the same way the citizens of Iraq, individually and collectively, are responsible for the actions of their leader in that they are not overthrowing their leader. It is also relevant to point out that many private citizens, particularly in industrialised countries, have been the ones who have provided the wherewithal for Iraq's military machine.
In the final paragraph we want to include the words `non-military' after `the need to intensify'. Again, that stresses the need for sanctions rather than military intervention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —War was declared by Iraq on 2 August-5 1/2 months ago-when Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait in a vicious and unprovoked attack, an attack that included the gravest violations of human rights, including rape, torture and executions. It has been the most brutal of occupations-Arab against Arab; very similar indeed to the early Hitler regime of German against German, when there was rape, torture and executions of the German Jews. Being one of the few senators in this place who lived as an adult through most of World War II, I am only too aware of the horrors of the full-blown world war. It is because of this experience that, perhaps more than most, I am totally and utterly opposed to another world war.

SPEECH.PARA: The world has experienced two world wars. Following World War I, the nations of the world grappled with trying to set up a policing system to make sure such world wars would not occur again-to stop any future conflict. And so was born the League of Nations. Its only power was one of moral pressure. Of course, as history tells us, it just did not work. So the League of Nations died a natural death.

When Hitler came to power, Britain was the leader of the democratic countries and had disarmed to an alarming extent, mainly through the Washington Treaty and later through other disarmament treaties and agreements. Because she was so unprepared, appeasement was tried. Mr Chamberlain, the Prime Minister of Britain at the time, tried to negotiate with Hitler, but precious time was lost. Finally, when war was declared, Hitler's armaments were so strong and the allies so weak it took five years and hundreds and thousands of lives before peace was restored.

Following World War II, once again the nations of the world grappled to set in order another policing system, again to stop any further world war. It had been the most horrific of world wars. With that determination the United Nations was born.

It was my dream at the time, and that of the majority of peace loving people of the world, that there never again would be a world war; that the whole of the world could get together, stand behind the United Nations, face any aggressor and say, `Withdraw'. If that aggressor refused to withdraw, then the united nations of the world could force that withdrawal. A few years ago I did not believe that that dream would have been possible in my life time. I was not alone. The majority of people at that time thought it was virtually impossible that there would be a Mr Gorbachev, that the Berlin Wall would come down, that Germany could possibly unite. I could not really imagine that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Great Britain and the United States of America could possibly sit together, negotiate on the same side, and when those negotiations fell through, vote together for the good of the world. Yet this has all happened in such a short time.

I have never felt so euphoric as when the Berlin Wall came down brick by brick, and when, on 29 November, the United Nations Security Council resolution 678 was voted on to give Baghdad `one final opportunity' until 15 January to comply with all previous resolutions. After that date nations allied with Kuwait were authorised `to use all necessary means' to force Iraq to withdraw and honour the resolutions. It was a phrase that all members agreed would permit a military strike.

This has fulfilled my dream that the world would face an aggressor, united; that the world could say to that aggressor, `Withdraw'; and when that nation refused to withdraw then the world could say, `We will force a withdrawal'. Whilst it is so appalling and so sad that Saddam Hussein has refused to withdraw, has treated the world with such contempt and has ignored the United Nations and all the world appeals, it is yet a momentous occasion because it is a new world order. I find it disappointing that those members of the peace movement-and I believe the majority had dreams exactly the same as my own-are not seeing this wonderful dream being fulfilled. I wonder if they realise that the very same peace movement expressed the same sentiments as Great Britain declared war against Hitler? Do they really mean that we should not have tried to stop Hitler massacring those hundreds of thousands of Jews in the gas chambers? Do they really mean we should not stop the butcher of Baghdad murdering and plundering the people of Kuwait?

It has been asked on many occasions: where were they when Saddam Hussein was killing the mothers and babies of Kuwait? Were they outside the Iraqi Embassy? There were no marches then. Where were the dreams of the peace movement, the dreams for world peace? At the moment we have three ships with our brave sailors serving in the Gulf, and we in the Opposition, to quote Dr Hewson, pledge our strongest support to them. Dr Hewson said:
They are acting in the highest traditions of our Services. They deserve the support of all Australians and we deeply hope that they will return safely to their families as soon as possible.

I hope that the peace movement joins me in this pledge of support. Australia must play its part. We cannot say we are too far away. If we believe in world peace, then we have to send the troops that we have been asked to send, and we have complied with that request.

Over 100 nations have called for the withdrawal of Saddam Hussein. Thirty-four nations supported the Security Council resolution, and 28 nations have committed forces in support of the Security Council resolution. Nine of those nations are Arab countries including Egypt, Syria, Saudi Arabia and the Gulf States, as well as Pakistan and Bangladesh. Other countries such as many of the Asian countries, including Japan, are supplying finance. Australia is one of the 28 countries committing forces. It has supported the resolution commensurate with our size and importance as a member of the Security Council, and it is important that we send a message to Saddam Hussein from the whole of this Parliament that we support our troops. In their tremendously difficult job this is the very least we can do. We cannot send a message that undermines our Navy. There should be no honourable senator or honourable member in this Parliament who acts as a pawn for Saddam Hussein.

How would our service personnel react to some of the speeches made in this place undermining them? I wonder how their wives and mothers feel when listening to the debate by the Democrats? If I were one of them I would be so angry. I would be very cross. I could imagine no one being so disloyal. America has borne the major brunt of the Democrats' abuse, and yet if it were not for the unbending determination of firstly Ronald Reagan-

The list of nations supporting this action goes on and on. Australia is not supporting the United States all the way with LBJ, as is claimed; it is supporting the United Nations resolution, along with France, Turkey, Italy, Germany, Britain, Saudi Arabia, Canada, Spain, Belgium, Greece, Denmark, Norway, Syria, Egypt, the Netherlands and, yes, the USA, along with Morocco, Pakistan and so many other countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion on the Gulf crisis moved by Senator Button on behalf of the Government this afternoon.
