It is a comprehensive and carefully constructed motion which, in my view and, I believe, in the view of the vast majority of senators, is utterly appropriate in these circumstances of crisis-a crisis which jeopardises international peace and security. It emerged from the ranks of the Labor Government after an exhaustive process of consultation, but it is very pleasing to note the degree of support that has emerged for the proposition from the Opposition parties. That demonstrates a practical application of bipartisanship on this very difficult issue and, in my view, there should be greater bipartisanship on issues of foreign affairs and defence policy. Certainly I would also like to associate my name with those words of support which have come from both sides of the chamber for the men and women of our naval force in the Gulf and the related medical teams.

SPEECH.PARA: My first speech in the Senate was on the Gulf crisis-on the crisis that stemmed from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on 2 August 1990. The first observations that I made in the chamber on the issue remain valid today. Certainly, the observations that were made at that time-not only by me but also by other senators who participated in that debate-concerning the regime of Saddam Hussein are especially appropriate in the light of the circumstances that have developed since.
In the House of Representatives in the United States of America on 12 January this year, Congressman Stephen Solarz said:
The great lesson of our time is that evil still exists, and when evil is on the march, it must be confronted.

In the Persian Gulf, almost half a year after the brutal and unprovoked annexation of Kuwait, the time for patience has ended and the time for firmness has arrived. Saddam Hussein represents a clear and present danger, not only to the region, but to the world.
That is a very clear assessment of the threat existing in the Middle East and beyond, caused by the aggression of the Hussein regime in Iraq.

Many historical analogies have been drawn with the circumstances of the present crisis. Many have been drawn accurately in the debate this afternoon and this evening. It is true that the world stood by when the Japanese military invaded, occupied and then annexed Manchuria in 1931. It is true that the world stood by when Nazi Germany marched into the Rhineland, when fascist Italy invaded Abyssinia, and when Hitler annexed Austria in the Anschluss of 1938 and then absorbed Czechoslovakia into the Third Reich.

But there are also other analogies that are appropriate in the circumstances and ought to be drawn. For it is also true that, in the Spanish Civil War from 1936 to 1939, the fascists for the very first time crushed a working democracy by force of arms. A lesson was very clear that the democracies in Britain, France and the United States (US) could be relied upon to stand by if sufficient force was shown early on. That led directly to the Second World War. It is also particularly appropriate to look at the circumstances of the Baltic states tonight, given that they were absorbed by force of arms into the Soviet Union in 1940. Again, the lessons of history can be drawn by analogy.

I want to make a brief observation or two about the position outlined by the Australian Democrats in the chamber today. I hope that I am not doing the Democrats a disservice when I say that as I listened to the contributions I found their position both uncertain and contradictory.

The argument is for sanctions to be applied-indeed, for sanctions to be given longer to work-but there is no provision for enforcement of the sanctions. At the same time, if we listen to the contributions made by some of the Democrats spokesmen, there is to be no Australian naval presence in the Gulf. Indeed, there is even a question about the presence of a multinational force to apply the sanctions. The Democrats argue-and I have no doubt that they are being utterly sincere-that they are opposed to Saddam Hussein and opposed to the annexation of Kuwait, but how is the international community supposed to demonstrate that opposition? With what resources? With what application? What practical steps can be taken in that circumstance?

Reluctant as we might be to reach the conclusion, United Nations (UN) resolution 678 is the only step left open to the world community. Not only had the process of negotiation under the auspices of the United Nations been exhausted but also the initiatives of the Soviet Union had come to an end-to nought. The French initiative had come to an end-to nought. A total of six United Nations resolutions had been defied by the Iraqi authorities. World opinion was being defied. Saddam clearly was not going to withdraw from Kuwait. The sanctions were not working. There is no doubt about that at all.
I again quote Congressman Solarz from the United States House of Representatives:

Judge Webster, the head of the CIA, does not believe the sanctions will be sufficient to get Iraq out of Kuwait. Nor do the British, nor the French, nor the Egyptians, nor the Saudis. Not one of our coalition partners believes that sanctions will be sufficient to get Iraq out of Kuwait.

When one looks at the circumstances of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait-at the widespread looting-it becomes clear in part why the sanctions could not work, because the looting was directed specifically at replacing some of the resources that had been locked out of Iraq by the quarantine. We should also make mention of the fact that because of the quarantine certain of the poorer states in the Third World were hurting grievously from the increase in oil prices. More directly, and perhaps more significantly as we debate the issue here in the chamber tonight, the Iraqi regime used the time in which the sanctions were in force to strengthen its position militarily in Kuwait itself and on the Saudi-Iraqi border.

It is a practical conclusion to draw that the coalition would not hold indefinitely. It had held remarkably well today and holds well tonight as we deliberate, but it would not have held indefinitely. So eventually an ultimatum was given to Saddam Hussein, followed by appeals to withdraw unconditionally. These appeals were rejected. It is a reasonable conclusion to draw that Saddam Hussein for a very long time had determined on a course of conflict and war.

I also wish to make a few observations about the peace movement in this country. I certainly acknowledge people's right to put a position, to articulate a case and to argue that case. But the position is confused and confusing. The very easy slogans of `no blood for oil' and `bring the ships home' are no substitute for reasoned policy; no substitute for a policy which will restore the circumstance in Kuwait; and no substitute for a policy that will end the pillage, murder and rape in Kuwait. Some in the peace movement argue for sanctions, some argue for negotiations and some argue for appeasement. It is the great virtue of our democracy that we can sit here and see what happened today in terms of people putting a point of view. But it could not occur in Kuwait tonight.

I also wish to say a few words about the Iraqi regime itself. There are some lessons for the West in terms of the kinds of people with whom we deal from time to time in international affairs. The Iraqi regime is one of singular brutality. In most circumstances, the maximum brutality is applied to reach a political conclusion. The Iraqi regime runs an economy that is based on a need for continuing conflict. Its political structure reflects its militarism and its aggression and the desire of its President for aggrandisement. This can be seen in the treatment of the Kurdish population. The only acknowledgment Saddam Hussein has ever given his Kurdish minority is to target them with his dreadful weapons. It is seen in the warfare conducted for nearly a decade against Iran, in terms of attacks upon centres of civilian population and the use of horrifying weapons of mass destruction, including chemical weapons-weapons not seen since they were outlawed after the First World War.

It is seen in the absolutely bloody and unjustified invasion and occupation of Kuwait, well documented now by Amnesty International in terms of the suffering inflicted upon the civilian population. It is seen in the unprovoked attack upon the state of Israel, again with weapons directed at population centres rather than military targets.
In a very disturbing turn, in the last 24 hours it is seen in the Iraqi treatment of prisoners of war in direct violation of the Geneva Convention and all the norms of human behaviour.

We should learn a little more about politics from our mistakes. The West should learn from our experience with Saddam Hussein. Not so long ago his army was seen as a bulwark against Islamic fundamentalism being directed against the Gulf states. We should learn from our errors and mistakes.

I now want to look briefly at the international reaction. This has been well covered, so I will not dwell upon it. If one excepts Iraq, all but four member states of the United Nations-those four being Jordan, Cuba, Yemen and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea; a misnomer if ever there was one-have voted for the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. They have brought the moral pressure inherent in their commitment to the United Nations to bear on an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. It has been said many times that 28 countries are now militarily involved. Most of the democracies are actively engaged.

To look within the ranks of the Socialist International-the umbrella association with which the Australian Labor Party is associated-to quote Neil Kinnock: the British Labour Party voted unequivocally in the House of Commons for the United Nations. When the UN intervention began, the Spanish Socialists said again, unequivocally, that responsibility for the war rested with Saddam Hussein. To quote the leader of the Italian Socialists, as Senator Tate and Senator McMullan did earlier in the debate, Bettino Craxi, in the Italian House of Deputies, just a few days ago, on 16 January, said:

We have seen many dictatorial regimes throw themselves into military adventures in the conviction or the illusion of victory. But never before have we witnessed a regime issuing a challenge of war, knowing full well that it will lose. All this has coloured the conduct of the Iraqi regime with such irrationality and fanaticism, that it is beyond our horizon, removed from the principles in which we believe, from our desire to see every contest be the subject of dialogue and negotiations.
Mr Craxi concluded by saying:
It is removed from the peaceful and pacifist spirit of our tradition, the tradition of men and women of peace.
I doubt that anyone can put a response in more eloquent terms than did Mr Craxi on that occasion in the House of Deputies in Rome.

This war is not being fought to make the world safe for democracy-no-one can claim that. It is certainly not being fought to make the world safe for feudalism in the Gulf. It is not being fought to restore the al-Sabah family in Kuwait in simple terms or in exclusive terms. But it is being fought in defence of the great principles inherent in the United Nations charter, including the principle of collective security. This Parliament was one of the first to support and endorse these principles. It was bipartisan in that endorsement. A great Australian Foreign Minister led the way and broke the ground. Of course, I am referring to Dr Herbert Vere Evatt, first President of the UN General Assembly.

The United Nations really is the last great hope for humanity. I will quote what the British Prime Minister Clem Attlee said in the House of Commons on 5 July 1950-the only other occasion in which the United Nations had been obliged to intervene militarily. This puts matters tonight in context. Of the outbreak of the Korean war and of Britain's decision, sponsored by the Labour Government and supported by the conservative opposition to intervene, he said:

The issue before the House this afternoon is a simple one, although it involves very grave issues of peace and war. I am asking the House to support the Government in the action which they have taken in resisting aggression. That action is fulfilling our obligations under the Charter of the United Nations.
Mr Attlee continued:
If the United Nations is not to go the way of the League of Nations, the members must be prepared to act when the need arises.

Mr Attlee's words have a certain resonance about them this evening, just as they did that afternoon in London on 5 July 1950 when the world was confronted by the outbreak of the Korean war, again an act of naked aggression.

This war is being fought to make the world a little safer for humanity in the longer term. A new international order is gradually emerging-hopefully one that is based on greater economic and political justice; hopefully one that is based on the great documents of the United Nations, particularly the Charter and the Declaration of Human Rights.

I want to make a few observations about the international media in this war. This is the first war of satellites in more than one sense. It is certainly the first war of the networks. It is very important to a democracy such as ours that we spend a little time looking at the way in which the media is obliged to report the conflict and goes about reporting the conflict. There is a myth abroad about the Vietnam war, particularly in the United States, and that is that television lost the war for the Americans. I know that that has been popularised with expressions such as, `If network television had been at the battle of Gettysburg, there would be two Americas today'. But it is a myth and a fraudulent assumption.

The only documented analysis of the coverage, not only of the American media but also of the international media of the war in Vietnam, was actually put together by the United States Army Centre for Military History; an author by the name of William Hammond compiled a 414-page study into the media's treatment of the war in Vietnam, particularly the American military presence. Mr Hammond left no-one in doubt as to his conclusions. He concluded that it was the lack of credibility on the part of the Administration, particularly the Johnson Administration, and the rising US casualty rate which supposedly caused American public opinion to sour. It is not the case that American television `lost' the war for the United States. It was a consequence of the low credibility and the damage being done to the American forces.

An assessment of that report means that, if anything, there is a greater obligation upon the Administration in Washington, upon governments generally and the media present to report the conflict than was previously believed. To date the media reporting has been, judging by our un- tutored but hopefully critical assessment, sound in the sense of evaluation and analysis. There are very great responsibilities upon the people charged with the reporting of the war in the Middle East. It is not without reason that Saddam Hussein has retained the Cable News Network in Baghdad. The Hussein regime sees the advantage of having network television present. We should be alert to the need to be careful in our analysis and not to leap to conclusions.

In terms of the post-war world which will emerge-hopefully sooner rather than later-we need to address the vexed problems inherent in the circumstances of the West Bank and the Gaza. Those circumstances are the result of wars not only in 1967 and in 1973 but also of the Jordanian Army's quite brutal suppression of the Palestinians in 1970 and of the war in Lebanon, fought from 1982 onwards. We need to address the problems of the Kurdish people who have been dispossessed, massacred and harassed by their Iraqi overlords. We need to make certain of the security of the state of Israel. That has become absolutely critical given the unprovoked missile assaults upon that country.

A new world order is emerging and addressing the problems of the Middle East will be an important first step. We should also look to the emergence of a genuine north-south dialogue-a dialogue which can begin a reality based on a more equitable distribution of both wealth and power so that peace and security can be more than just words. We can make the world a little less safer for despots and ultimately make it unsafe for aggressors.

When this war is over, there will be lessons to be learnt and other wars can be avoided. As we support UN Resolution 678 tonight, so in the Middle East we should reaffirm our support for resolutions 242 and 338 in terms of settlement affecting Israel and the Palestinians. This Government is committed to the support of an international conference on the Middle East, although not to linkage with the circumstances of the invasion of Kuwait. We can look to justice for people currently living under the Iraqi regime whose only crime is to call themselves Kurds; we can acknowledge their rights.
To finish I will quote again from Clem Attlee's speech of July 1950:

The main matter that concerns all of us is the preservation of peace. I have no doubt at all that this matter has to be carried through and settled, to show that aggression does not pay. I hope that it will be realised by all the people in all the free countries that to preserve peace the rule of law must be upheld and that we are in this, and that we cannot leave it to someone else to do.
It concerns us all. We have pledged ourselves to the support of the United Nations; we have taken action with others. Mr Attlee concluded with these words, and they are appropriate tonight:
I confidently ask the House and the country for their unanimous support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am one of those who believe there is no such thing as either a just war or a justifiable war. Events of the past few days have served only to reinforce my view that all wars are intrinsically wrong, that violence begets violence and that this endorsement of violence as a legitimate means of conflict resolution from us, the law-makers of our society, will filter down and permeate our entire society. I believe we have an obligation to demonstrate that other options can work.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the actions of Saddam Hussein and the troops acting in his name are indefensible and no Australian Democrats are defending him or them, but to say that supporting and demonstrating for peace is equivalent to support for Hussein is just plain dishonest. In the same way, involvement in peace demonstrations does not mean that we are condemning or betraying the Australian naval forces currently in the Gulf. We share the very grave concern expressed here for their safety and our prayers go to all of them and to their families.

However, in choosing the option for war in the Gulf, I believe the United States and its allies, including Australia, are ignoring the fundamental lesson of history: that war solves nothing and only creates more problems. We have only to look at the so-called peace settlement of World War I to see that; we know that it was a direct cause of the Second World War.

Some things have changed and I think it is encouraging to note that since the Second World War many people throughout the world have learnt the lessons of history. I would like to quote from an article in today's Australian Financial Review entitled, `Anti-war sentiments gather strength', which states:
News of the Gulf war has been greeted with widespread public opposition in Europe, the US and Australia.
In Europe the opposition has been strongest in Germany.

. . . with 80 per cent of the population opposing military action in the Middle East. The streets of Germany's major cities have erupted in daily mass peace rallies since the allied bombing of Iraq began last week.
In France . . . nearly 60 per cent . . . said they opposed any military action.
About 55 per cent of Italians said they did not agree with their country's involvement in the Gulf, in particular after the Pope pronounced that no war could be justified.
While about 63 per cent of Spaniards thought President Saddam Hussein was to blame, about the same number thought that war should be avoided.
About 65 per cent of Belgiums backed their Government's decision not to participate in the conflict.
The article continues:
Thousands of apartment blocks across Germany now have white sheets waving from the windows, signifying peace.
An older generation, not only in Germany but in other parts of Europe, remembers the experience, the humiliation and the destruction of war.

I think the real cost of war compared with the cost of prolonged peace initiatives has been glossed over in this debate. We are asked how much will it cost and who will pay the bill if we are to leave ships enforcing sanctions for 18 months. That question symbolises to me the inability of most people here to recognise the real long term and intangible costs of war which balance sheets do not accommodate.

There is the cost of the human impact of the attack on Kuwait. How does one measure the long term cost of human suffering and trauma? Suffering does not end when a ceasefire is achieved or when a military budget runs out. The second cost of the Gulf war is the major long term repercussions for international relations in the Middle East. Assuming the United States wins, what will be the aftermath? Will the people of the Middle East accept the new order and live comfortably with Western domination of their political life? Of course not. Virtually all the present problems of the Middle East date back to World War I and the determination of what was then still imperial Britain to shape a strategic region in its own interest.

Emotionally devastated by the vast casualty lists generated on the killing grounds of France, I think it is fair to say that the British public had little interest in Middle East affairs at that time. Perhaps we are again to see a carve up of the Middle East as an outcome of this war. High on the agenda will be the future of Palestinians. One of the important issues on the agenda of those seeking a peace conference on all of the festering problems of the Middle East will be achieved and could have been achieved before imposing a deadline if there had been a genuine willingness to pursue the option of extensive and prolonged negotiations and discussions.

Despite the fact that this was a European initiative, we said, `No, this may allow Saddam Hussein to save face'. Preventing him from saving face was so much more important than saving hundreds of thousands of innocent lives. In refusing this option, we are reinforcing 70-year-old secret deals and shabby political manoeuvrings which laid the foundations for the present Middle East agony and, I would contend, the roots for further war will flourish.

The third long term cost relates to the precedent that war against Iraq sets for the post-Cold War international order, something we have heard a great deal about so far in this debate. Does this mean that military action should be taken against all big countries which are attempting to subjugate smaller ones? For example, are Tibet and Lithuania to be liberated by massive forces and will we take part?

Social justice costs also have to be counted. To date our deployment of frigates has cost $300,000 a day or $100m per year. Just 12 days costs amounting to $3.6m would completely fund the request of the United Nations Children's Fund for emergency assistance to the refugees in Jordan. In this financial year, the United States will spend $30 billion mounting its offensive against Iraq. The total of world aid by comparison is $50 billion. I ask: Where is the morality in these priorities?

Then there are the environmental costs, some of which Senator Coulter has already referred to. Red Adair, as reported in a recent British Broadcasting Corporation program, maintains that it would be impossible to deal with the fire situation if Iraq sets off the charges attached to the Iraqi oil wells. This environmental cataclysm could just as easily be ignited by aerial bombardment from the West. The fires would raise the temperature in surrounding countries to 60 or even 65 degrees centigrade. Such an environment would be unlivable. India's entire grain crop, for instance, would be affected. Where do the conventional ledger books take account of these costs? The answer is that they do not. What, too, of the cost of a breakdown in this Government's policy of multiculturalism-a policy so carefully built up by the community with goodwill and understanding over many years, a policy seriously threatened by the present upsurge in anti-Arab racism.

Like Senator Loosley, I would like to refer to the role of the media because it is one of the significant and distinguishing features of this conflict and the build-up to it. It has involved the use of the most sophisticated of this century's communications technology. Personally, I have found it sickening, and I know that many Australians have as well, to hear from nearly all Australian television stations, `You are now watching the Gulf war live on channel x', and to see it interspersed with advertisements for cars and fast foods. I believe that it is dangerous to a democracy when the majority of the media wants war because they believe that it makes good media, the sort of good media which reduces warfare and the killing of unknown and unpredictable numbers of human beings to the same format as a gridiron game where a cold analysis of each manoeuvre is followed by replays to make sure that we are sufficiently desensitised. How encouraging it is then to read that a huge number of viewers are now turning off prime time war coverage.

The role of the media must not be underestimated. I want to praise the reporters and camera operators who have made a conscious effort to canvass all viewpoints. Equally, I want to roundly condemn those who deliberately choose to deal in stereotypes, concentrating on the stereotypical, colourfully visual demonstrator, for example, without showing the broad cross-section of people who have been attending peace demonstrations throughout this country. These attempts to sensationalise, trivialise and marginalise peace demonstrations are dishonest and undemocratic.

John Pilger in the Guardian Weekly last week suggests that in the present conflict the media will bear much of the responsibility for a patriotic and culpable silence and that it will not play the role it played during the Vietnam War. He advances two reasons for this: firstly, that there has been the communications revolution in recent years and, secondly, because in this war the United States might actually win.

I strongly reject the assertion that five months was a sufficient trial time for sanctions to be demonstrated as working. We have heard from other speakers that international experts accept that sanctions succeed when they affect 25 to 35 per cent of the target nation's trade. We know that this has been achieved in Iraq. The importance of these sanctions has been canvassed by previous Democrat speakers. I support and endorse their comments.

We are not just liberating Kuwait, we are leaving a legacy of violence that will endure for decades-not, as Senator Loosley said, a world certain to be safer for humanity in the longer term. I call for a cessation of hostilities and a new peace initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion we are dealing with today relating to the Gulf war is basically in five parts: firstly, the threat to world peace by the invasion and occupation of Kuwait by Iraq; secondly, the support for United Nations initiatives; thirdly, confidence and support for our involved service personnel and the involvement of our allies; fourthly, concern about the Iraqi attacks on Israel; and, fifthly, the long term resolution of security issues in the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: I look at this problem from the perspective of the Northern Territory electorate which has previously been involved in war. Forcibly this is brought home by the historical account in the book entitled Australia's Pearl Harbour by Douglas Lockwood. The author's note to that book states:

Eight ships were sunk and others beached and burnt. Two hundred and forty three people were killed in less than one hour and more than three hundred wounded. Much of the town was destroyed and commercial life ceased at once. The banks were closed by government decree and the centre of N.T. Administration shortly removed to Alice Springs. Thereafter, although martial law was never proclaimed, Darwin was a town under military control. There were more than fifty subsequent attacks upon it by the Japanese.

The death toll on that first day made it the worst disaster in history on Australian soil. In spite of that, comparatively little is known of what happened. Two or three writers have discussed it only briefly. The Official War History, in each of several volumes, gives the barest outline.

How very different to the situation which we are now considering. Two and a half years before the bombing of Darwin, the then wartime member of the House of Representatives for Northern Territory, Adair Macalister Blain, had made a very prophetic speech in Parliament on 6 September 1939 about the early stages of the war in Europe. In talking about the Northern Territory, he said:

My electorate includes people of all classes. I have bushmen and workers, civil servants and businessmen, military and naval officers and men, and people of every other class in my electorate. I know that whatever may be their differences on local issues-and we all have our differences-my constituents will stand firmly behind the Government. They are all good Australians. They are the flower of this country, and they are prepared to fight for it.
That statement is just as true today. Further on in the same speech he said:

Although I cannot cry, as Hitler did in the Reichstag, ``Heil Victory'', I can and do cry, ``Hail Justice''-justice for the frightened millions of Europe who live under the fear of this bully of Berlin who is determined to win his objectives even over the corpses of women and children. We are fighting for justice.
The comparisons in these quotes with today and today's issues are more than interesting. I am reminded of the quote by Santayana:
Those who do not remember the past are condemned to relive it.

The comparisons between Hitler, the bully boy of Berlin, and the butcher of Baghdad, Saddam Hussein, are very valid to this debate. We need to state over and again if necessary that it is Saddam Hussein's aggression, terror and blackmail that have caused the present conflict with all its sad consequences and necessary forceful use of conflict.

Saddam Hussein has flouted the international and United Nations overtures since 2 August last year. No-one wants war, but the brutality and bastardry of Iraq have left the civilised and thinking nations with no alternatives. Senator Tate's speech put many of the human rights issues and more personal theological points into an excellent perspective. It is necessary at this time that all parliamentarians and in fact all citizens of Australia need to stand behind service personnel and their families more than ever before. We must not abandon the much needed support for service personnel serving in Australia and the Middle East. Now, more than ever, we need to reaffirm our commitment to the thousands of service personnel living and working in the Northern Territory, particularly those in logistic and strategic support and at Pine Gap. We cannot let those people down.

Freedom and the high tech-revolution are inextricably connected. In both the military operation and the media presentation of the Gulf war, we have come to realise just how complex this war is in areas of technology. But there is also a deeper consideration. I quote from American author, George Gilder. In an article in November 1990, he said:

Today, America is the world leader in technological innovation not because of its government or its Pentagon funding or its accumulated wealth or its natural resources or its continental scope-or any of the blessings to which U.S. success is often ascribed in text books-but because of an older ethic of freedom and sacrifice. In short, America's triumphs spring from the very moral codes and disciplines, the religious commitment and faith . . .

The media coverage, of course, heightens our impressions, perceptions and delusions of the Gulf war. In the early stages, it was easy to get drawn into the war games scenario in which the euphoria almost created the view that Star Wars' Luke Sky Walker and Darth Vader were with us. It is certainly a war of good and evil. But we do have to put it back into a real and human context and not rely on our initial, surrealistic impressions. We must pay credit to the skill and the commitment of the United States, Britain, France, the Arab coalition and all of the 28 participating countries.

This was illustrated just a short while ago when the Australian Democrats as usual were wrong. Belgium is involved. It has four ships committed and its Government has just recently reinstated its commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, a further commitment of which has been given in recent days to support Turkey. The Democrats have a throwaway line in that particular area.

Let us also stop for a moment and pay credit to the crucial role of the United Nations. The United Nations has played a role through much of the history of recent years as a peacemaker, a conciliator, and we certainly saw the SecretaryGeneral try the last minute stops to avoid this catastrophe.

There is no guarantee that this will be a short war. It could well drag on for weeks and months. As the action moves to a battle on the ground the tactics, problems and frustrations will compound. This will be the time to stand forcibly behind our objectives and our field troops. We must acknowledge that Pine Gap and Nurrungar do play an important role and are a measure of our international obligations. Organisations such as the Red Cross and the international medical teams will need to know that we reinforce their roles and work with thanks, appreciation and support. We do not need the trendies and the treacherous demonstrators undermining their dangerous and necessary tasks.

By all means pray for peace. What a wonderful dream. We are all doing that. I have Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, for example, at Galiwinku in Arnhem Land, which have made similar expressions to so many other communities throughout Australia. I had discussions last week with the acting imam of the muslim mosque in Darwin and with other religious leaders with regard to the situation at the time. But, as Senator Newman said earlier, our prayers must be equally with our service personnel and, most importantly, their families and the support they need in this community; our people working in medical, political and diplomatic fields of service; and our Middle East migrants-particularly those suffering community misunderstandings or tensions.

Today in this chamber and in the House of Representatives we saw and heard demonstrators from a group called Students United Against War. I understand that Senator Vallentine also publicly yelled her frustrations from a privileged position reserved for senators in the House of Representatives. I can only describe their organised angry activities as naive and misguided. It is a pity that the education, social and economic conditions and results of the last few years have produced this sort of unacceptable behaviour. Certainly, Senator Vallentine and the students have every right to state their views, however naive and misguided. But there are proper forums and certainly a sympathetic media to expound their opinions. If there is validity and balance in what they say, then those points will register with the community.

It is an insult to the intelligence of Australians to presume that the community is not listening to or dealing with the complexity of the moral, military, political, economic, religious or social issues. I read the yellow flier that was sent to us like a kindergarten kite from the gallery. When I looked through that particular pamphlet I noticed the sort of catch words about how the Students United Against War is a loose network of students committed to ending the conflict in the Gulf. They condemn the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq but they say, and I heighten, that they:
. . . believe that war will not resolve any of the underlying problems which gave rise to the invasion.

The next paragraph speaks of a commitment to bring the warships home and achieve a cease-fire. They condemn racism and then acknowledge that this has been generated by cultural ignorance and prejudice. Again there is a catchcry. They want:
. . . a more comprehensive solution to the problems of the Middle East through an international peace conference . . .

This would concentrate, of course, on issues such as self-determination. The paucity of the arguments in that pamphlet only convinced me that the views of this vocal, noisy minority were, as I said earlier, naive and misguided.

Similarly, I express concern at the activities of the Labor member for the Northern Territory, Warren Snowdon. Mr Snowdon holds office as Parliamentary Secretary and a member of the Executive Council. Obviously, he has trouble reconciling his roles as a member of the Hawke Labor Government and his past, which is steeped in radical peace activism and entrenched in the Marxist-Leninist roots of the socialist Left.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very obviously, Mr Snowdon is out of step with the Government and he has abdicated his responsibility in speaking for the majority of his electorate-the same one I represent, the Northern Territory. Mr Snowdon has acted as sponsor for a street peace rally under the banner `War is not the answer', after-I stress, after-the commencement of military activities. His office has also acted as the conduit for fax material by the Alice Springs Peace Group against Pine Gap, located in his own electorate and manned by hundreds of his own and my constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: What a marked difference there is between the positions of Mr Snowdon and Senator Tate. Mr Snowdon has no alternative but to join Senator Vallentine's pacifist alliance and get out of his official positions. He cannot be a wolf in sheep's clothing. If the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not call the tune and set proper examples for his own team, then not only does he weaken his own leadership but also he compromises the position of his rhetoric and the official Government position. I ask the Prime Minister to apply the same standards to Mr Snowdon as to the protesters he accused of mouthing mindless slogans and falling into the trap of appeasement.
I earlier quoted Adair Blain, a former member of the House of Representatives for the Northern Territory. On 29 November 1939-remember, this is 1939-he also said:

The Labour party has nothing to be proud of in acting in the way it is doing. When the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holloway) talked today about the horrors of war tears rolled down his cheeks like pebbles and scoria sliding down the slopes of a mountain. Sentiment will have no effect on the German people other than to convince them that Australia, from the defence point of view, is a huge joke. It will also keep the neutrals wondering how we stand. There must be an end to the Labour Party's policy of compartmentalism.
He further said:

When I go back to the Northern Territory, no doubt, two or three people will ask me, `Why do you speak on matters that do not directly concern the Territory?' I shall answer them that I was elected to this Parliament as a representative, not as a delegate. Apparently, however, members of the Labour Party regard themselves as delegates. Perhaps they would wish this House to be described as the House of Delegates.

I wonder if that quote could not be applied equally to the factionalism within the Labor Party today. The motion before the Senate is a strong statement by the major parties and reflects the majority view of the Australian community. The debate also highlights the total irrelevancy of the Democrats.

The focus of this serious issue stands on its merits and the high principles of Australia, the United States, Britain, France, the Arab coalition partners and the United Nations. We will not be subdued by the arrogance of the dictator Saddam Hussein, his Baath Socialist Party, terrorism or tyranny in whatever form it takes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I contribute to this debate in part as one who has lived first hand through the horrors of war, not as a soldier but as a 12-year-old bit of flotsam who for some three months was part of the 1945 refugee trek between the retreating German and advancing Russian armies. Compared with today's sophisticated remote control weaponry, the planes and tanks which shot up the refugee columns were primitive, yet probably on a dollar for dollar basis at least as efficient in producing burnt human flesh.

SPEECH.PARA: Later in life, I determined that I would attempt to contribute to the elimination of institutional violence in all its forms. It is a determination which was lent additional urgency by the total horror of the Holocaust. Let us not make a mistake: once we accept institutional killing as a valid instrument of national policy, the difference is one of degree only. In today's world, there will be cases where to kill will prevent a greater loss of life, and this statement will indicate to honourable senators that I have been unable to achieve the position of an uncompromising pacifist. In many ways, I wish I could have done so. I suspect that it would make me a better person. Certainly, life would be much less complicated.

As it is, I believe that as a world community we have some way to go before we become a humane and more civilised community. It is a slow and difficult path that nations and their leaders have to tread, a path that demands moral commitment, intellectual rigour and independence, and determination to use economic resources to change the hearts and minds of this and future generations. It is a matter of great regret and indeed sadness that Australia's political establishment-as represented by the Government and the Opposition-could not meet this challenge on this occasion.

There is no doubt that Saddam Hussein is a violent aggressor with the blood of millions on his hands, and that he must be stopped. However, the key to the divergence of thinking between the Australian Democrats and the old parties are two phrases the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) repeated this afternoon: `Only as a last resort' and `Should that become necessary'. Both statements open the way to build on the unique consensus of United Nations member states to impose and enforce sanctions. It was a tangible acknowledgment that we had left behind the Cold War with its nuclear threat and that we might be moving towards a new world order-a term used in somewhat different senses by other people today-an age when conflicts are resolved and aggressors stopped by essentially non-violent means.

We have now lost the chance to move this world towards a more civilised and humane community. We have lost it through the utter lack of true leadership displayed by what professes to be the leading government of the Western world, that of the United States of America, and by our own Government and our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who could not rush fast enough into embracing the means of mass destruction as the simplistic Rambo solution to the challenges facing us in the Middle East.

The reasons put forward for this utter failure of leadership are spurious. They say that we cannot have appeasement, and Hitler is invoked in a dishonest sleight of hand. However, there was no attempt to contain Hitler prior to 1939 except by talking, no determination to apply sanctions, and no capacity to do so: there was no choice but to go to war ultimately. By contrast, it is clear that resolution 678 is permissive and not mandatory. It does offer alternatives, yet the United States, and to our shame, Australia, have chosen to use the most violent option, an option which, in Philip Adams's words in the Australian last weekend, `will burn children alive'.

It is an option which was chosen despite the mounting evidence that sanctions are working. After only five months, no-one other than the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) reports that exports have been contained to 97 per cent, that imports have been contained to 90 per cent, and that there has been a 40 per cent drop in production in Iraq.

It is also illogical in economic terms. The cost of keeping a determined United Nations force, which we would have to have in place if we continued to rely on sanctions as we should, is but a fraction of what it costs the United States and the world as a whole to run this particular war. Day one of Operation Desert Storm was estimated to have cost the United States in excess of $US500m-in our terms $A645m. This cost is purely ammunition and equipment. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the cost to the United States alone could vary between $A36 billion and $A111 billion, depending on the length and intensity of the conflict. It is horrific in terms of human lives and it is catastrophic in terms of throwing the world back to the Dark Ages.

If any proof were needed for the bankruptcy of our so-called leaders, one only needs to look at the Prime Minister's mindless gibe at people asking him to think again; in fact to think. Worse than the facile arguments we have heard from the Government is the insult that Dr Hewson hurled at people who are seeking peaceful solutions. According to Dr Hewson, people who do not want to kill are wimps. Let us ask the question: who is a wimp-the person who risks his or her life, like the peace activists Robert Burrowes, Jack Lomax and Jack King, or people like John Hewson egging on others to kill or be killed in the secure knowledge that they will not be called upon to leave their safe havens well behind the front lines? Who is the wimp? Who, indeed, is the coward?

In conclusion, let me express gratitude for the substantial proportion of Australians opposing the military solution. No cheap shots about the shouts, the dress or the appearance of the young people in the chamber today can obscure the fact that they have the moral conviction and the determination to fashion a future which is not dependent on the destruction of human beings; a determination the old parties in this place lack.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to support the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the motion that springs from his statement. To put it another way, I would like to speak on behalf of other peace activists in this House-not the peace activists who believe that the only way to put one's point of view is to stand outside the American Embassy and shout obscenities; not the peace activists who shout down lecturers and who shout down politicians in this home of free speech; not the people who accuse anyone who has a different view from them of being warmongers; but the other type of peace activist who is not necessarily a pacifist but who believes that in human nature there is always a tendency to be aggressive and that in the conduct of nations there will from time to time be a breakdown of communications between those nations. At the end of the day there are some nations, because of their social and political structures, which are unable to accept the rule of law; which are unable to accept the sovereignty of their neighbours; which are unable to accept even the most basic forms of human decency; and which are not prepared to accept that their citizens have any entitlement to those basic forms of human decency.

SPEECH.PARA: Yes, I am a peace activist like most people in the Australian Labor Party. I put my papers in as a conscientious objector during the Vietnam war because I thought that war was a mistake. I believe that anyone who opposed that war was quite correct. It was strategically a bad decision. It was humanely a bad decision. In the long term geopolitical network that has come out of Asia, and South East Asia in particular, it was a bad mistake. But that does not mean to say that because the Americans, for example, made a mistake in Vietnam-as did the French before them-and because the Americans made mistakes in Central and South America, the Americans are always wrong.

In fact, one thing that strikes me about American society is that, for all its faults, on the whole it is the epitome of a society which encourages and tolerates freedom of expression. In a strange way, it has brought through from its eighteenth century beginnings a concept of universal democracy which has been extremely influential in the parliaments of this world and in world forums. It occasionally lets itself down. Yet we do have so-called peace activists, who can see only wrong in what the United States does. I found it on the whole a fairly healthy society. I must say that it is a lot healthier than Romania, the Soviet Union and other peoples' democracies that I have come in contact with during my political career.

When we come into this Parliament to debate this particular issue, I would hope that we would talk about how we can bring peace to this world. I cannot think of anyone in this chamber that I know who specifically gets pleasure out of going to war; who believes that the impact of a Cruise missile, some antitank device or some antipersonnel weapon is fun. Nobody in this Government, and I think nobody in this Parliament, extracts pleasure from seeing Australia at war. To tell the truth, Australia is at war at the moment; albeit in a limited way according to the capacity of this country to provide rational assistance to the United Nations force.

The war did not begin, as so many people have said, on the seventeenth of this month. It began on 2 August last year when the Iraqi forces marched into Kuwait, having sued for peace against the Iranians-the war against whom they also began. We are not talking here about a particular country that by circumstances had been forced to defend its borders. Sometimes excuses can be made in that type of situation. We are talking about a country that, in clear breach of international understandings and law, marched into a separate sovereign country, began torturing its innocent citizens and began dismantling the infrastructure of that country almost immediately after it had gained any control over it.

It does not matter two hoots whether the ruling family in Kuwait were convinced democrats, moderate royalists or whatever. The simple fact is that they were the internationally recognised government of the independent country of Kuwait. Let us face it, for the peace activists, so-called, to find an excuse for Saddam Hussein to attack Kuwait by saying that the ruling family of Kuwait was not democratic is one of the most tenuous and I think deceitful arguments for people to parade before this Parliament. It does not excuse the Iraqi move.

The Middle East is not exactly brimming over with democratic countries. Even Israel, which has a parliament similar to ours in terms of its representational arrangements, still denies at least 800,000 of its Palestinian citizens-or prisoners, if one can call them that-the right to vote and to have the civil liberties that are accepted by Israeli citizens. But at least Israel is some way towards being a genuine democracy. If one looks around the rest of the Middle East, the countries are very much a product of their history.

To begin with, let us get rid of the argument that it was all right, it was okay, it was acceptable for Saddam Hussein to march into Kuwait because the Kuwaitis were not running a pristine democracy. That argument is no excuse for breaches of international covenants and accepted international law. It certainly in no way defends the atrocities that are being committed now and have been committed since 2 August on Kuwaiti citizens.

I think that nobody in this chamber, with a few exceptions, can stand up and be proud about our record in the Middle East. We have tolerated excesses from the Israelis. We have tolerated it because the Iraqis were fighting the dreaded Ayatollah Khomeini. We tolerated excesses from the Iraqis that we would not have tolerated, I presume, at any other time. We sat on our backsides while the most enormous invasions of civil liberties and human rights occurred in both Iran and Iraq. I do not say everyone in this Parliament, but on the whole we were pretty quiet.

Certainly the peace activists who have been standing outside the American Embassy did not seem to be saying too much about the gross violations of civil rights, the tortures, the imprisonments and the beatings that have been occurring in Iraq for at least eight years. Why? It is because Iraq was fighting the dreaded Ayatollah Khomeini. There is no other reason. That justified whatever went on in Iraq. It also enabled Brazil, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union, the United States and, especially, France to sell the most modern weapons of war to Iraq. Why? It is because the Iraqis were fighting the dreaded Ayatollah Khomeini.

So, if we go back into the Middle East over the last decade we will see that on many occasions we made mistakes, the Western alliance made mistakes, about the way we looked at the Middle East. We took a short term vision, if we can call it a vision, and our vision was one based upon fear and a misunderstanding of the Arab psyche.
So let us not hear the simplistic arguments that the only activists for peace are those who demonstrate against the Americans and oppose the United Nations' activities in the Middle East--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Soviets were providing weapons to Iraq.

—Precisely. The Soviet Union was providing Iraq with a very significant part of its very modern armoury. This was for various reasons: partly the income it earned; partly because of the influence it could have in that particular region; and partly because of fear of Muslim fundamentalism within the Soviet Union's own borders. It seemed that so many countries had their own reasons for supporting Saddam Hussein, and now we are reaping the whirlwind. But that does not in any way justify the Australian Democrats or the peace activists, so-called, who can stand back and say, `The West has come to its senses but it ought to be stopped', because at last they have stood up to someone who has gone beyond the bounds of what is accepted internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly am talking now to the young people in this country, the ones who have been conned into believing that a slogan solves a problem and who believe that it is good and slightly exciting to challenge authority in this country by supporting the most authoritarian dictator in the Middle East, or at least he is neck and neck with Assad of Syria, who for the moment remains our ally, lest it not be forgotten that he is our ally.

I want to go through, very quickly, the nature of the Iraqi regime that has relevance to this debate. Like Sparta, the Iraqis have been a nation at war for a very long time, and they are a nation at war not necessarily because their borders have been threatened; they are a nation at war because the Baath Party and Saddam Hussein have benefited from having the country on a war footing for a decade or more.

The nature of Baathism has been to control their population by appearing to be and genuinely engaging in, wherever possible, acts of war in order to keep the country united, to suppress dissent, and to ensure that the ruling minority stays a ruling minority. That is one part of the nature of Iraqi society. Where else would a country with a population about the same as Australia find the need to have 4,000 tanks or more, 700 planes of the most modern varieties and the most modern missiles? Why would it need to have such a large standing army and such suppression of its own citizens? Why would it need, for example, to poison the Kurds or any other minority who opposed them? Why does that regime need to keep its hand on its citizens so tightly? The answer is basically because it sees itself-many people alongside Saddam Hussein see themselves-as part of the old Babylonian empire. There is a pride there that has a lot to do with a sense of expansionism. They are not protecting their borders. Therefore, we are dealing with a different creature.

To the so-called peace activists I leave this message: if they do not understand the Baathist regime in Iraq or the regime in Syria, they will never understand at least one or two of the major factors in the recurring problems that plague the Middle East. Again, it is not appropriate to simply mouth slogans in order to push this Government into finding some sort of simple solution. Slogans are not solutions. This is a long term situation which sooner or later-and sooner, I hope-after this war is over must be addressed by all nations of the world, preferably through the United Nations as an appropriate forum. Let us not lose sight of the fact that there are long term objectives after this war that we have to look at.

Let me go to something that is particularly important to me as an individual and particularly important to the basic philosophy of the Labor Party: the concept of collective security. This century has been plagued, particularly in Europe but, I guess, also elsewhere in the world, by a series of wars caused by shifting alliances and the expansion of individual aggressive countries, both big and small, against their neighbours. The rollcall of our failure to resolve international problems is very long indeed: Abyssinia, the Rhineland, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Austria, East Timor-which is a dreadful blight on Australian diplomatic skills-Cambodia and Vietnam; the list goes on and on. This is precisely because the one thing that we hoped for after the Second World War has not occurred; that is, the ability of an organisation like the United Nations to create collective security as the major concept underpinning international relations.

The reality is that the superpowers, because of their rivalry, have been able to negate any move towards the proper use of the concept of collective security. Vetoes, backdoor vetoes, secret arms supplies, secret agreements and secret understandings have all been used to ensure that, as a world, we have not been able to bring people together to say, `These are the rules that underpin relationships between sovereign nations and these are the penalties for those who breach those rules'. Now we have a unique opportunity to create a system of collective security with appropriate policing where necessary. It will not be perfect. There will always be aggression and mistakes in diplomacy. There will always be difficulty in getting that collective force together to take ultimate action when it is necessary.

I refer to someone I admire very greatly-Herbert Vere Evatt-not for all his viewpoints because in some areas I think he had very overt and obvious weaknesses. But the one thing he did was to put Australia, after the Second World War, at the forefront of moves towards putting into practice the concept of collective security. He was one of the founding fathers of the United Nations. If one reads the books about Herbert Vere Evatt and his efforts in San Francisco and elsewhere to bring the concept of collective security to reality, one cannot help being impressed with the way a native Australian was able to take certain fortes that we have in our character into the world theatre and to give the world something to think about and to have an effect-breaking down the dominance of the big powers in the creation of the United Nations in the way the ground rules were laid down; encouraging the smaller nations to play a role and, above all else, saying that at the heart of collective security is proper economic and social development of the have-nots. His words still ring true. If we do not solve the difference between the haves and the have-nots, the question of collective security is made all the harder. But he was right.

It gives me, in a rather ironic way, a certain degree of pride to see that something for which Australia fought very strongly-a strong, active United Nations, in search of security for every member-could, in fact, be the result of the action that has now been taken by the United Nations in the Middle East. Many people say that that is idealistic, that it was a pinko dream back in the 1950s. It is, in fact, a realistic and sensible approach to international relationships now that the superpowers have discarded their rivalries. The option is there. The opening is there. So the message to young people is that sometimes, when the time is right, people of good intentions must stand up and be counted and they must act quickly. They must say to Saddam Hussein and others like him in other parts of the world, `There is a better way of doing things and we will not tolerate the way you are approaching things'.

It is a strange irony of history that Saddam Hussein, who has the most modern technology in the warfare area, is really a creature of the 1930s. He is a creature of a period where the League of Nations was useless. It was not prepared to act. He is a creature of the thinking which dominated the expansionism of certain countries in that period.

The German generals, who were anti-Hitler and wanted to see Hitler go, from 1933 onwards waited for the West to stand up to Hitler. They wanted Hitler to fail because then Hitler would lose his support at home; he would be a failure. What happened? Hitler went from success to success. There was the Rhineland. Czechoslovakia, one of the strongest standing armies in the world at that time, collapsed overnight. Then there was Austria. Every time Hitler had a win and a diplomatic success by the use of arms, fear and pressure, the stronger he became within his own country. Similarly with Mussolini. Saddam Hussein is part of that era in his thinking. I know it sounds trite to compare him with Hitler, but the same approach that was there in the 1930s with Hitler exists now with Saddam Hussein. We, as Australians, have to say, `Enough is enough. That approach-the annexation of an independent neighbour-is not acceptable'.

I finish on the point-being very practical because I have moved from idealism and the United Nations and have described what can be possible-that the most practical thing that can come out of this war in the Middle East and the most beneficial thing for Australia is the sure knowledge that, if we are successful in the Middle East, a lesson will have been taught to those medium-sized countries which are essentially authoritarian and which rely for their success from time to time on an appropriate war to galvanise their citizens, allowing them to put pressure on their citizens and deny their civil liberties and so on. If that message is getting through to those dictators and authoritarian nations, we are all the better off as Australians because we live in a region where there are a significant number of middle-sized powers, well armed with internal divisions and problems and essentially authoritarian, which at any time in the next decade may resort to the creation of external fears or external aggression against their neighbours for various reasons.

If the lesson of Kuwait is that the United Nations is prepared to stand up, with big power backing-and that is important-against such expansionist philosophies and nations, and if that lesson is learnt, Australia will be the safer for it. We can never defend ourselves on our own-not in the next decade. It is just not possible to do so. But what we can do is take part in the moves at the moment to create a new world order which does not say to smaller countries such as Australia, `You look after yourself. When the going is rough we don't want to know you'. It is the old philosophy of saying, `Oh, well, we can give up the Sudetenland; after all, they are probably Germans there anyway' and not, `Oh, well, Poland is just a country run by a group of semi-fascists'. There is always some excuse to justify doing nothing. Australia will be the better for this conflict. Initially there may be problems. Everyone has to face the reality of terrorism and the reality that people will die in this war. Everyone has to face the reality that we have said yes to a war, and that must sit on our conscience.

At the end of the day, if the concept of collective security becomes an accepted one and is a philosophy that can be put into practice, then Australia-and I think on the whole the family of nations around this world-will benefit. Therefore I support the Government's approach to this issue. Everyone finds it distasteful to be involved in a war, but at some time we have to make a judgment about conflicts in our region or in regions which affect us. I believe we have made the right judgment. I believe our involvement is appropriate according to our capacity. I believe our involvement is of real benefit to the allies, and psychologically our involvement is terribly important to those countries which in the future may face pressure from the likes of Saddam Hussein and others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Parliament tonight, and indeed today, is one which should have been debated some weeks ago and which could have been debated at a much earlier time, but it would probably not have been debated at all if the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had not been forced by weight of numbers in this chamber to convene a special sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons for such anxiety to avoid the scrutiny of the Parliament ought to be obvious to all: a desperate wish to avoid antagonising the left wing factions by putting up words that it would find unacceptable. Hence we have no mention of the leadership role played by the United States, nor of the consummate diplomatic skills displayed by George Bush and his principal advisers in stitching together an unprecedented and most unlikely coalition which has operated very effectively to date, and which shows no signs of unravelling.

Despite Saddam Hussein's blatant and clumsy attempts at provocation, the allies have managed to stick together, and even some of those most unlikely bed fellows have exhibited a maturity and astuteness which owes much to the assiduous diplomatic activities of the United States.

The war is now in its sixth day, and perhaps the most remarkable feature to date on all the known evidence is just how few deaths and casualties there have been. It is indeed paradoxical that, at a time when the world has been through two wars to end all wars and has now had some 45 years since Hiroshima to develop and perfect unimaginably powerful weapons of mass destruction, to date we are seeing a clinical war replete with surgical strikes. It is against the background of conventional wars such as East Timor and the civil war in Birundi, to name but two, which were reputed to have led to the deaths of hundreds of thousands of people, that we now seem to have entered an era or maybe only a phase when the principal targets are objects and not subjects. Perhaps this is due to the powerful deterrent effects of televised mass killings, one of the major lessons learned from the Vietnam conflict. It is almost miraculous that two Scud missile attacks on large Israeli population centres have apparently not killed a single person. We do not know whether this is due to the effectiveness of Israel's preparations or to the ineptness and inadequacy of Saddam's missile capability. Either way it has been little more than a token assault the prime purpose of which was always intended to be symbolic.

But all the evidence to date justifies the decision to take on Saddam Hussein. The alternative would have been no alternative at all-pandering to an egomaniac who has been impervious to all attempts to reason and negotiate. Those who are determined to argue that there was an alternative like to pretend that sanctions would have worked, but even the tightest noose will only be effective against a ruler who is responsive and responsible to his people. Saddam's track record clearly indicates the opposite. He has consistently brooked no opposition, exterminated political opponents, gassed the defenceless Kurds, and obsessed with the glories of pan-Arabism and the struggle, he is not susceptible to logic, argument or negotiation. Saddam understands only force and terror and will yield when forced to do so.

In many ways we are a product of our own cultures, and those of us who lead comfortable middle class lives often find it very difficult to understand how there can be such people in the world who are not similarly as reasonable and sensible as we are. I think it does require quite an effort at times to try to comprehend what motivates others with cultures entirely alien to our own and what is likely to persuade them to see what we regard as sweet reason. That I think is one of the regrettable features of the opposition to this motion in the Parliament, because in many ways I think there are a number of professional peace activists, and others seeking their votes, who refuse to analyse the options or concede that there are times when force as a last resort must be adopted.

However, it is at least very encouraging to find spokesmen for several of the major churches being prepared to stand up and be counted. We can all wring our hands and wish that it were not so. It is much harder to take the tough decisions and see them through. I therefore congratulate the Catholic and Anglican churches for having the courage to show moral leadership and accept that enough is enough.

It is hard to imagine a more clear cut case of brutal and unjustified aggression-the act of a megalomaniac or bully prepared to rape, pillage and plunder without compunction-yet what do those who oppose this option argue? If you are an Australian Democrat you first argued that the United Nations was the appropriate arbiter, not the United States of America, and that when the United Nations decided overwhelmingly to support a measured, and if necessary, forcible response, the argument changed. Now it is that sanctions ought to be given more time.

I do not think one needs to resort to the Central Intelligence Agency to understand the likely limited effectiveness of sanctions. If one is dealing with a rational ruler of a democracy and one who is likely to be responsive to public pressures, then one might have some real prospects. The way in which Mr Hawke goes to water every time there is a tough decision shows us how acutely sensitive some leaders can be. But we are dealing with a vastly different proposition when we have someone who has been prepared to embark upon what turned out to be an eight year war, one which he thought would be over fairly quickly, but one where he thought there was a political advantage to be gained-aspiring to leadership of the Arab world-and was prepared to sacrifice untold millions of dollars, and certainly up to a million lives in the pursuit of a goal which he achieved with very limited success and which he immediately forsook when he saw another opportunity for further aggrandisement.

That sort of behaviour could not be tolerated for a moment under any rational regime, and nor could people who were not cowered by years of brutal oppression, tyranny, persecution and execution have copped it for a moment, but of course cop it they do because they have no choice, and therefore the prospects of Saddam Hussein yielding to democratic pressures from within his own country or somehow being susceptible to moral suasion from the international community is not only remote in the extreme but verging on the self delusory. Therefore I find it interesting to canvass some of the arguments put forward by the Democrats, and in particular, Senator Vallentine who of course is the self-proclaimed leading peace activist in the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never proclaimed that; unfair!

—I am pleased to see that a degree of modesty is becoming. I took the opportunity to analyse her contribution in this chamber on 4 December, but not because I expect that she is likely to change her posture. Indeed, I believe that even those whom she purports to represent and those who, of course, will always have fear as the prime motivation, should not for a moment believe that sincerity is a substitute for sanity. Concern is no substitute for reason and logic is no substitute for emotion.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the rule of law ought to prevail and I hope that Senator Vallentine does too. Of course, that involves people being responsible for the consequences of their own actions; for enforcement procedures being put in place if a rogue nation or individual refuses to abide by the rules of the game-either domestic or international. Not even Senator Vallentine and the Democrats condone, let alone defend, the actions of Saddam Hussein. All their words are mere vacuous mouthings if they do not accept that adults must be accountable for their actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Timor?

—What about Timor? Timor is not comparable, much as there are those who might wish that Mr Whitlam had not given the encouragement that he did, in the face of a vacuum and in the face of a very powerful adjoining country which took the view that a departing colonial power had left a territory which it regarded as geographically proximate and, therefore, capable of being absorbed. That in no way can be compared to the actions of a state such as Kuwait which was not about to be vacated by a colonial power, and which was conducting its business in the same way that many other distasteful regimes-to Senator Spindler-are able to conduct their own business, and no-one advocates that they ought to be forcibly removed.

SPEECH.PARA: The motives for Saddam Hussein invading Kuwait would seem to be primarily economic. I do not think we ought to apologise for a moment. If one nation, which has something like 10 per cent of the world's oil resources under its power and control, not only seeks to take over another 10 per cent in Kuwait but makes all sorts of indications that ought to be taken seriously about acquiring the reserves of Saudi Arabia and, therefore, to have control of perhaps 50 per cent of the world's resources, we ought to be very concerned about that. It is not just another action which is harmless to the world community; it is an action that can virtually hold the world hostage.

Unless one is prepared to stand up and take action against those sorts of acts of blatant aggression, they can only be encouraged in the short term and, in the long term, they become an invitation to anarchy and the law of the jungle. That, I would have thought, is the last thing that those opposing this motion would profess to want to see. Indeed, when one looks at the history of the United Nations, one sees that for many years the West has despaired that it has never been able to get its act together. Apart from the occasional peacekeeping force that has been sent into places such as Cyprus and Kashmir, it has manifestly been unable to reach a conclusion that was in the best interests of the international community, largely because some nations have been prepared to exercise a blind veto.

It has only been in very recent times, with the collapse of communism in eastern Europe and a realisation by the Soviet Union that it is economically if not morally bankrupt, that these nations have come to their senses and been prepared to make reasonable decisions in the Security Council. That having occurred, it provides the United Nations, for almost the first time, with an ability to carry out the job that it was charged to do in the first instance.

The very people who now oppose this motion are those who for many years have always said that they do not condone the activities of the superpowers; that they do not believe that might is right but that these matters ought to be resolved in that international democratic forum, the United Nations. If that is the view that they have held for so long and have promoted in this and other forums, I cannot for the life of me see any logical or moral justification for the attitude that Senator Vallentine in particular has adopted to the latest series of UN resolutions. Make no mistake about it, Senator Vallentine is no international democrat. She simply says:
I do not care whether the United Nations Security Council agreed to it with two negative votes and one abstention, it is wrong . . .

Even if the United Nations did that, there would not be any sane person on the face of the earth who would want the type of war that might be unleashed in the Middle East-United Nations permission granted, or not . . . The United Nations can make mistakes. I think resolution 678 is a grave mistake.

How can one pretend to aspire to a democratic world order where decisions are made by the majority and not just the mighty, yet when we have an overwhelmingly one-sided result in both the General Assembly and the Security Council, we simply refuse to accept the outcome? That, I suggest, is not only morally superior; it is intolerant and utterly undemocratic. That is the problem with saying that sanctions ought to be given more time to work. If they do not, what does one do? One ends up wringing one's hands.
Again, what Senator Vallentine had to say about sanctions is virtually breathtaking. Her best argument is that in South Africa it took 12 years--

TALK.START.PARA: —That was sanctions.

—If Senator Powell wants to disown Senator Vallentine's view of the world I would be very interested to hear about it in due course, but I would have thought that they generally shared the same views. That is why I am analysing--
—I am disagreeing with what you are saying.
—Does Senator Powell agree with Senator Vallentine's views? Let me recite hers and we can see whether Senator Powell still does. Senator Vallentine said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Prime Minister, let the sanctions work. It took 12 years to find that the sanctions worked in South Africa. In the meantime, the black South African people have suffered and continue to suffer. The sanctions finally worked there without a military blockade to back them up. Why could not time have been allowed in the Gulf for the sanctions to work?
I cannot comprehend that Senator Vallentine or Senator Powell could seriously imagine that waiting even 12 months could do anything other than exacerbate the problem.

South Africa is not even a comparable case study, as we all know, because there 20 per cent of the population is in power, hoping to preside permanently over the other 80 per cent. I would not have thought time was on their side. Whether or not it is sanctions that have brought about the changes and upheavals in South Africa is still debatable.
