If we just take at face value the proposition that if we are prepared to wait 12 years we might get somewhere, we can see what preposterous and ludicrous nonsense the proposition is in the Gulf context. When someone has thumbed his nose at the world community, has been prepared to use even the 5 1/2 months that have elapsed since the first invasion not only to prop up his own forces in the region but also to dig into Kuwait, to pillage that country and remove all that was worthwhile, to appropriate it and annexe it as the nineteenth province of Iraq, one can imagine what would have happened if he had been given another six months or more-another 11 1/2 years-to go about his business and remain, presumably and inevitably, just as impervious to logic, criticism, persuasion and negotiation as he has proved to date.

In other words, we are talking about an utterly intransigent tyrant who is not amenable to logic, is not amenable to persuasion, and does not live in the same beautiful world that Senator Vallentine would like to see where everyone sits around the table and is reasonable and comes up with a negotiated solution that is satisfactory to all sides. This is not the Industrial Relations Commission. This is not simply another party to a dispute that one would like call in and say, `Come on, be reasonable. What is your bottom line?'. This is someone who has no compunction about using nerve gas, about exterminating his own political opponents, and about putting the Kurds out of business as a minority people in his own country-someone who will simply stop at nothing. We have seen that over the last 4 1/2 months.

I would have thought that if ever there was a good example of not rushing precipitately into a conflict, it is the behaviour pattern that we have seen from the United States, the nation, as I say, that gets no credit at all in this motion, obviously for factional reasons. Nonetheless, I am sure that the majority on the other side of the chamber would acknowledge that what President Bush has managed to do to date is embark on a very skilful exercise in diplomacy that has locked in a number of very unlikely players.

TALK.START.PARA: —He locked himself into a war scenario and we followed him like fools.

—That is where Senator Vallentine's intellectual intolerance demonstrates itself. On the one hand she says, `Look at this: America trying to rule the world; America trying to tell people what to do. How undemocratic. You ought to go off to the UN. If you can win your case there then you've got some democracy in action'. On the other hand, the minute it happens, the minute that 140 nations in the General Assembly assent to the proposition and 12--
—They meant sanctions, not war.
—I think we know what the Security Council resolved; it said, `If necessary, force'.
—Twelve nations out of 159, that's all.
—Order!

— If one believes in the legitimacy of the Senate as an upper House-we have not heard to date any dispute about the legitimacy of the Security Council-then one has to accept that the rules of that House are not a mirror image of the lower House. In other words, it was deliberately set up with five permanent members who were the most powerful players on the world scene in 1945 and it has since been expanded to the point where there are 10 rotating members. When there is a majority of 12 out of 15, one would think that we are being told something: that it is not just one person's or one nation's view of the world; that it represents a very widespread view of what is morally right and wrong. No-one wants to see a rush to war. In whose interest is that? It is certainly not in the moral interest of anyone. Yet, when we have that overwhelming majority view, those opposing the motion somehow pretend that that in itself is an illegitimate decision. I find that incomprehensible.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to take up any more time other than to say that we all regret the necessity for war. But I think we can console ourselves and our countrymen with the fact that it has come as a last resort. We can only hope that it will come to a speedy conclusion. But there is something more important than that, and that is a just conclusion.

I am sure that the Middle East will never be the same again. We would all hope that this horrible experience will ensure that future necessary changes will be accomplished by a reason based on a will to action. I have no doubt at all that by standing up and being counted at this time, the Assads of this world will think twice, the Gaddafis of this world will think twice, and hopefully Hussein will not be around for a second thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally oppose Australian involvement in this war. It is a very sad duty even to have to address this issue of Australia being at war. It is the mark of an uncivilised nation to respond to aggression with more violence. War debases and dehumanises our society. At this stage of human development we ought to be more enlightened, particularly because of the possible use of weapons of mass destruction. There just has to be a better way. I do not believe that this is a last resort; we have far from exhausted all other avenues.

SPEECH.PARA: International protests against the war were held on 19 January to mark the birthday of Martin Luther King. There is a national holiday in the United States to respect the amazing work of this man of non-violence. He is respected not only by the church community and the black community, for which he worked so hard, but also by mainstream American society. What would he be saying in the present situation? He would be advocating mediation. He would be advocating non-violence. What would Mahatma Gandhi be saying in this present situation? He would also be advocating non-violence. What would Jesus Christ be saying in this situation? He would also be advocating non-violence.

The churches have at last come out internationally against the war option. Contrary to what Senator Alston said, the Pope himself has spoken in opposition to the war option. The Catholic churches, which earlier in this argument were not supportive of the anti-war situation, now have the Pope to contend with on that score. Generally, churches are more enlightened than some of their predecessors, which have in the past tried to justify war in the name of Jesus Christ. The Crusades and the Inquisition are among the atrocities committed in the name of this man of peace. The churches are not justifying war this time because they know it is wrong. They know war will solve nothing but will exacerbate the problems of the Middle East. I encourage them to go further and to lead their congregations in civil disobedience and to let their governments know that the war must stop, and stop soon.

I am not prepared to support the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or the motion before the Senate today. I will counter some of the baseless allegations he and other Government Ministers, members and senators have made against the peace movement.

I need to make it quite clear from the outset that I am opposed to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, as I am opposed to any act of international aggression. Furthermore, I put it firmly on record that the peace movement is not advocating appeasement, nor is there any parallel with the 1930s in this respect. No-one is saying that Saddam Hussein should keep Kuwait, which is vastly different from the Japanese situation when it took over Manchuria; vastly different from when Italy occupied Abyssinia; and vastly different from when Germany occupied Czechoslovakia. That is a scandalous allegation and an invalid comparison.

The fundamental difference between the peace movement and this Government, and for that matter the coalition, is over the way in which we seek to resolve this conflict. The Government advocates the early war option or, as the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) put it, `going in with all guns blazing', while the peace movement advocates continued sanctions and negotiations. No-one here is advocating appeasement. There is a huge difference between this situation and the Hitler scenario, and that is that he had a huge industrial-military complex to continue his aggression unabated.

Saddam Hussein has been able to fight war for eight years only with outside help. More of that later. But freeze the arms supplies, as the United Nations (UN) embargo would have done, and Saddam Hussein would not have been able to continue.

Another allegation is that the peace movement is anti-American. This charge is frequently levied in order to discredit critics of the United States' role in the world today. It fails of course to distinguish between criticism of the United States and its people and criticism of United States Government policy, which is an entirely different matter. The peace movement in Australia has always worked closely with the peace movement in the United States. We have coordinated the dates of our rallies in North America and Australia, hosted United States anti-war speakers-of whom there are plenty-and supported United States marines who have opted not to fight for United States oil interests in the Gulf.

Our quarrel is with the policies of the Bush Administration and the forces which propelled it into war and the military-industrial complex which former President Eisenhower warned about as he left office. The Prime Minister has said that there is no comparison between the Gulf war and the Vietnam war, although I would have thought that the parallels were obvious. I note with some irony that there are a number of Government Ministers and members of parliament who were prominent in the movement against the Vietnam war but who now support the war option in the Gulf. I mention just a few Ministers from my own State-Kim Beazley, John Dawkins, Peter Cook and Bob McMullan, who was in Western Australia at the time of the Vietnam moratorium movement. They do amazing somersaults when it suits their politics.

I am sad and angry that the Government is too frightened to allow its own members a conscience vote on our participation in the Gulf war. Public opinion in this country is not wholeheartedly in support of the war option. Indeed, according to the Saulwick poll in the Sydney Morning Herald in December 1990, only 43 per cent of women are in favour of it. There is a gender difference there, which is hardly surprising.

It is a travesty of our political system that the bipartisan position of the two major parties on foreign policy means that they can never truly represent public opinion on issues such as our commitment to yet another foreign war on foreign soil. This is the most important issue to come before this Parliament in 25 years and all we are getting is set party pieces.

The Prime Minister has ignored the historic sequence of events whereby the United States moved troops into the Gulf and only then brought in other troops to make up a multinational force and lobbied the other four permanent members of the United Nations Security Council to support it. Nor did he mention his own role in deciding to send Australian naval forces to serve in the Gulf, then getting the Australian Embassy in Washington to arrange a telephone call between himself and President Bush to firm up the arrangement, a sequence outlined in the Sydney Morning Herald on 1 September last year. In fact, he was so enthusiastic that he offered five ships before realising that we did not have five ships to send. So, of course, our contribution is three.

There has been a great deal of discussion over the role of the United Nations in this conflict. What is really at issue is the interpretation of article 51 of the UN charter, which affirms the right of individual and collective self-defence. I believe that the United Nations was established to put an end to fighting, not to authorise the bombing and long haul bloody ground war that we are now contemplating in Iraq rather than just the liberation of Kuwait which, of course, will be the destruction of Kuwait. The United Nations should be a peace making and peacekeeping body, not a war fighting body. The people of Korea are still suffering from the United Nations' previous error in fighting a war there in the 1950s.

The Government has justified its position in the Gulf war by stressing its obligations under the UN charter. However, there is no obligation to commit troops to fight. I have heard no criticism whatsoever of the 131 member countries of the United Nations which are not involved in this war. It was a matter of choice and Australia chose because the Prime Minister pushed Australia to fight in this war. A mere 28 out of 159 nations have chosen to go to war; there is no United Nations obligation.

As Senator Powell pointed out resolution 678 was not a compulsion to use force by any stretch of the imagination. The Government has argued that sanctions will take too long to work. As Senator Powell has already pointed out, this is at some variance with a Central Intelligence Agency report, although we do not always believe the CIA, where its Director, William Webster, testified on Capitol Hill in Washington-so we would hope he was speaking the truth-before the Congress of the United States that Iraqi exports had been slashed by 97 per cent and its imports by 90 per cent since the implementation of the sanctions.

We do not pretend that sanctions will work overnight but sanctions were given only five months and we are told they have not worked yet. None of the people supporting the war option are saying that a war lasting months will also be a failure. There is no mention either of the cost as long as oil prices do not rocket. Of course the taxpayers will be picking up the bill for this expensive and destructive exercise for years, and at the cost of social programs which are vastly more important.

There is a further irony in the way in which other issues have been put on the backburner in order to solicit world support for the US-inspired blockade. China has suddenly been rehabilitated; Syria, which until August was officially on record as a terrorist state, is now part of the multinational force, despite the atrocities carried out against its own people by the regime of President Assad; and Soviet military intervention in Lithuania has virtually been ignored. All this has been done in order to maintain the facade of unity against Iraq.

We then have to ask: who created this monster, as the media like to portray Saddam Hussein? Senator Evans referred to the enormous military forces amassed by Iraq, but he did not say who provided them. The Stockholm Peace Research Institute has recorded that some 30 countries armed Iraq between 1980 and 1988. For the record let me list them: Austria, Belgium, Brazil, Britain, Bulgaria, Chile, China, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, France, West Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, North Korea, The Netherlands, Pakistan, Poland, Portugal, South Korea, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the United States, the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia sold arms to both sides in the Iran-Iraq war- great morality-while Ethiopia, Egypt, Jordan and the Philippines sold arms only to Iraq.

According to Western intelligence officials and a variety of military experts, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was able to amass the most powerful items of his arsenal by appealing to two strong emotions among his foreign suppliers: firstly, their hunger for Iraqi petrodollars and, secondly, in the West particularly, their fear of an Iranian victory in the 1980 Gulf war. Between 1980 and 1988 Iraq became the largest retail buyer of arms in the world, spending $US43 billion for weapons deliveries by the end of 1987, the last year for which figures are available. That is according to the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

After he came to power in 1979, sometimes with deception but often with the silent acquiescence of Western governments, Saddam Hussein was able to acquire the machines, components, tools and expertise to develop chemical, biological and nuclear weapons. A confidential report to the German Parliament in August 1990 by Economic Minister Helmut Hausmann said West German companies were the main suppliers for all of Iraq's major weapons projects, including its nuclear weapons project, poison gas facilities, ballistic missiles, and long-range super cannon development. With West German assistance, the report says, Iraq is now believed to be five years away from producing its own nuclear bomb. In the United States, Commerce Department figures show that between 1985 and 1990 the United States approved the export to Iraq of $US1.5 billion-worth of dual-use items with military as well as civilian application, including powerful computers, precision machine tools and advanced electronics.

Although suspicions by Pentagon officials halted the export of certain items, such as kyrton nuclear triggers and `skull' furnaces which could be used in the development of missiles and nuclear bombs, many other sophisticated items were sent to Iraq and are believed to have enhanced Saddam Hussein's chemical war machine, his missile development program, intelligence gathering capability and battlefield communications, according to Pentagon officials. Michael Maloof, Director of Technology Security Operations at the Pentagon's Department for Trade Security Policy, says:
The reality is that our guys in the desert are now facing sophisticated American technology sold to the Iraqis over the years by the Commerce Department.

So, who is to blame for the situation in which we find ourselves now? All we are trying to do is disable the military machine which the West in particular helped to create. Yet a public opinion poll indicates that 73 per cent of Americans are not even aware of the fact that the United States sold arms to Iraq between 1980 and 1988. I suspect too that even fewer Australians are aware of this and of the fact that Australia was prepared to sell military equipment to the same regime last year. The media is having a field day describing the high tech weapons in the desert, but they seem curiously silent about who sold them to Iraq.

The trade credits were largely provided by the United States and the United Kingdom, yet this was the regime which invaded Iran in 1980 just as it invaded Kuwait in August 1990, and the world stayed silent. Iraq was confidently backed by Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states because it held the balance of power in the region-a balance which is now being upset by the stated US aim of wiping Iraq out as a military power. The long term US presence will not only strengthen Iran and Israel-the traditional enemies of the conservative oil states-but will also strengthen the forces of fundamentalist Islam throughout the Middle East and the world.

There has been much criticism of the Palestine Liberation Organisation in this crisis, but the PLO is rapidly losing ground to the fundamentalist movement, Hamas, especially in the Gaza Strip and especially amongst young people. Israel, tacitly supported by the United States, has managed to block off UN resolutions on the occupied territories since 1967. However, if it thought the PLO was too extreme to talk to, it has not yet met Hamas. The PLO has had it on record for over two years that it supports the right of Israel to exist, and still Israel is not prepared to talk to it.

The Prime Minister in his proposed resolution refers to an eventual settlement to the Israel-Palestine conflict, but it is not acknowledged that the problem will be much harder as a result of this war. It is ironic to note that the Prime Minister now calls for Palestine to go onto the agenda after the crisis-war-because had he said that before the war, the war might have been averted. It is one of the things called for to be put on the international agenda. Clearly, linkage, so adamantly resistant by the US, is vital and the Prime Minister now recognises this.

We know that Iraq is developing a nuclear capability, but no one seems willing to get up and say where Saddam Hussein got it from, which is curious, to say the least. Nor has anyone said why, if it is wrong for Iraq to have nuclear weapons, we keep quiet about Israel's nuclear weapons and the imprisonment of Mordecai Vanunu for telling the truth about that Israeli nuclear arsenal. I suggest that this proliferation in such an unstable part of the world is sound justification for declaring that all nuclear weapons are immoral and cutting off this proliferation at source is imperative.

We have heard, too, of the atrocities of Saddam Hussein since 1979. However, we have not heard a good explanation of why the world acquiesced in the invasion of Iran in 1980 and why there was an uneasy silence over the use of chemical weapons at Halabja in 1988. Did anyone from this Government speak to the Kurds who demonstrated outside Parliament House at the time or listen to their tales of horror? After the prior Gulf war was over in 1988, even Australia was prepared to sell weapons to this atrocious regime, although the deal in aircraft spare parts was called off after the 2 August invasion. Indeed the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) said last year that he saw nothing wrong with the proposed sale. When the Prime Minister announced that we were at war, he spoke of the new international order. What is new about an international order based on the firepower that is now amassed in the Arabian desert?

Supporters of the war option have said that the peace movement should put forward an alternative. From the outset I have suggested a negotiating position. In a speech in the Senate on 19 December last year I detailed that; I will reiterate the main points now. An alternative is not based on appeasement nor on rewarding Saddam Hussein. I outlined a three-step approach to the conflict in the Gulf suggesting possible solutions to the issue of the disputed islands of Bubiyan and Warbah, the al-Rumeilah oil field and the long term wider problems in the Middle East.

I drew an analogy with the Aland Islands in the Baltic which were the subject of a dispute between Sweden and Finland after the First World War. That issue was resolved when the Council of the League of Nations adjudicated in favour of a demilitarised zone which has stood to this day, while the islands remain part of Finland. Disputes over oil fields across national boundaries can be resolved by negotiation just as Australia settled the dispute with Indonesia over the Timor Sea oil reserves, although it took a long time. It is unfortunate that we were negotiating with the wrong country in that situation.

As for the general conference on the Middle East, I drew an analogy with the Congress of Vienna in Europe in 1814-15 following the ravages of the Napoleonic wars that lasted over 20 years. Such a conference could be in three stages: stage 1 could cover Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait; stage 2 could deal with the Israeli-Palestine issue; stage 3 could set up a stable government in the Lebanon with UN guarantees. At each level the UN or the Arab League would be needed either as observers or to act as peacekeepers, and certainly as guarantors of agreements.

It might take years but the problems will remain whether we choose to pour more arms into the area for future wars or patiently attempt to work them out over many months, if not years. These problems go back decades and they will not be solved overnight.

Nearer to Australia than the Gulf is Cambodia. Australia chose to play a more constructive negotiating role in that conflict, although I believe that Pol Pot has been more of a monster than Saddam Hussein, yet the world community chose to allow his representatives to occupy a seat at the United Nations for many years. This is the selective indignation that we can no longer tolerate.

The Arab masses are puzzled why the United States can disregard United Nations resolutions on Palestine since 1967, especially resolution 262, and later ones on Lebanon, but act so fast over Kuwait. Others look at the new found enthusiasm of the United States for the United Nations and think back to the blatant disregard for UN resolutions shown by the United States over the invasion of Panama. It was also a disgrace that Mr Hawke instructed the Australian delegation to change its position and to vote against the UN resolution criticising US interventionism in Panama just over a year ago.

Then there was the refusal of the United States Government to acknowledge the authority of the International Court of Justice when it mined Nicaragua's harbours. It completely ignored it. Nearer home again, we have the appalling hypocrisy of this Government over Indonesia's invasion of East Timor. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) could only lamely say in answer to my question on this parallel last month that this unfortunate invasion happened in 1975 and it was a bit late to do anything about it.

I reflected that Australia had refused to acknowledge the Soviet Union's illegal jurisdiction over the Baltic states for more than 50 years, but somehow this too was different. The Government's hypocrisy over East Timor is blatant and disgraceful. We must and we will change government policy to ensure self-determination for the people of East Timor. The Government claims public support for its position, yet public opinion polls indicate that only 56 per cent support the decision to send war ships to the Gulf to use force to eject Iraq from Kuwait.

It is a savage indictment of Parliament that only a handful of senators and one member of the House of Representatives are speaking out on behalf of this substantial number of Australians who can see what this conflict is really about and believe that there is another way to solve it. There has been much greater debate in Europe and North America than in Australia even though these countries too have joined the multinational force. It was a close debate in the United States Senate and President Bush only got his war making powers authorised by 52 votes to 47. One of his critics was the Chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Senator Sam Nunn. During the debate he asked:

Will I be able to say to the families of the Americans in the Middle East that their loved ones sacrificed their lives for a cause vital to the United States and that there was no other reasonable alternative? At this time I cannot.

Other leading senators urged Mr Bush to allow sanctions to work, arguing that sufficient time had not been given for them to do so. Yet in Australia, Australian Labor Party (ALP) criticism has once again been muzzled by the Prime Minister, although at the State level MPs have been less inclined to keep quiet.

I pay tribute to my colleagues from the Labor Party in the West Australian Alliance for Peace in the Middle East who have had the courage to speak out, along with other ALP members of State parliaments in Victoria, Queensland, New South Wales, and possibly other States. I only wish that their Federal counterparts had been allowed a conscience vote on this issue and permitted to speak out here in Canberra as well. Indeed, it is a waste of time and money for Parliament to return for set pieces. War is government legalised and government organised mass murder on a grand scale at the taxpayers expense. The taxpayers just see set pieces and people are not able to speak from their hearts about this concern.

I want to mention the concerns expressed about the use of US bases in Australia in this Gulf conflict. As Dr Michael McKinley and Dr Desmond Ball at the Australian National University have put on the record, Pine Gap, Nurrungar and North West Cape are all playing an active part in this war, although we shall not hear any acknowledgment of this fact from the Minister for Defence. It therefore seems too important to put it on the record, given that this involvement clearly alters Australia's traditional even-handed policy on the Middle East.

Pine Gap would be picking up communications within Iraq, which is based on microwave transmission, and the same would occur between Iraq and Kuwait. All communications which have microwave links as their bases would be monitored by Pine Gap. Nurrungar which is hooked up to the DSP satellites is picking up the Scud missile launches. This information is then downlinked into Nurrungar and relayed to central command communication headquarters in Saudi Arabia, and presumably from there to Israel where the information could be used by the crews of the Patriot anti-missile missile.

North West Cape passes on communications to US naval forces in the Gulf. Given the current situation most, if not all, of the information would be handled by the US staff despite the myth of the joint facilities. Why can the Government not admit this and end the farce of referring to an obsolete non-statement on the basis made by the Prime Minister several years ago which says precisely nothing? We should never have allowed the setting up of these US bases in Australia in the first place and the sooner we close them down completely, the better.
Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the interjections about Israel are concerned, Iraq would not have launched its attack on Israel had not the multinational forces been engaged in the Gulf. This is a classic case of violence producing more violence and aggression producing more aggression.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to environmental issues. Warfare in the Gulf would be an environmental disaster. While some of the likely impacts are familiar from past conflicts, others will be unique because of the intense fire power now concentrated in the region and because of its distinctive geography and ecology.

I refer, firstly, to burning oil. Oil fires and oil contamination are the most serious environmental hazards of a war in the Gulf. Smoke, soot and chemicals produced by the burning of oil wells and facilities could cause temporary regional or global cooling. One hundred days of burning would produce a cloud of smoke covering half the northern hemisphere lasting months if not years. The cloud would threaten agricultural production. Agriculture as far away as India could be affected by the cooling and disruption of the monsoons. The result could be mass starvation of people with little or no stake in the conflict. Oil fields set alight deliberately would take a very long time to put out. There are only four or five crews in the world experienced in putting out oil well fires. It could take months, if not years, to put out the fires.

Then there is the question of the spilling of oil. Oil will flow into the Gulf from military attacks on refineries, oil terminals, storage tanks, pipelines, offshore wells and tankers. A single storage tank can hold as much as was spilled by the Exxon Valdez, the United States' worst oil spill. The shallow and relatively enclosed nature of the Gulf will worsen any impact from oil spills and its currents will carry any oil towards the shores of Saudi Arabia and nearby nations threatening desalination plants vital to making fresh water for drinking and agriculture.
I turn now to the question of destroying the deserts. The deployment of more than one million troops in the Gulf deserts has already disrupted their rich and delicate ecosystems.
Senator Schacht interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am including them. Armies generally produce prodigious amounts of garbage, toxic waste and sewage. It is unlikely that in the rush to deploy and reinforce troops any of the armies have taken much care to ensure that their wastes are being disposed of properly. Digging and traffic in the desert are disturbing and destroying plants and wildlife and generating dust storms. Deserts, which are very fragile environments, are susceptible to increasing erosion.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the question of explosive remnants. Nearly every modern war has littered its battlefields with unexploded bombs, mines and shells. All bombs and missiles do not work as planned and buried explosives cause casualties long after the fighting stops.

Then there is chemical contamination. Nerve gases are volatile and will dissipate within hours or days. However, exposure can cause a quick death to any living thing without a gas mask. Mustard gas is much more persistent and does not break down readily. Unexploded chemical shells could cause local tragedy if set off. The destruction of chemical weapons production and storage facilities could rupture storage containers or bombs releasing the chemicals whether they are deliberately used or not.

I now refer to the nuclear legacy. Destruction of nuclear facilities or weapons, even if they are not exploded, would release an array of radioactive substances. Nuclear explosions would spread short and long lived radioactivity over a wide area. The impact of attacks on nuclear facilities in the region, such as Israel's major nuclear weapons complex at Dimona, Iraq's smaller research reactors or United States nuclear-powered war ships would also spread radioactivity.

Then there is the water war. The possible destruction of Iraq's dykes, dams and other irrigation structures could decimate agricultural production in the fertile valley of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers. These waters have made possible the cultivation of arid land for centuries, turning Iraq into the breadbasket of the Gulf. Archaeological treasures in this area, one of the cradles of civilisation, are in the battle zone and could be lost forever.

The rich marshlands at the mouths of the two rivers which host migratory water fowl are also at risk. Grazing areas already overstressed would be devastated. Massive amounts of refugees fleeing the war zone and induced environmental contamination would further strain resources and ecosystems in the area.

Finally, I want to salute the members of the international Gulf peace team who went to the Iraq-Saudi border to witness their conviction that war was not the right way to resolve this conflict. They are extremely brave. I hope they come back safely.

I want to express once more my concern for the Arab-Australian community facing a racist backlash and to reiterate my concern for Australian Defence Force personnel and their families and to wish our forces a safe and speedy return home. I grieve for the innocent victims of this war, whether they be in Kuwait, Iraq, Israel or any other country which may become directly involved at a later date. In totally objecting to Australia's involvement in this war I therefore call for an immediate cease-fire in the Gulf and an immediate stop to all Australian support for this war which should never have happened.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns those in authority in the Soviet Union who have acted to resume by force military control over Lithuania;
(b) profoundly deplores the killing of innocent Lithuanian citizens and the use of Soviet troops and tanks at the front door of the Lithuanian Parliament;
(c) calls on the Government of the Soviet Union to bring this brutality to an end and to permit the fledgling moves towards democracy in the Baltic States to take their natural course; and
(d) conveys these sentiments to the Government of the Soviet Union.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
